-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3126
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-01 00:50:51
Subject:Happy New Year 2003!!
Message:

Check out the ProLibertad Web site:
http://ProLibertadWeb.Tripod.com/page7.html

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign wishes our allies and supporters, 
nationally and internationally, a Happy New Year of organizing, educating 
and mobilizing in 2003.

As we enter another year of work, victories and opportunities, We in 
ProLibertad, feel it is important for us to remind people that there are 
STILL five Puerto Rican Political Prisoners in U.S. jails.  Imprisoned for 
their actions and politics as freedom fighting revolutionaries, it is 
important to remember the sacrifice they have made for La Patria (The 
Country of Puerto Rico)and do whatever we can to support the movement for 
which they have been incarcerated.

Below are their addresses; we urge you to write to them and to create a 
relationship with them.  It is our letters, post cards and donations of 
money that show the prisoners that we are thinking of them and support our 
National Liberation struggle.

Write to them:

Oscar Lopez Rivera
#87651-024
P.O. Box 33
Terre Haute, IN 47808

Haydee Beltran Torres
#88462-024
SCI Tallahassee
501 Capitol Circle NE
Tallahassee, FL 32031

Carlos Alberto Torres
#88976-024
P.O. Box 1000
Oxford, WI 53952

Juan Segarra Palmer
#15357-077
FCI Coleman Med.
P.O. Box 1032
Coleman, FL 33521

Pedro Colon Almenas
#22192-069
MDC Guaynabo
P.O. Box 2147
San Juan, PR  00922-2147







_________________________________________________________________
Help STOP SPAM: Try the new MSN 8 and get 2 months FREE* 
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail

Post ID:3127
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-01 00:51:35
Subject:Happy New Year 2003!!
Message:

Check out the ProLibertad Web site:
http://ProLibertadWeb.Tripod.com/page7.html

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign wishes our allies and supporters, 
nationally and internationally, a Happy New Year of organizing, educating 
and mobilizing in 2003.

As we enter another year of work, victories and opportunities, We in 
ProLibertad, feel it is important for us to remind people that there are 
STILL five Puerto Rican Political Prisoners in U.S. jails.  Imprisoned for 
their actions and politics as freedom fighting revolutionaries, it is 
important to remember the sacrifice they have made for La Patria (The 
Country of Puerto Rico)and do whatever we can to support the movement for 
which they have been incarcerated.

Below are their addresses; we urge you to write to them and to create a 
relationship with them.  It is our letters, post cards and donations of 
money that show the prisoners that we are thinking of them and support our 
National Liberation struggle.

Write to them:

Oscar Lopez Rivera
#87651-024
P.O. Box 33
Terre Haute, IN 47808

Haydee Beltran Torres
#88462-024
SCI Tallahassee
501 Capitol Circle NE
Tallahassee, FL 32031

Carlos Alberto Torres
#88976-024
P.O. Box 1000
Oxford, WI 53952

Juan Segarra Palmer
#15357-077
FCI Coleman Med.
P.O. Box 1032
Coleman, FL 33521

Pedro Colon Almenas
#22192-069
MDC Guaynabo
P.O. Box 2147
San Juan, PR  00922-2147

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3128
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-01 11:10:00
Subject:Three Kings, 10 Political Prisoners and 1 Struggle
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is making a call to all progressive
organizations; ProLibertad and The Venceremos Brigade (the oldest solidarity 
organization around Cuba that goes to Cuba annually to work on civic 
projects in support of the revolution)are organizing a special fundraiser 
for the Cuban Five and the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

In order to endorse, we ask organizations to donate $25 as a special
commissary gift for the Cuban Five. We are trying to raise $2500 for the 
Cuban Five as a special Three Kings Commissary Gift.

If you are interested in endorsing please email ProLibertad
(ProLibertad@...) with your response so that we can add your name to 
the announcement emails and to the special Three Kings activity webpage on 
the ProLibertad website.

Please send your endorsement fee to:

IFCO/ProLibertad/Cuban Five
402 w145th St.
New York, NY 10031
________________________________________________________________________

Three Kings!! 10 Political Prisoners!! 1 Struggle!!

A special Three Kings CELEBRATION/ Night of Poetry for the Puerto Rican and 
the Cuban Political Prisoners!! Sponsored by the Venceremos Brigade and The 
ProLibertad Freedom Campaign!!

Saturday January 4th, 2003 At 6:30pm
St. Mary's Church 521 W126th St.(between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)

Invited Poets:
SANDRA MARIA ESTEVEZ
LUIS REYES RIVERA
REV. PEDRO PIETRI

ALL OF THIS FOR JUST A $10 DONATION

The Puerto Rican Political Prisoners and Prisoners of War are imprisoned for 
struggling (or in some cases simply supporting) Puerto Rican Independence 
from the U.S.

The Cuban Political Prisoners are imprisoned for defending Cuba
by infiltrating terrorist organizations based in the U.S.

For more information call 718-601-4751

ENDORSING ORGANIZATIONS:
New Black Panther Party
FREE MUMIA COALITION
Where we live, WBAI
Cuba in focus, WBAI
Know Thy Self Speakers Bureau
Bring da noise productions(speaking truth to power for the hiphop
generation),
La Iglesia san Juan Bautista
Iglesia San Romero de Las Americas
Uptown for Peace with Justice
IFCO/Pastors for Peace
Free the Five Committee
SALAAM
National Network on Cuba
Stand Up New York
ANARCHIST BLACK CROSS FEDERATION-NORTHEAST BRANCH
Jeanine Maland
Asociacion Pro Derechos de los Confinados
Yuri Kochiyama
El Comite de solidaridad con Cuba, Puerto Rico
NY Cuba Solidarity Movement






_________________________________________________________________
MSN 8: advanced junk mail protection and 2 months FREE*. 
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail

Post ID:3129
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-01 11:10:55
Subject:3 Kings, 10 Political Prisoners, and 1 Struggle
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is making a call to all progressive
organizations; ProLibertad and The Venceremos Brigade (the oldest solidarity 
organization around Cuba that goes to Cuba annually to work on civic 
projects in support of the revolution)are organizing a special fundraiser 
for the Cuban Five and the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

In order to endorse, we ask organizations to donate $25 as a special
commissary gift for the Cuban Five. We are trying to raise $2500 for the 
Cuban Five as a special Three Kings Commissary Gift.

If you are interested in endorsing please email ProLibertad
(ProLibertad@...) with your response so that we can add your name to 
the announcement emails and to the special Three Kings activity webpage on 
the ProLibertad website.

Please send your endorsement fee to:

IFCO/ProLibertad/Cuban Five
402 w145th St.
New York, NY 10031
________________________________________________________________________

Three Kings!! 10 Political Prisoners!! 1 Struggle!!

A special Three Kings CELEBRATION/ Night of Poetry for the Puerto Rican and 
the Cuban Political Prisoners!! Sponsored by the Venceremos Brigade and The 
ProLibertad Freedom Campaign!!

Saturday January 4th, 2003 At 6:30pm
St. Mary's Church 521 W126th St.(between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)

Invited Poets:
SANDRA MARIA ESTEVEZ
LUIS REYES RIVERA
REV. PEDRO PIETRI

ALL OF THIS FOR JUST A $10 DONATION

The Puerto Rican Political Prisoners and Prisoners of War are imprisoned for 
struggling (or in some cases simply supporting) Puerto Rican Independence 
from the U.S.

The Cuban Political Prisoners are imprisoned for defending Cuba
by infiltrating terrorist organizations based in the U.S.

For more information call 718-601-4751

ENDORSING ORGANIZATIONS:
New Black Panther Party
FREE MUMIA COALITION
Where we live, WBAI
Cuba in focus, WBAI
Know Thy Self Speakers Bureau
Bring da noise productions(speaking truth to power for the hiphop
generation),
La Iglesia san Juan Bautista
Iglesia San Romero de Las Americas
Uptown for Peace with Justice
IFCO/Pastors for Peace
Free the Five Committee
SALAAM
National Network on Cuba
Stand Up New York
ANARCHIST BLACK CROSS FEDERATION-NORTHEAST BRANCH
Jeanine Maland
Asociacion Pro Derechos de los Confinados
Yuri Kochiyama
El Comite de solidaridad con Cuba, Puerto Rico
NY Cuba Solidarity Movement

projects in support of the revolution)are organizing a special fundraiser

Cuban Five as a special Three Kings Commissary Gift.

the announcement emails and to the special Three Kings activity webpage on

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3134
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 09:46:14
Subject:Go to Cuba-Join Venceremos Brigade
Message:

This July, the 34th contingent of the Venceremos Brigade will spend two 
weeks in Cuba.  As part of a �Travel Challenge,� organized with IFCO/Pastors 
for Peace, Brigadistas will challenge the u.s. blockade on Cuba.  We hope 
that your organization will play a role in this year�s contingent, either by 
sending representatives on the trip and/or supporting our efforts in other 
ways.

On SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8TH FROM 3:00PM-5:00PM, we will be holding an 
informational meeting for all those interested in finding out more.  The 
meeting will be held at 10 Park Terrace East, #1L (A train to 207th St, 1 
train to 215th St).

For more information and to confirm your organization�s attendance, please 
email vbrigade@... or call 212-560-4360.  Individuals with no 
organizational affiliation are also encouraged to attend.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
The Venceremos Brigade is an anti-imperialist educational project that, 
since 1969, has sent over 8,000 people to Cuba.  A national organization, 
the Brigade brings people together from all over the U.S. for an 
unforgettable, life changing experience.  During trips, brigadistas 
participate in agricultural and/or construction work while also learning 
about Cuba�s revolution, history, and culture.

This year, the Venceremos Brigade has launched a special campaign.  Along 
with IFCO/Pastors for Peace, we are calling upon people across the country 
to join a mass �Travel Challenge.�  Around 75% of the U.S. population, 
including a majority of Cuban Americans, want an end to the travel ban.  
Over the past two years, both houses of Congress have voted not to enforce 
the travel restrictions.  Yet, since Bush became president, harassment of 
travelers to Cuba, both licensed and unlicensed, has greatly increased.  In 
this climate, it is clear that the Cuba solidarity  movement must take a 
stand.

The Venceremos Brigade has always traveled unlicensed in order to make a 
statement against the U.S. blockade on Cuba, an inhumane policy that attacks 
both the island�s sovereignty and its 11 million people.  This July, 
however, brigadistas will make our most open challenge to the U.S. travel 
restrictions.  In order for the �Travel Challenge� to work, a lot of folks 
will have to participate.

The �Travel Challenge� is not the only reason to (re)join the Venceremos 
Brigade now.  The 34th contingent will participate in Cuba�s national 
celebrations for a special July 26th--this year marks the 50th anniversary 
of the attack on the Moncada Garrison.  The trip will have a special 
concentration on Cuba�s elders, as we hope to participate in the renovation 
of la Habana�s �Casas de Ancianos,� and to collect oral histories from some 
of the island�s elder generation.  The program will also include events 
centered around Cuban hip hop, democracy, health care, education, among 
other topics.










_________________________________________________________________
The new MSN 8: smart spam protection and 2 months FREE*  
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3135
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 09:45:16
Subject:Go to Cuba-Join Venceremos Brigade
Message:

This July, the 34th contingent of the Venceremos Brigade will spend two 
weeks in Cuba.  As part of a �Travel Challenge,� organized with IFCO/Pastors 
for Peace, Brigadistas will challenge the u.s. blockade on Cuba.  We hope 
that your organization will play a role in this year�s contingent, either by 
sending representatives on the trip and/or supporting our efforts in other 
ways.

On SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8TH FROM 3:00PM-5:00PM, we will be holding an 
informational meeting for all those interested in finding out more.  The 
meeting will be held at 10 Park Terrace East, #1L (A train to 207th St, 1 
train to 215th St).

For more information and to confirm your organization�s attendance, please 
email vbrigade@... or call 212-560-4360.  Individuals with no 
organizational affiliation are also encouraged to attend.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
The Venceremos Brigade is an anti-imperialist educational project that, 
since 1969, has sent over 8,000 people to Cuba.  A national organization, 
the Brigade brings people together from all over the U.S. for an 
unforgettable, life changing experience.  During trips, brigadistas 
participate in agricultural and/or construction work while also learning 
about Cuba�s revolution, history, and culture.

This year, the Venceremos Brigade has launched a special campaign.  Along 
with IFCO/Pastors for Peace, we are calling upon people across the country 
to join a mass �Travel Challenge.�  Around 75% of the U.S. population, 
including a majority of Cuban Americans, want an end to the travel ban.  
Over the past two years, both houses of Congress have voted not to enforce 
the travel restrictions.  Yet, since Bush became president, harassment of 
travelers to Cuba, both licensed and unlicensed, has greatly increased.  In 
this climate, it is clear that the Cuba solidarity  movement must take a 
stand.

The Venceremos Brigade has always traveled unlicensed in order to make a 
statement against the U.S. blockade on Cuba, an inhumane policy that attacks 
both the island�s sovereignty and its 11 million people.  This July, 
however, brigadistas will make our most open challenge to the U.S. travel 
restrictions.  In order for the �Travel Challenge� to work, a lot of folks 
will have to participate.

The �Travel Challenge� is not the only reason to (re)join the Venceremos 
Brigade now.  The 34th contingent will participate in Cuba�s national 
celebrations for a special July 26th--this year marks the 50th anniversary 
of the attack on the Moncada Garrison.  The trip will have a special 
concentration on Cuba�s elders, as we hope to participate in the renovation 
of la Habana�s �Casas de Ancianos,� and to collect oral histories from some 
of the island�s elder generation.  The program will also include events 
centered around Cuban hip hop, democracy, health care, education, among 
other topics.

Post ID:3136
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-14 16:07:49
Subject:Vieques Political Prisoners
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is urging all of our allies and supporters 
to write to the following Vieques Political Prisoners.

The five brothers below are members of the Puerto Rican Independence Party 
that were arrested for engaging in civil disobedience in Vieques, yesterday 
when the bombing practices recommenced.

Luis A. Amely Mart�nez - 25851-069
Francisco Bartolomei Crespo - 25852-069
Edwin Vargas Becerril - 25853-069
Abraham Ayala Ortiz - 25854-069
�ngel Rub�n Santiago Aponte - 25855-069

MDC Guaynabo
PO Box 2147
San Juan, Puerto Rico  00922-2147

Post ID:3138
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-14 22:19:30
Subject:SUPPORT CARLOS ALBERTO!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters 
to support this action;  Please contact Kathleen Saywer of the Bureau of 
Prisons to allow Carlos Alberto Torres, A Puerto Rican Political Prisoner in 
U.S. jails, to be visited by his father, Rev. Jose Torres and his mother 
Alexandrina Torres, a former Puerto Rican political prisoner released on 
Sept. 11th, 1999.

Contacts for Bureau of Prisons:

Warden,
FCI Oxford,
Box 1000,
Oxford, WI 53952,
telephone 608/584-5511, fax
608/584-6325;

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer,
Director, Federal Bureau of Prisons,
320 First Street
NW, Washington, D.C. 20534,
telephone 202/514-8534, fax 202/514-6878


COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907


                               PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others can
claim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In 
1999,after serving 16 years, Alejandrina was released when President 
Clintoncommuted the sentences of eleven of Puerto Rico's political 
prisoners,finding their sentences ranging from 35 to 90 years were 
disproportionatelylengthy. Inexplicably, Mr. Clinton left behind Carlos 
Alberto, whose disproportionate 70 year sentence will keep him imprisoned 
until the year 2024.

Upon her release she applied to visit her stepson Carlos Alberto at FCI
Oxford, Wisconsin, to reunite with him and to take Rev. Torres to see their 
son together. While parole authorities supported this family reunion, Oxford 
prison authorities denied the request, in spite of Carlos Alberto's 
exemplary conduct; in spite of the fact that Alejandrina, like all eleven of 
those whose sentences were commuted, had successfully reintegrated into 
civil society; and in spite of their having permitted other former prisoners 
to visit their imprisoned family members.

Now, three years later, Alejandrina continues to work as a mentor in an
alternative high school, to participate in her church and community, and to 
fully comply with the conditions of her parole. And now, three years later, 
Reverend Torres, with cancer raging through his 80 year old body, has again 
been denied this family reunion, the prison having once again turned down 
their modest request to be permitted to share together in the confines of 
the prison visiting room under the watchful eye of prison officials. "It 
would mean so much to Papi," daughter Dr. Catalina Torres stated, "to be 
able to see Mami and Berti (Carlos Alberto) together before he dies."

"Christmas is such an important moment for Puerto Rican families to be
together, and this may well be Rev. Torres' last Christmas," said Rev.
Alfonso Rom�n, of Puerto Rico's Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos (Human Rights 
Committee), whose letter writing campaign aims to convince Oxford and Bureau 
of Prisons officials to allow the family visit.

Joining the campaign will be many of Rev. Torres' friends and colleagues
from the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto Mart�nez,
Evangelical Council of Puerto Rico; Rev. Luis Rosario, Conference 
MinisterUnited Evangelical Church of Puerto Rico, Rev. Miguel Vilar and Rev. 
Cheo Vilar of the Episcopal Church of Puerto Rico; Rev. Nozomi Ikuta of the 
Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience Project. in Cleveland, OH; and Father 
Angel Dar�o Carrero of the Jesuits of Puerto Rico. On Sunday, December 22, 
churches throughout Puerto Rico and the United States will devote their 
services to the Torres family, praying for their reunion.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:
Rev. Alfonso Rom�n, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean
Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 00907, 787/725-6284





_________________________________________________________________
Add photos to your e-mail with MSN 8. Get 2 months FREE*. 
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/featuredemail

Post Date/Time:2003-01-14 22:18:27
Subject:SUPPORT CARLOS ALBERTO!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters 
to support this action;  Please contact Kathleen Saywer of the Bureau of 
Prisons to allow Carlos Alberto Torres, A Puerto Rican Political Prisoner in 
U.S. jails, to be visited by his father, Rev. Jose Torres and his mother 
Alexandrina Torres, a former Puerto Rican political prisoner released on 
Sept. 11th, 1999.

Contacts for Bureau of Prisons:

Warden,
FCI Oxford,
Box 1000,
Oxford, WI 53952,
telephone 608/584-5511, fax
608/584-6325;

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer,
Director, Federal Bureau of Prisons,
320 First Street
NW, Washington, D.C. 20534,
telephone 202/514-8534, fax 202/514-6878


COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907


                               PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others can
claim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In

been denied this family reunion, the prison having once again turned down 
their modest request to be permitted to share together in the confines of 
the prison visiting room under the watchful eye of prison officials. "It 
would mean so much to Papi," daughter Dr. Catalina Torres stated, "to be 
able to see Mami and Berti (Carlos Alberto) together before he dies."

"Christmas is such an important moment for Puerto Rican families to be
together, and this may well be Rev. Torres' last Christmas," said Rev.
Alfonso Rom�n, of Puerto Rico's Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos (Human Rights 
Committee), whose letter writing campaign aims to convince Oxford and Bureau 
of Prisons officials to allow the family visit.

Joining the campaign will be many of Rev. Torres' friends and colleagues
from the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto Mart�nez,
Evangelical Council of Puerto Rico; Rev. Luis Rosario, Conference 
MinisterUnited Evangelical Church of Puerto Rico, Rev. Miguel Vilar and Rev.

Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 00907, 787/725-6284

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3140
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-15 14:36:31
Subject:Support Venceremos Brigade
Message:

This July, the 34th contingent of the Venceremos Brigade will spend two
weeks in Cuba. As part of a �Travel Challenge,� organized with IFCO/Pastors 
for Peace, Brigadistas will challenge the u.s. blockade on Cuba. We hope 
that your organization will play a role in this year�s contingent, either by 
sending representatives on the trip and/or supporting our efforts in other 
ways.

On SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8TH FROM 3:00PM-5:00PM, we will be holding an
informational meeting for all those interested in finding out more. The
meeting will be held at 10 Park Terrace East, #1L (A train to 207th St, 1 
train to 215th St).

For more information and to confirm your organization�s attendance, please 
email vbrigade@... or call 212-560-4360. Individuals with no 
organizational affiliation are also encouraged to attend.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
The Venceremos Brigade is an anti-imperialist educational project that,
since 1969, has sent over 8,000 people to Cuba. A national organization, the 
Brigade brings people together from all over the U.S. for an unforgettable, 
life changing experience. During trips, brigadistas participate in 
agricultural and/or construction work while also learning about Cuba�s 
revolution, history, and culture.

This year, the Venceremos Brigade has launched a special campaign. Along 
with IFCO/Pastors for Peace, we are calling upon people across the country 
to join a mass �Travel Challenge.� Around 75% of the U.S. population, 
including a majority of Cuban Americans, want an end to the travel ban. Over 
the past two years, both houses of Congress have voted not to enforce the 
travel restrictions. Yet, since Bush became president, harassment of 
travelers to Cuba, both licensed and unlicensed, has greatly increased. In 
this climate, it is clear that the Cuba solidarity movement must take a 
stand.

The Venceremos Brigade has always traveled unlicensed in order to make a 
statement against the U.S. blockade on Cuba, an inhumane policy that attacks 
both the island�s sovereignty and its 11 million people. This July, however, 
brigadistas will make our most open challenge to the U.S. travel 
restrictions. In order for the �Travel Challenge� to work, a lot of folks 
will have to participate.

The �Travel Challenge� is not the only reason to (re)join the Venceremos 
Brigade now. The 34th contingent will participate in Cuba�s national 
celebrations for a special July 26th--this year marks the 50th anniversary 
of the attack on the Moncada Garrison. The trip will have a special 
concentration on Cuba�s elders, as we hope to participate in the renovation 
of la Habana�s �Casas de Ancianos,� and to collect oral histories from some 
of the island�s elder generation. The program will also include events 
centered around Cuban hip hop, democracy, health care, education, among 
other topics.










_________________________________________________________________
MSN 8: advanced junk mail protection and 2 months FREE*. 
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail

Post Date/Time:2003-01-15 14:35:25
Subject:Support Venceremos Brigade
Message:

This July, the 34th contingent of the Venceremos Brigade will spend two
weeks in Cuba. As part of a �Travel Challenge,� organized with IFCO/Pastors 
for Peace, Brigadistas will challenge the u.s. blockade on Cuba. We hope 
that your organization will play a role in this year�s contingent, either by 
sending representatives on the trip and/or supporting our efforts in other 
ways.

On SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8TH FROM 3:00PM-5:00PM, we will be holding an
informational meeting for all those interested in finding out more. The
meeting will be held at 10 Park Terrace East, #1L (A train to 207th St, 1 
train to 215th St).

For more information and to confirm your organization�s attendance, please 
email vbrigade@... or call 212-560-4360. Individuals with no 
organizational affiliation are also encouraged to attend.

since 1969, has sent over 8,000 people to Cuba. A national organization, the 
Brigade brings people together from all over the U.S. for an unforgettable, 
life changing experience. During trips, brigadistas participate in 
agricultural and/or construction work while also learning about Cuba�s 
revolution, history, and culture.

This year, the Venceremos Brigade has launched a special campaign. Along 
with IFCO/Pastors for Peace, we are calling upon people across the country 
to join a mass �Travel Challenge.� Around 75% of the U.S. population, 
including a majority of Cuban Americans, want an end to the travel ban. Over 
the past two years, both houses of Congress have voted not to enforce the 
travel restrictions. Yet, since Bush became president, harassment of

this climate, it is clear that the Cuba solidarity movement must take a

will have to participate.

The �Travel Challenge� is not the only reason to (re)join the Venceremos 
Brigade now. The 34th contingent will participate in Cuba�s national 
celebrations for a special July 26th--this year marks the 50th anniversary 
of the attack on the Moncada Garrison. The trip will have a special 
concentration on Cuba�s elders, as we hope to participate in the renovation 
of la Habana�s �Casas de Ancianos,� and to collect oral histories from some 
of the island�s elder generation. The program will also include events 
centered around Cuban hip hop, democracy, health care, education, among 
other topics.

Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is urging people to write to the NEW 
VIEQUES POLITICAL PRISONERS!!  These three brothers were a aprt of a Civil 
Diobedience Brigade called the Pablo Soto Brigade of the MST (The Socialist 
Workers Movement in Puerto Rico that penetrated the restricted Bombing range 
and caused the US Navy to end their practices a couple of hours earlier than 
scheduled.

They were denied bail by their judge (a pro-Navy advocate)and are in jail 
until their trial.  please wite to these brothers and show them your 
support.


JOSE JAVIER STERLING-RIOS

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3144
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-18 17:21:55
Subject:People Of Color Cont.-Jan. 24th
Message:

All,

At the people of color emergency meeting on 1/13, groups met and decided to 
move ahead with a people of color mobilization on 2/15, the International 
Day of Action against the war. A large planning meeting is scheduled for 
Friday, 1/24.

On Monday, 1/20 there will be a pre-planning meeting for those who want to 
put some work into setting up for 1/24. Both meetings will take place at 
CSS, 105 East 22nd Street at 7pm. The 1/20 meeting is on the 4th Floor. The 
1/24 meeting is on the 9th floor.

peace, eric
___________________________________________
February 15, 2003 is the “International Day for Action.” On this day, 
millions around the world will participate in mass protests to demand peace 
and justice. In particular, the people of the world will call for an end to 
the escalating war against Iraq. Because the Bush administration in 
hell-bent on driving the world into state of war, it is vital that 
communities in the US come out strong on this day. New York City is being 
looked to as a site for US-based action on February 15.

An international action in a people-of-color city demands that communities 
of color play a central leadership role on February 15. We have the 
opportunity to show the world that people of color in the United States do 
not support the war.

This is a call for people of color communities to mobilize New York City for 
peace and justice on February 15. Meetings are now being set for planning 
the NYC action. We call on people of color community groups representing 
multiple sectors-- youth, labor, housing, environmental justice, gender and 
sexual rights, international solidarity, political prisoners and the prison 
industrial complex, immigrant rights, racial justice, and the religious 
community (to name
but a few) – to roll out on JANUARY 24 for a large planning meeting where 
we will discuss February 15 activities.

WHAT: People of Color Planning Meeting for February 15
WHEN: Friday, January 24, 2003, 7pm.
WHERE: Community Service Society, 105 East 22nd Street (on the corner of 
Park Ave), 9th Floor.

This initial call-out is initiated by the New York City members of Racial 
Justice 9-11. RJ-911 is a national network of people of color/racial justice 
organizations opposed to the US war program.

For More information contact:
Eric Tang (718) 473-6485 x 15, etang@...
or Hany Khalil (718) 439-5662, hanykhalil@...

Why Stopping the War on Iraq is Critical:

Stopping Bush's war on Iraq is important for many reasons--to stop Bush from 
murdering innocent people of color, to defeat the dangerous policy of  
"pre-emptive" wars, to make it harder for Israel to follow through on its 
threats to ethnically cleanse Palestine of its indigenous people, etc.. For 
our movement, it's also important because if we can impose a defeat on Bush 
on this front, it will help us defeat Bush on all fronts in the "War on 
Terrorism." With Bush politically weakened, it will be far easier to end The 
detentions and deportations, to roll back the PATRIOT Act, to shift money 
away from the military and into public services, to make it much harder for 
Bush to unilaterally overthrow other governments across the Third World.






_________________________________________________________________
MSN 8: advanced junk mail protection and 2 months FREE*. 
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers,
670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907

PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others 
canclaim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In 
1999,after serving 16 years, Alejandrina was released when President 
Clintoncommuted the sentences of eleven of Puerto Rico's political 
prisoners,finding their sentences ranging from 35 to 90 years were 
disproportionatelylengthy. Inexplicably, Mr. Clinton left behind Carlos 
Alberto, whose disproportionate 70 year sentence will keep him imprisoned 
until the year 2024.

Upon her release she applied to visit her stepson Carlos Alberto at 
FCIOxford, Wisconsin, to reunite with him and to take Rev. Torres to see 
their son together. While parole authorities supported this family reunion, 
Oxford prison authorities denied the request, in spite of Carlos Alberto's 
exemplary conduct; in spite of the fact that Alejandrina, like all eleven of 
those whose sentences were commuted, had successfully reintegrated into 
civil society; and in spite of their having permitted other former prisoners 
to visit their imprisoned family members.Now, three years later, Alejandrina 
continues to work as a mentor in analternative high school, to participate 
in her church and community, and to fully comply with the conditions of her 
parole. And now, three years later, Reverend Torres, with cancer raging 
through his 80 year old body, has again been denied this family reunion, the 
prison having once again turned down their modest request to be permitted to 
share together in the confines of the prison visiting room under the 
watchful eye of prison officials. "It would mean so much to Papi," daughter 
Dr. Catalina Torres stated, "to be able to see Mami and Berti (Carlos 
Alberto) together before he dies.""Christmas is such an important moment for 
Puerto Rican families to betogether, and this may well be Rev. Torres' last 
Christmas," said Rev.Alfonso Rom�n, of Puerto Rico's Comit� Pro Derechos 
Humanos (Human Rights Committee), whose letter writing campaign aims to 
convince Oxford and Bureau of Prisons officials to allow the family 
visit.Joining the campaign will be many of Rev. Torres' friends and 
colleaguesfrom the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto 
Mart�nez,Evangelical Council of Puerto Rico; Rev. Luis Rosario, Conference 
MinisterUnited Evangelical Church of Puerto Rico, Rev. Miguel Vilar and Rev. 
Cheo Vilar of the Episcopal Church of Puerto Rico; Rev. Nozomi Ikuta of the 
Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience Project. in Cleveland, OH; and Father 
Angel Dar�o Carrero of the Jesuits of Puerto Rico. On Sunday, December 22, 
churches throughout Puerto Rico and the United States devoted their services 
to the Torres family, praying for their reunion.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:Rev. Alfonso Rom�n, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, 
Condominio CaribbeanTowers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 
00907, 787/725-6284

U.S. jails, to be visited by his father, Rev. Jose Torres and his mother 
Alexandrina Torres, a former Puerto Rican political prisoner released on 
Sept. 11th, 1999.

Contacts for Bureau of Prisons:
Warden,FCI Oxford,
Box 1000,Oxford,
WI 53952,telephone 608/584-5511, fax608/584-6325;

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer,Director,
Federal Bureau of Prisons,
320 First StreetNW,
Washington, D.C. 20534,telephone 202/514-8534, fax 202/514-6878

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers,
670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907

PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others 
canclaim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In 
1999,after serving 16 years, Alejandrina was released when President 
Clintoncommuted the sentences of eleven of Puerto Rico's political 
prisoners,finding their sentences ranging from 35 to 90 years were 
disproportionatelylengthy. Inexplicably, Mr. Clinton left behind Carlos 
Alberto, whose disproportionate 70 year sentence will keep him imprisoned 
until the year 2024.

Upon her release she applied to visit her stepson Carlos Alberto at 
FCIOxford, Wisconsin, to reunite with him and to take Rev. Torres to see 
their son together. While parole authorities supported this family reunion, 
Oxford prison authorities denied the request, in spite of Carlos Alberto's 
exemplary conduct; in spite of the fact that Alejandrina, like all eleven of 
those whose sentences were commuted, had successfully reintegrated into 
civil society; and in spite of their having permitted other former prisoners 
to visit their imprisoned family members.Now, three years later, Alejandrina 
continues to work as a mentor in analternative high school, to participate 
in her church and community, and to fully comply with the conditions of her 
parole. And now, three years later, Reverend Torres, with cancer raging 
through his 80 year old body, has again been denied this family reunion, the 
prison having once again turned down their modest request to be permitted to 
share together in the confines of the prison visiting room under the 
watchful eye of prison officials. "It would mean so much to Papi," daughter 
Dr. Catalina Torres stated, "to be able to see Mami and Berti (Carlos 
Alberto) together before he dies.""Christmas is such an important moment for 
Puerto Rican families to betogether, and this may well be Rev. Torres' last 
Christmas," said Rev.Alfonso Rom�n, of Puerto Rico's Comit� Pro Derechos 
Humanos (Human Rights Committee), whose letter writing campaign aims to 
convince Oxford and Bureau of Prisons officials to allow the family 
visit.Joining the campaign will be many of Rev. Torres' friends and 
colleaguesfrom the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto 
Mart�nez,Evangelical Council of Puerto Rico; Rev. Luis Rosario, Conference 
MinisterUnited Evangelical Church of Puerto Rico, Rev. Miguel Vilar and Rev. 
Cheo Vilar of the Episcopal Church of Puerto Rico; Rev. Nozomi Ikuta of the 
Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience Project. in Cleveland, OH; and Father 
Angel Dar�o Carrero of the Jesuits of Puerto Rico. On Sunday, December 22, 
churches throughout Puerto Rico and the United States devoted their services 
to the Torres family, praying for their reunion.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:Rev. Alfonso Rom�n, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, 
Condominio CaribbeanTowers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 
00907, 787/725-6284

http://join.msn.com/?page=dept/dialup

Post ID:3148
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 10:58:12
Subject:Rutgers University Day of Action for Divestment - January 28, 2003
Message:

On January 28, 2003, the Rutgers University Campaign for Divestment from
Israeli Apartheid will officially launch its campaign with a series of
events, activities and actions.

We call upon Rutgers University to cease investing in corporations that do
business with the apartheid state of Israel and to begin investing with an
eye toward social justice and institutional progressive values! In
addition, we call upon the State of New Jersey to cease its institutional
support for the government of the state of Israel and the apartheid-based
economy of Israel through its official support of the New Jersey-Israel
Commission. If you believe in justice and equality, and that the power of
the purse should be used for justice rather than injustice, join us!


TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 2003 - NEW BRUNSWICK CAMPUS, RUTGERS UNIVERSITY

12:00 NOON - Rally and Die-In, Brower Commons.

We will rally for justice in Palestine and institutional divestment! Join
faculty, students, alumni and community members to call for justice! If
your organization wants to endorse or speak at the rally, please contact
Charlotte from New Jersey Solidarity at ckates@.... At the
close of the rally, we will symbolically DIE at Brower Commons to make
clear that money to Israel is not merely a matter of dollars, but a matter
of lives! Use your body to fight injustice - join us!

1:00 PM  - Press Conference, Brower Commons

Students, faculty, alumni and NJ residents will speak in support of
institutional divestment to the press, expressing their concerns and
unique reasons for supporting the divestment campaign and bringing this
national movement to Rutgers University. The campaign's divestment report
will be distributed, as will its other documentation. To participate,
please contact Cecilia of NJ Solidarity at cjoulain@....

--Divestment Petition will be distributed for signatures at ALL events!!--

7:00 PM - Adam Shapiro and Huwaida Arraf, Faculty Dining Room, Douglass
College Center

Huwaida Arraf and Adam Shapiro, co-founders of the International
Solidarity Movement, the international grassroots nonviolent resistance
movement in support of the Palestinian people, will speak at the Douglass
College Center as part of theDivestment Day of Action. Be there to welcome
Huwaida and Adam, internationally renowned for their commitment to
hands-on activism for human rights, to Rutgers!

COME OUT JANUARY 28, 2003! DIVEST FROM ISRAEL!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3149
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 11:05:47
Subject:SIGN the Rutgers University DIVESTMENT PETITION!
Message:

Are you a
*Rutgers University Student (undergrad, grad, all campuses)
*Rutgers University Faculty Member
*Rutgers University Staff Member
*Rutgers University Alumna or Alumnus
*New Jersey Resident
who wants to stand for justice in Palestine? If so, sign on to the Rutgers
University divestment petition! Our official website, with online
signatures, will launch for the DIVESTMENT DAY OF ACTION January 28! In
the meantime, we need your voices for justice.

Below is the petition. If you agree, please send your NAME, EMAIL ADDRESS,
STATUS (Student/Faculty/Staff/Alumni/NJ Resident), to
ckates@... or info@... and sign the petition!

Please forward this message to ANY who may be interested. Also, if you are
involved with a student organization, please consider endorsing as a
group!

Petition
We, the undersigned, are appalled by the human rights abuses against
Palestinians at the hands of the Israeli government, the continual
military occupation and colonization of Palestinian territory by Israeli
armed forces and settlers, and the forcible eviction from and demolition
of Palestinian homes, towns and cities.

As members of the Rutgers University community, we call for the university
to apply its human rights ideals where its dollars are invested. That is,
we urge the university to use its political and financial influence to
encourage the United States government to suspend its military aid and
arms sale to Israel. We also call upon Rutgers University to divest from
from Israel, from US companies that sell arms to Israel, and from US
companies engaged in business with Israel until the following conditions
are met:

*Israel is in compliance with United Nations Resolution 242, which notes
the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war, and which
calls for withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from occupied territories.


*Israel is in compliance with the United Nations Committee Against Torture
2001 Report, which recommends that Israel's use of legal torture be ended.


*In compliance with the Fourth Geneva Convention ("The occupying power
shall not deport or transfer parts of its own civilian population into
territories it occupies"; Article 49, Paragraph 6), Israel ceases building
new settlements, and vacates existing settlements, in the Occupied
Territories.


*Israel acknowledges the applicability of Untied Nations Resolution 194
with respect to the rights of refugees to return to their former lands
(also outlined in the Fourth Geneva Convention).


The undersigned,

________________________________________________________________________

PEDRO COLON ALMENAS IS OUT OF JAIL AND IN A HALF WAY HOUSE!!

By Ricardo Olivero Lora of Bandera Roja
Translated by Benjamin Ramos of ProLibertad

On Thursday January 23rd, 2003, After completing 11 months in MDC Guaynabo 
in Puerto Rico, Pedro Colon Almenas was transferred to a Half Way House to 
complete the rest of his  sentence.

Pedro, who was very animated and excited, was taken in a taxi from MDC 
Guaynabo to the Half Way House in Trujillo Alto.  Pedro was received by a 
support rally made up of youth and family outside of the prison, Pedro 
stated, "Thank you for the ROTC strike!!", a comment directed to the student 
strike against the ROTC at the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras.

The Half Way House program has less restrictions than a prison.  A person in 
the program can work or study outside the confines of the Half Way House 
from 6am-6pm and can be visited by friends and family on a regular basis.

Pedro will stay in the Half Way House until his sentence is completed on 
February 21st, 2003.  "Even though we are happy that we will soon be 
reunited with Pedro, we must denounce the fact that he will still be a 
victim of repression, because he will be under parole for three years", 
commented Hugo Delgado Marti, spokesperson of the Comite de Apoyo de Pedro.

In a press conference organized in the encampments close to the detention 
center, it was announced that Pedro would be received on February 25th at 
the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras.  This activity would be 
coordinated by the Consejo General de Estudiantes in conjunction with other 
student organizations.

The press conference was attended by Roberto Rabin, del Comit� Pro Rescate y 
Desarrollo de Vieques; Jorge Farinacci, of the  Frente Socialista; �ngel 
Santos, of La Hermandad de Empleados Exentos No Docentes de la UPR; 
Elizabeth Santiago, of El Taller de Formaci�n Pol�tica and Aurora Sambol�n, 
of La Uni�n de Juventudes Socialistas.
________________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters 
to support this action;  Please contact Kathleen Saywer of the Bureau of 
Prisons to allow Carlos Alberto Torres, A Puerto Rican Political Prisoner in 
U.S. jails, to be visited by his father, Rev. Jose Torres and his mother 
Alexandrina Torres, a former Puerto Rican political prisoner released on 
Sept. 11th, 1999.

Contacts for Bureau of Prisons:
Warden,FCI Oxford,
Box 1000,Oxford,
WI 53952,telephone 608/584-5511, fax608/584-6325;

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer,Director,
Federal Bureau of Prisons,
320 First StreetNW,
Washington, D.C. 20534,telephone 202/514-8534, fax 202/514-6878

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907

PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others 
canclaim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In 
1999,after serving 16 years, Alejandrina was released when President 
Clintoncommuted the sentences of eleven of Puerto Rico's political 
prisoners,finding their sentences ranging from 35 to 90 years were 
disproportionatelylengthy. Inexplicably, Mr. Clinton left behind Carlos 
Alberto, whose disproportionate 70 year sentence will keep him imprisoned 
until the year 2024.Upon her release she applied to visit her stepson Carlos 
Alberto at FCIOxford, Wisconsin, to reunite with him and to take Rev. Torres 
to see their son together. While parole authorities supported this family 
reunion, Oxford prison authorities denied the request, in spite of Carlos 
Alberto's exemplary conduct; in spite of the fact that Alejandrina, like all 
eleven of those whose sentences were commuted, had successfully reintegrated 
into civil society; and in spite of their having permitted other former 
prisoners to visit their imprisoned family members.Now, three years later, 
Alejandrina continues to work as a mentor in analternative high school, to 
participate in her church and community, and to fully comply with the 
conditions of her parole. And now, three years later, Reverend Torres, with 
cancer raging through his 80 year old body, has again been denied this 
family reunion, the prison having once again turned down their modest 
request to be permitted to share together in the confines of the prison 
visiting room under the watchful eye of prison officials. "It would mean so 
much to Papi," daughter Dr. Catalina Torres stated, "to be able to see Mami 
and Berti (Carlos Alberto) together before he dies.""Christmas is such an 
important moment for Puerto Rican families to betogether, and this may well 
be Rev. Torres' last Christmas," said Rev.Alfonso Rom�n, of Puerto Rico's 
Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos (Human Rights Committee), whose letter writing 
campaign aims to convince Oxford and Bureau of Prisons officials to allow 
the family visit.Joining the campaign will be many of Rev. Torres' friends 
and colleaguesfrom the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto 
Mart�nez,Evangelical Council of Puerto Rico; Rev. Luis Rosario, Conference 
MinisterUnited Evangelical Church of Puerto Rico, Rev. Miguel Vilar and Rev. 
Cheo Vilar of the Episcopal Church of Puerto Rico; Rev. Nozomi Ikuta of the 
Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience Project. in Cleveland, OH; and Father 
Angel Dar�o Carrero of the Jesuits of Puerto Rico. On Sunday, December 22, 
churches throughout Puerto Rico and the United States will devote their 
services to the Torres family, praying for their reunion.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:Rev. Alfonso Rom�n, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, 
Condominio CaribbeanTowers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 
00907, 787/725-6284

in Puerto Rico, Pedro Colon Almenas was transferred to a Half Way House to

Desarrollo de Vieques; Jorge Farinacci, of the  Frente Socialista; �ngel 
Santos, of La Hermandad de Empleados Exentos No Docentes de la UPR; 
Elizabeth Santiago, of El Taller de Formaci�n Pol�tica and Aurora Sambol�n, 
of La Uni�n de Juventudes Socialistas.

Post ID:3152
Sender:Charlotte Kates <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-27 15:49:59
Subject:All out for Justice in Palestine! Tues. Jan. 28, 2003 @ Rutgers!
Message:

On January 28, 2003, New Jersey Solidarity and the  Rutgers University
Campaign for Divestment from
Israeli Apartheid will officially launch their divestment campaign with a
series of
events, activities and actions.

We call upon Rutgers University to cease investing in corporations that do
business with the apartheid state of Israel and to begin investing with an
eye toward social justice and institutional progressive values! In
addition, we call upon the State of New Jersey to cease its institutional
support for the government of the state of Israel and the apartheid-based
economy of Israel through its official support of the New Jersey-Israel
Commission. If you believe in justice and equality, and that the power of
the purse should be used for justice rather than injustice, join us! To
sign our petition online, visit our website at
http://www.rutgersdivest.org - For more information, please visit our
website: http://www.njsolidarity.org/

TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 2003 - NEW BRUNSWICK CAMPUS, RUTGERS UNIVERSITY

12:00 NOON - Rally and Die-In, Brower Commons, College Avenue, New
Brunswick, NJ

We will rally for justice in Palestine and institutional divestment! Join
faculty, students, alumni and community members to call for justice! If
your organization wants to endorse or speak at the rally, please contact
Charlotte from New Jersey Solidarity at ckates @ eden.rutgers.edu. At the
close of the rally, we will symbolically DIE at Brower Commons to make
clear that money to Israel is not merely a matter of dollars, but a matter
of lives! Use your body to fight injustice - join us!

1:00 PM - Press Conference, Brower Commons, College Avenue, New Brunswick,
NJ

Students, faculty, alumni and NJ residents will speak in support of
institutional divestment to the press, expressing their concerns and
unique reasons for supporting the divestment campaign and bringing this
national movement to Rutgers University. The campaign's divestment report
will be distributed, as will its other documentation. To participate,
please contact Cecilia of NJ Solidarity at cjoulain @ eden.rutgers.edu.

--Divestment Petition will be distributed for signatures at ALL events!!--

7:00 PM - Adam Shapiro and Huwaida Arraf, Room 113, Livingston Student
Center, 84 Joyce Kilmer Avenue, Piscataway, NJ

Huwaida Arraf and Adam Shapiro, co-founders of the International
Solidarity Movement, the international grassroots nonviolent resistance
movement in support of the Palestinian people, will speak at the Douglass
College Center as part of theDivestment Day of Action. Be there to welcome
Huwaida and Adam, internationally renowned for their commitment to
hands-on activism for human rights, to Rutgers!

COME OUT JANUARY 28, 2003! DIVEST FROM ISRAEL!

**NOTE: The ADL has listed this protest on their calendar and our
opposition is planning a counter-rally! We need a presence for justice in
Palestine on January 28!

PEDRO COLON ALMENAS IS OUT OF JAIL AND IN A HALF WAY HOUSE!!

By Ricardo Olivero Lora of Bandera Roja
Translated by Benjamin Ramos of ProLibertad

On Thursday January 23rd, 2003, After completing 11 months in MDC Guaynabo 
in Puerto Rico, Pedro Colon Almenas was transferred to a Half Way House to 
complete the rest of his  sentence.

Pedro, who was very animated and excited, was taken in a taxi from MDC
Guaynabo to the Half Way House in Trujillo Alto.  Pedro was received by a 
support rally made up of youth and family outside of the prison, Pedro 
stated, "Thank you for the ROTC strike!!", a comment directed to the student 
strike against the ROTC at the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras.

The Half Way House program has less restrictions than a prison.  A person in 
the program can work or study outside the confines of the Half Way House 
from 6am-6pm and can be visited by friends and family on a regular basis.

Pedro will stay in the Half Way House until his sentence is completed on 
February 21st, 2003.  "Even though we are happy that we will soon be
reunited with Pedro, we must denounce the fact that he will still be a
victim of repression, because he will be under parole for three years",
commented Hugo Delgado Marti, spokesperson of the Comite de Apoyo de Pedro.

In a press conference organized in the encampments close to the detention 
center, it was announced that Pedro would be received on February 25th at 
the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras.  This activity would be 
coordinated by the Consejo General de Estudiantes in conjunction with other 
student organizations.

The press conference was attended by Roberto Rabin, del Comit� Pro Rescate y 
Desarrollo de Vieques; Jorge Farinacci, of the  Frente Socialista; �ngel 
Santos, of La Hermandad de Empleados Exentos No Docentes de la UPR; 
Elizabeth Santiago, of El Taller de Formaci�n Pol�tica and Aurora Sambol�n, 
of La Uni�n de Juventudes Socialistas.
________________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters 
to support this action;  Please contact Kathleen Saywer of the Bureau of 
Prisons to allow Carlos Alberto Torres, A Puerto Rican Political Prisoner in 
U.S. jails, to be visited by his father, Rev. Jose Torres and his mother 
Alexandrina Torres, a former Puerto Rican political prisoner released on 
Sept. 11th, 1999.

Contacts for Bureau of Prisons:
Warden,FCI Oxford,
Box 1000,Oxford,
WI 53952,telephone 608/584-5511, fax608/584-6325;

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer,Director,
Federal Bureau of Prisons,
320 First StreetNW,
Washington, D.C. 20534,telephone 202/514-8534, fax 202/514-6878

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907

PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others
canclaim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In 
1999,after serving 16 years, Alejandrina was released when President Clinton 
commuted the sentences of eleven of Puerto Rico's political 
prisoners,finding their sentences ranging from 35 to 90 years were 
disproportionatelylengthy. Inexplicably, Mr. Clinton left behind Carlos 
Alberto, whose disproportionate 70 year sentence will keep him imprisoned 
until the year 2024.Upon her release she applied to visit her stepson Carlos 
Alberto at FCIOxford, Wisconsin, to reunite with him and to take Rev. Torres 
to see their son together. While parole authorities supported this family 
reunion, Oxford prison authorities denied the request, in spite of Carlos 
Alberto's exemplary conduct; in spite of the fact that Alejandrina, like all 
eleven of those whose sentences were commuted, had successfully reintegrated 
into civil society; and in spite of their having permitted other former
prisoners to visit their imprisoned family members.Now, three years later, 
Alejandrina continues to work as a mentor in analternative high school, to 
participate in her church and community, and to fully comply with the 
conditions of her parole. And now, three years later, Reverend Torres, with 
cancer raging through his 80 year old body, has again been denied this 
family reunion, the prison having once again turned down their modest 
request to be permitted to share together in the confines of the prison 
visiting room under the watchful eye of prison officials. "It would mean so 
much to Papi," daughter Dr. Catalina Torres stated, "to be able to see Mami 
and Berti (Carlos Alberto) together before he dies.""Christmas is such an 
important moment for Puerto Rican families to betogether, and this may well 
be Rev. Torres' last Christmas," said Rev.Alfonso Rom�n, of Puerto Rico's 
Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos (Human Rights Committee), whose letter writing
campaign aims to convince Oxford and Bureau of Prisons officials to allow 
the family visit.Joining the campaign will be many of Rev. Torres' friends 
and colleaguesfrom the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto 
Mart�nez,Evangelical Council of Puerto Rico; Rev. Luis Rosario, Conference 
MinisterUnited Evangelical Church of Puerto Rico, Rev. Miguel Vilar and Rev. 
Cheo Vilar of the Episcopal Church of Puerto Rico; Rev. Nozomi Ikuta of the 
Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience Project. in Cleveland, OH; and Father 
Angel Dar�o Carrero of the Jesuits of Puerto Rico. On Sunday, December 22, 
churches throughout Puerto Rico and the United States will devote their 
services to the Torres family, praying for their reunion.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:Rev. Alfonso Rom�n, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, 
Condominio CaribbeanTowers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 
00907, 787/725-6284






_________________________________________________________________

http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

to write to the following Vieques Political Prisoners.

Mart�n Castro
C�sar Pacheco Rodr�guez

Please make sure to write their full name and prison number in order for the 
prisoner to receive your correspondence.

MDC Guaynabo
PO Box 2147
San Juan, Puerto Rico
00922-2147
________________________________________________________________________

PEDRO COLON ALMENAS IS OUT OF JAIL AND IN A HALF WAY HOUSE!!

By Ricardo Olivero Lora of Bandera Roja
Translated by Benjamin Ramos of ProLibertad

On Thursday January 23rd, 2003, After completing 11 months in MDC Guaynabo 
in Puerto Rico, Pedro Colon Almenas was transferred to a Half Way House to 
complete the rest of his  sentence.

Pedro, who was very animated and excited, was taken in a taxi from MDC
Guaynabo to the Half Way House in Trujillo Alto.  Pedro was received by a 
support rally made up of youth and family outside of the prison, Pedro 
stated, "Thank you for the ROTC strike!!", a comment directed to the student 
strike against the ROTC at the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras.

The Half Way House program has less restrictions than a prison.  A person in 
the program can work or study outside the confines of the Half Way House 
from 6am-6pm and can be visited by friends and family on a regular basis.

Pedro will stay in the Half Way House until his sentence is completed on 
February 21st, 2003.  "Even though we are happy that we will soon be
reunited with Pedro, we must denounce the fact that he will still be a
victim of repression, because he will be under parole for three years",
commented Hugo Delgado Marti, spokesperson of the Comite de Apoyo de Pedro.

In a press conference organized in the encampments close to the detention 
center, it was announced that Pedro would be received on February 25th at 
the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras.  This activity would be 
coordinated by the Consejo General de Estudiantes in conjunction with other 
student organizations.

The press conference was attended by Roberto Rabin, del Comit� Pro Rescate y 
Desarrollo de Vieques; Jorge Farinacci, of the  Frente Socialista; �ngel 
Santos, of La Hermandad de Empleados Exentos No Docentes de la UPR; 
Elizabeth Santiago, of El Taller de Formaci�n Pol�tica and Aurora Sambol�n, 
of La Uni�n de Juventudes Socialistas.
________________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters 
to support this action;  Please contact Kathleen Saywer of the Bureau of 
Prisons to allow Carlos Alberto Torres, A Puerto Rican Political Prisoner in 
U.S. jails, to be visited by his father, Rev. Jose Torres and his mother 
Alexandrina Torres, a former Puerto Rican political prisoner released on 
Sept. 11th, 1999.

Contacts for Bureau of Prisons:
Warden,FCI Oxford,
Box 1000,Oxford,
WI 53952,telephone 608/584-5511, fax608/584-6325;

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer,Director,
Federal Bureau of Prisons,
320 First StreetNW,
Washington, D.C. 20534,telephone 202/514-8534, fax 202/514-6878

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907

PRESS RELEASE

Reverend Jos� Alberto Torres of Chicago has a distinction few others
canclaim: his wife Alejandrina Torres, his son Carlos Alberto Torres, and 
his(now former) daughter-in-law Hayde� Beltr�n, all went to prison in 
theUnited States for seeking Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S. In 
1999,after serving 16 years, Alejandrina was released when President Clinton

and colleaguesfrom the religious community, including Rev. Heriberto

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3155
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-30 15:52:54
Subject:Visit with Yuri Kochiyama
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is happy to announce that our sister, 
friend, comrade and ever-present ally Yuri Kochiyama will be visiting New 
York City!!  ProLibertad is organizing a special People's Reception on 
Saturday February 8th, 2003 for Yuri!!

Join us for food, entertainment and wonderful conversation with Yuri!!

SATURDAY FEBRUARY 8TH, 2003 AT 7:30PM-10PM
ST. MARY'S CHURCH 521 W126TH ST.
BETWEEN AMSTERDAM AVENUE AND BROADWAY
TAKE THE 1 OR 9 TRAIN TO W125TH ST AND BROADWAY

________________________________________________________________________
YURI'S BIOGRAPHY AND A SPECIAL PEOPLE'S NOTE:

Yuri Kochiyama

Yuri Kochiyama is one of the most revered and beloved activists our movement 
has known.  She spans decades of activism and worlds of cultures and 
political movements.  Born in 1921 in San Pedro California, by the time she 
was 21, Yuri was interned in one of the concentration camps set up for 
Japanese-Americans during World War II.  She was  in Jerome, Arkansas.  She 
spent two years in that camp, from 1942 - 1944.  After that she went to 
Hattisburg, Mississippi, working for the USO specifically to help 
Japanese-American soldiers.   When the war ended Yuri was happy to reunite 
with Bill Kochiyama, her lifelong partner, who returned from fighting with 
the 442 Battalion, an all Japanese-American combat unit acclaimed as one of 
the most courageous infantry groups in US history.

After coming to New York, Yuri worked with Harlem Parents, and later with 
Malcolm in the Organization of Afro-American Unity.  She organized a welcome 
for Hiroshima and Nagasaki victims who came to this country, and Malcolm 
attended that welcome.  As has  been documented on film, Yuri was in the 
Audubon the day Malcolm was assassinated, and she ran up to the stage to 
help him and to make sure the children and Betty were safe.

During the Viet Nam War, Yuri participated in the Asian-American organized 
opposition to the war.  By the 70's,  with the intense attacks on the Black 
Panther Party, Yuri became involved in the National Committee for the 
Defense of Political Prisoners, thus beginning more than three decades of 
her legendary support for political prisoners.  Her Christmas letters to 
friends, to this day, detail the situation of every political prisoner she 
can track down, and her caring dedication to each of them is an inspiration 
to all those who do political prisoner support work.

Many a political prisoner, including those who've gotten out, has paid 
tribute to what Yuri's support meant to those who were incarcerated.  In 
addition to her work in the movement, Yuri taught conversational English at 
Riverside Church from 1983 to 1993, and later spent ten years volunteering 
at a soup kitchen and homeless shelter.  In 1993 Bill Kochiyama, Yuri's 
husband, died and was mourned by hundreds of people from family, to friends, 
to activists giving a small sense of who the Kochiyamas were, and how much 
they were treasured.

Yuri continues to be a much sought after lecturer at dozens of colleges and 
universities, including such places as Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Radcliffe, 
Oberlin, and the University of Hawaii.  She also spoke at many high schools 
and even some junior high schools and elementary schools.


Finally, Yuri participated in the 1987 Venceremos Brigade, and travelled to 
both Peru and the Phillipines in  support of political prisoners.

This is truly only a biographical SKETCH of Yuri's incredible life to this 
date.  She has been the recipient of dozens of awards, tributes, and honors.

But most of all, she is beloved by many hundreds of activists and people -- 
from those who've worked with  her and know her well to those who've simply 
crossed paths with her and were inspired by her modest, charming, and 
powerful presence.
________________________________________________________________________

A NOTE FROM YURI

January 30, 2003

I am 81 going on 82.  Born in San Pedro, Calif 1921.  World War II -1942 - 
spent Concentration Camp in Jerome, Arkansas.  1946 - came to New York,  
married Bill Kochiyama , member of the 442nd All Japanese American Infantry. 
Bill grew up right here where the St. Mary's Church stands.  But then it was 
called Sheltering Arms, an orphanage.  In 1960, we were lucky to get into 
the Manhattanville Project (right across the street).  Before that, we lived 
at Amsterdam Houses   So, you can see, I've come home.

Just want to thank all the people who came into my life while living in New 
York for 54 years; 40 years in Harlem.  It was the movement and the people 
in the movement, that I owe my life's purpose, meaningfulness and friendship 
to (Black/New African, Puerto Rican/Latinos, White/anti-imperialist, the few 
American Indians/Indigenous, Asian Americans, and mixed blood folks.

Thanx, too, to all the others - family friends, neighbors, project friends, 
my kids' friends. etc.  What a huge life you gave me!  Love and thanx for 
the many ways you blessed me.

Remembering
Gratefully always,
Yuri





_________________________________________________________________

http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

and even some junior high schools and elementary schools.


Finally, Yuri participated in the 1987 Venceremos Brigade, and travelled to 
both Peru and the Phillipines in  support of political prisoners.

This is truly only a biographical SKETCH of Yuri's incredible life to this 
date.  She has been the recipient of dozens of awards, tributes, and honors.

But most of all, she is beloved by many hundreds of activists and people -- 
from those who've worked with  her and know her well to those who've simply 
crossed paths with her and were inspired by her modest, charming, and 
powerful presence.
________________________________________________________________________

A NOTE FROM YURI

January 30, 2003

I am 81 going on 82.  Born in San Pedro, Calif 1921.  World War II -1942 - 
spent Concentration Camp in Jerome, Arkansas.  1946 - came to New York,  
married Bill Kochiyama , member of the 442nd All Japanese American Infantry. 
Bill grew up right here where the St. Mary's Church stands.  But then it was 
called Sheltering Arms, an orphanage.  In 1960, we were lucky to get into 
the Manhattanville Project (right across the street).  Before that, we lived 
at Amsterdam Houses   So, you can see, I've come home.

Just want to thank all the people who came into my life while living in New 
York for 54 years; 40 years in Harlem.  It was the movement and the people 
in the movement, that I owe my life's purpose, meaningfulness and friendship 
to (Black/New African, Puerto Rican/Latinos, White/anti-imperialist, the few 
American Indians/Indigenous, Asian Americans, and mixed blood folks.

Thanx, too, to all the others - family friends, neighbors, project friends, 
my kids' friends. etc.  What a huge life you gave me!  Love and thanx for 
the many ways you blessed me.

Remembering
Gratefully always,
Yuri

York City!!  All three groups are organizing a special People's Reception on 
Saturday February 8th, 2003 for Yuri!!

Yuri Kochiyama

A NOTE FROM YURI

January 30, 2003

I am 81 going on 82.  Born in San Pedro, Calif 1921.  World War II -1942 - 
spent Concentration Camp in Jerome, Arkansas.  1946 - came to New York,  
married Bill Kochiyama , member of the 442nd All Japanese American Infantry. 
Bill grew up right here where the St. Mary's Church stands.  But then it was 
called Sheltering Arms, an orphanage.  In 1960, we were lucky to get into 
the Manhattanville Project (right across the street).  Before that, we lived 
at Amsterdam Houses   So, you can see, I've come home.

Just want to thank all the people who came into my life while living in New 
York for 54 years; 40 years in Harlem.  It was the movement and the people 
in the movement, that I owe my life's purpose, meaningfulness and friendship 
to (Black/New African, Puerto Rican/Latinos, White/anti-imperialist, the few 
American Indians/Indigenous, Asian Americans, and mixed blood folks.

Thanx, too, to all the others - family friends, neighbors, project friends, 
my kids' friends. etc.  What a huge life you gave me!  Love and thanx for 
the many ways you blessed me.
