25 June, 2003  Press Release

FBI arrest Vieques leader, Nilda Medina

Shortly before 5AM today, five agents of the FBI entered the home of Nilda 
Medina and Robert Rabin, members of the Committee for the Rescue and 
Development of Vieques (CRDV) with a warrant to arrest Medina, acusing her 
of violation of Title 18 of the Federal Code for "damage to property''.  
Teodoro Lebron was the agent in charge of the operation that included 
members of the Puerto Rican police.  The arrest order was signed by 
Magistrate Aida Delgado and Special Agent of the FBI, Carlos Rodr�guez.

Members of the CRDV and the Vieques community denounced the arresta as an 
abuse against a woman who has been a example of this struggle for peace and 
made great efforts over the past four years to maintain the non violent 
nature of the struggle that gained the respect of people throughout the 
world.

This arrest comes just four days after FBI agents entered the facilities of 
the CRDV in the Peace and Justice Camp, with a search warrant to find "maps, 
photos, phone and address lists or other materials as evidence of the 
commission of a crime."

Nilda Medina is recognized as one of the principal leaders of the Vieques 
struggle during more than two decades and is a founding member of the CRDV.  
During actions of civil disobedience, Medina was arrested on May 4th, 2000 
and again in June of that year when she participated in the first brigade to 
return to the bombing zone after the "removal'' of the Civil Disobedience 
Camps from the military area.

Spokespersons for the CRDV also denounce the arrest of others in Vieques and 
in the main island that could take place today and emphasized that the group 
continues its plan to hold a Peopl's Assembly this Thursday at 7PM in the 
Count Mirasol Fort on Vieques to discuss strategies for this new phase of 
the struggle for decontamination, return of the lands to the people and 
sustainable development.

>25 June, 2003  Press Release
>
>FBI arrest Vieques leader, Nilda Medina
>
>Shortly before 5AM today, five agents of the FBI entered the home of Nilda
>Medina and Robert Rabin, members of the Committee for the Rescue and
>Development of Vieques (CRDV) with a warrant to arrest Medina, acusing her
>of violation of Title 18 of the Federal Code for "damage to property''.
>Teodoro Lebron was the agent in charge of the operation that included
>members of the Puerto Rican police.  The arrest order was signed by
>Magistrate Aida Delgado and Special Agent of the FBI, Carlos Rodr�guez.
>
>Members of the CRDV and the Vieques community denounced the arresta as an
>abuse against a woman who has been a example of this struggle for peace and
>made great efforts over the past four years to maintain the non violent
>nature of the struggle that gained the respect of people throughout the
>world.
>
>This arrest comes just four days after FBI agents entered the facilities of
>the CRDV in the Peace and Justice Camp, with a search warrant to find 
>"maps,
>photos, phone and address lists or other materials as evidence of the
>commission of a crime."
>
>Nilda Medina is recognized as one of the principal leaders of the Vieques
>struggle during more than two decades and is a founding member of the CRDV.
>During actions of civil disobedience, Medina was arrested on May 4th, 2000
>and again in June of that year when she participated in the first brigade 
>to
>return to the bombing zone after the "removal'' of the Civil Disobedience
>Camps from the military area.
>
>Spokespersons for the CRDV also denounce the arrest of others in Vieques 
>and
>in the main island that could take place today and emphasized that the 
>group
>continues its plan to hold a Peopl's Assembly this Thursday at 7PM in the
>Count Mirasol Fort on Vieques to discuss strategies for this new phase of
>the struggle for decontamination, return of the lands to the people and
>sustainable development.

EMERGENCY PROTEST FOR VIEQUES!
Monday, June 30th 4:30 P.M.
26 Federal Plaza
(lower Manhattan)
New York City

Although a small victory was achieved, the struggle for Vieques is far
from over. So long as a single U.S. military personnel is in Puerto
Rico, the oppressive yoke of U.S. colonialism will make its presence
felt.

And now, those who are responsible for the cancer and destruction that
took place for more than six decades, want to implement a policy of
reprisals on the people of Vieques. The FBI have arrested people who
have been active in the noble struggle to get the U.S. Navy to stop
its bombing destruction and withdraw from the island.

It was in Vieques where all U.S. wars since World War II, including
the invasion and conquest of Afganistan and Iraq, have been rehearsed.

Of the people of Vieques who were arrested, some have been charged
with conspiracy to destroy governemnt property, a potentially serious
charge. We have to make it clear - the real destructive criminal is
U.S. colonialism in Puerto Rico. From the U.S. Navy, the FBI to U.S.
officials in Washington, they are all responsible for the
destructiveness in Vieques and all of Puerto Rico.

Please join us in an emergency picket Monday, June 30th, 4:30 P.M., at
26 Federal Plaza to support of the people of Vieques, Puerto Rico. DO
NOT let Vieques become the scene of FBI reprisals.

Transportation information: Take the IRT subway trains 6, 4, 5 to
Brooklyn Bridge or the IND subway trains "R" or "N" to City Hall.

_________________________________________________________________

http://join.msn.com/?page=features/featuredemail

Friends in Solidarity with the Cause of Peace in Vieques:

We ask your support in the face of a campaign of repression by the FBI and 
the federal "justice'' system against our people in struggle.� Twelve people 
accused of conspiracy and destruction of federal property during the 
activities of last May First face possible sentences of 5 to 20 years in 
prison.

We include with this note a model letter to send by fax to the Puerto Rican 
congress people and the Puerto Rico Resident Commissioner in Washington, 
Anibal Acevedo Vil�, whose phone and fax numbers are listed below.

We also would appreciate any economic help for the Committee of Families of 
Arrested - May First.� Donations may be deposited in the Banco Popular 
account # 512 076 726 or checks sent in the name of the group to:� P.O. Box 
1424 Vieques, PR� 00765.

With this petition, we begin a campaign to support the accused in this 
case.� Thanks greatly for your consistent solidarity.

CRDV
__________________________________________________________________________________

THE WELFARE POETS
13 years of Poetry, Activism, Conscious Hip-Hop, Bomba & Plena Appearing
at the Landmark "NuyoRicans Poets Cafe"

"The Welfare Poets are sharpening the intensity of our people's minds."
--ANGELA DAVIS, Activist & former Black Panther

WHO/WHAT: THE WELFARE POETS, independent artists performing music of
resistance since 1990
will perform their unique brand of conscious music, a distinct blend of
politics, music, and poetry incorporating
the historical and the political with rhythms from various genres such
as: Hip Hop, Funk, Salsa, Blues, and
Latin Jazz.

The Welfare Poets will be performing songs from their 2000 debut album,
PROJECT BLUES, and the
forthcoming album RHYMES FOR TREASON, and commenting on the welfare of
people in ghettos around the
world.

WHEN/WHERE: July 5, 2003 9 PM
NuyoRican Poets Cafe
236 East 3rd Street (Between Aves B & C)
New York, NY 10009
Hotline: 212-505-8183
www.welfarepoets.com
__________________________________________________________________________________

"When you buff history you get violence."
- Lee (LEE) Qui�ones

RICANSTRUCTION comes up from
beneath the underground and makes
a return audio visual assault on NYC!

CELEBRATE YOUR DEFIANCE!
CELEBRATE YOUR RESISTANCE!
CELEBRATE YOUR INDEPENDENCE!

ALL AGES SHOW - $5 Donation

SATURDAY the 5th of JULY

@ ST. MARKS CHURCH
(10th Street @ 2nd Avenue)

7PM -12AM
Doors Open @ 6:30PM
with

Penny Arcade

Tuli Kupferberg

Chris Rael (Church of Betty)

Reverend Vince Anderson

Bina Sharif

Maya Dorn

Frank Morales

Theresa Byrnes

Harry Listig

Sanaz

Special Guests: Bill Weinberg (WW3 Report, WBAI), Paul Garrin
(ReclaimThe.net), Chris Flash (The Shadow), Armand Ruhlman
& the Earth People.

The show will benefit the Bluestockings Independent Bookstore
on 172 Allen Street in NYC.

The show is sponsored by the SHADOW.

www.ricanstruction.net
__________________________________________________________________________________

RESISTANCE IN BROOKLYN'S ANNUAL ANTI-JULY 4TH BENEFIT PARTY

SUNDAY, JULY 6, 2003, 2 to 7pm

309 Park Place, Brooklyn, New York
(between Vanderbilt and Underhill)
Suggested donation: $10 (includes dinner;
cash (beer) bar)

All proceeds from this event will go to two groups.
Desis Rising Up and Moving (DRUM) is a community-based
social justice organization of working-class and poor
South Asian immigrants in New York City founded in
1999.  More info is at <www.drumnation.org>. Operation
Homeland Resistance was a people-of-color-led and
-organized coalition of organizations that came
together to participate in a major civil disobedience
to protest the war abroad and the war at home. More
info is at <www.homelandresistance.org>.

Directions:  1,2,4 trains to Grand Army Plaza, walk
down Flatbush to Park Place and make a right (1 1/2
blocks), or Q Train to 7th Avenue, cross Flatbush and
walk along Park Place until you get to #309.
Sponsored by Resistance in Brooklyn
718-399-8366, mmmsrnb@...

RESISTANCE IN BROOKLYN  is an anti-racist, anti-imperialist, anti-sexist
affinity group.


-- The politicians ain't the solution - the people are.
Let us organize. ---mumia abu jamal

__________________________________________________________________________________

The New York Solidarity Movement for a Free Palestine and the Brecht Forum
Present:

The Road Map to Truth Tour: Reports from Palestinian Activists

July 12
7:30pm
Brecht Forum
122 W27th. St.,10th Floor
NY, NY 10001
brechtforum.org
212.242.4201

About NYSMFP:

NYSMFP is a predominantly people of color organized
membership of activists from varied communities in New
York City with a history of mobilizing around domestic
and international struggles for economic and racial
justice.  We believe our struggles for
self-determination and resistance to imperialism are
linked to and aided by the Palestinian fight against
occupation.  We are looking forward to having Maha
Nassar and Ala Al Azzeh here speaking with our
communities first hand about the Palestinians
struggle.

About Maha Nassar:

Maha Nassar is the elected chair person of U.P.W.C.,
Union of Palestinian Womens Committees she is also
Chair Person of the Board of Trustees of the
Alternative Information Centre (co project between
Palestinian and Israeli Progressives who look for a
secular democratic State in Palestine).  She has been
a secondary school Physics teacher for 26 years and a
member of Teachers Union for the 20 past years.  Maha
Nassar is an ex-prisoner, she was in Israeli Jails
during both the first and the second Intifadas.  She
was under house arrest for 6 months during the first
Intifada.

About the UPWC:

Union of Palestinian Womens Committees is a
grassroots or mass based women's
organization doing work in West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Their main goal is to raise the awareness of women about
their social, economic and political rights, and also
to encourage women to take a role in civil society
enforcing laws that forbid discrimination against
them.  Their programs also take into consideration the
critical situation of our people under the aggressive
attacks of Israeli occupation.  Not only on
has the occupation effected our people, but also on
the infrastructure to such a degree that it brought
more responsibilities and burdens on the shoulder of
non-governmental organizations like the UPWC.


About Ala Mahmoud Younis Al Azzeh:

Ala Al Azzeh is currently pursuing an MA in
International Studies from Birzeit University and
works as a math and science teacher at Al Ezzeriyeh
Boys School.  He has been active in the Palestinian
student movement through the course of his higher
education at Bethlehem, AlQuds, and Birzeit
Universities.

He is a founding member of the Handala Center, one of
the only youth activities center in Beit Jibrin
refugee camp. He also volunteers as an
editorial assistant, translator and consultant for an
alternative English language magazine dedicated to
providing alternative and critical information and
analysis on developments in Palestine from a
progressive perspective. (See www.between-lines.org

Sliding scale: $6, $8, $10
__________________________________________________________________________________

WEDNESDAY, JULY 9TH, 2003 AT 7:30PM
THE BRECHT FORUM 122 W27TH ST., 10TH FL
THE MALCOLM X GRASSROOTS MOVEMENT AND THE BRECHT FORUM INVITE YOU TO A BOOK 
PARTY/FORUM

We Are Our Own Liberators:  Selected Prison Writings of Jalil Muntaqim with 
Asha Bandele, Antoinette Bottom* & Others TBA

Join us to celebrate the long-awaited publication of prison writings by 
former Black Panther Party/Black Liberation Army member Jalil Muntaqim, one 
of the world's longest held political prisoners. Imprisoned since 1971, as a 
result of the American government's campaign to crush domestic opposition, 
this collection spans his 31 years of prison writings and outlines his major 
theoretical contributions to the Black Liberation and New-Afrikan 
Independence Movements. It includes "We Are Our Own Liberators," "Africans 
In The Diaspora," "On the Black Liberation Army," "A Case Against Domestic 
Neo-Colonialism," "For The Liberation of North America," "National Strategy 
for the Front for the Liberation of the New Afrikan Nation," "Handbook for 
Revolutionary Nationalist Cadres," "The National and International Struggle 
Toward a New Global Revolutionary Pan-Afrikan Strategy," and his 1975 
sentencing statement.

Asha Bandele is an editor at Essence magazine, published author of The 
Prisoners Wife: A Memoir and Absence in the Palm of my Hands. She is a 
member of Malcolm X Grassroots Movement. Antoinette Bottom (*invited) is the
daughter of Jalil Muntaqim, and is a mother. Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
__________________________________________________________________________________

FRIDAY, JULY 11TH, 2003 AT 6PM AND 8PM FILM FORUM  209 WEST HOUSTON ST. 
BETWEEN 6TH AVE. AND VARICK (7TH AVENUES)
Tickets are $9.  Proceeds benefit the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement, Black 
August and political prisoners.

If you haven't yet seen the Weather Underground movie, or if you've seen it 
and want to see it again, please go to the Film Forum showing on FRIDAY, 
JULY 11, at either 6:00 or 8:00 -- the proceeds from those showings will be 
donated to the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement for their work to support and 
win release of political prisoners (and especially for their annual hip-hop 
concert, Black August www.blackaugust.com.) The theater holds 150 people per 
show, and the more seats are filled, the more money we will raise for MXGM 
and their important work to free political prisoners. The film itself makes 
no mention of all the political prisoners from the Black Panther Party, 
Black Liberation Army and white anti-imperialist groups still inside after 
30 years. But the film-maker helped arrange these two benefit screenings.

Please circulate this message to all your friends and lists in New York, so 
that we can use the film to generate support for political prisoners and the 
struggle for Black liberation.

_________________________________________________________________
Help STOP SPAM with the new MSN 8 and get 2 months FREE*  
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail

Post ID:3274

Subject:ProLibertad Action Digest
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedomm Campaign is calling on all our allies and 
supporters to support the ProLibertad Freedom Picnic; this is our summer 
fund-raiser for our campaign work and to raise commissary money for the 
Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

ALSO, THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES HAVE MADE A CALL FOR SUPPORT FOR THE VIEQUES 
ARRESTEES, PLEASE SEND A DOANTION TO THE VIEQUES BAIL FUND BELOW!!

ALSO,  below the ProLibertad Picnic and Vieques Bail FUnd email, ProLibertad 
has provided folks a small calendar of activities around Political 
Prisoners, Political Art and Support Activities!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLIbertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
__________________________________________________________________________________

SATURDAY JULY 19TH, 2003 AT 9AM
COME TO THE PROLIBERTAD FREEDOM PICNIC
AT HIGHLAND POOLS IN RINGWOOD, NEW JERSEY

Bring your swimming trunks for the chemical free steam fed ponds!!  We will 
have food, FUN, music, dancing, games, sports and relaxation!! Help us raise 
money for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Commissary Fund!!

Meet at the corner of w179th St. and Broadway at 9am to catch one of our 
Freedom Vans to HighLand pools!! $20 for Transportation from NYC for adults 
and $15 for children, Entrance to HighLand Pools and Food.  Contact 
ProLibertad to reserve a seat on our Freedom Vans by calling 718-601-4751 or 
email ProLibertad@...
__________________________________________________________________________________

Friends in Solidarity with the Cause of Peace in Vieques:

We ask your support in the face of a campaign of repression by the FBI and 
the federal "justice'' system against our people in struggle.  Twelve people 
accused of conspiracy and destruction of federal property during the 
activities of last May First face possible sentences of 5 to 20 years in 
prison.

We include with this note a model letter to send by fax to the Puerto Rican 
congress people and the Puerto Rico Resident Commissioner in Washington, 
Anibal Acevedo Vil�, whose phone and fax numbers are listed below.

We also would appreciate any economic help for the Committee of Families of 
Arrested - May First.  Donations may be deposited in the Banco Popular 
account # 512 076 726 or checks sent in the name of the group to:  P.O. Box 
1424 Vieques, PR  00765.

With this petition, we begin a campaign to support the accused in this case. 
  Thanks greatly for your consistent solidarity.

CRDV
__________________________________________________________________________________

THE WELFARE POETS
13 years of Poetry, Activism, Conscious Hip-Hop, Bomba & Plena Appearing
at the Landmark "NuyoRicans Poets Cafe"

"The Welfare Poets are sharpening the intensity of our people's minds."
--ANGELA DAVIS, Activist & former Black Panther

WHO/WHAT: THE WELFARE POETS, independent artists performing music of
resistance since 1990
will perform their unique brand of conscious music, a distinct blend of
politics, music, and poetry incorporating
the historical and the political with rhythms from various genres such
as: Hip Hop, Funk, Salsa, Blues, and
Latin Jazz.

The Welfare Poets will be performing songs from their 2000 debut album,
PROJECT BLUES, and the
forthcoming album RHYMES FOR TREASON, and commenting on the welfare of
people in ghettos around the
world.

WHEN/WHERE: July 5, 2003 9 PM
NuyoRican Poets Cafe
236 East 3rd Street (Between Aves B & C)
New York, NY 10009
Hotline: 212-505-8183
www.welfarepoets.com

Desis Rising Up and Moving (DRUM) is a community-based
social justice organization of working-class and poor
South Asian immigrants in New York City founded in
1999.  More info is at <www.drumnation.org>. Operation
Homeland Resistance was a people-of-color-led and
-organized coalition of organizations that came
together to participate in a major civil disobedience
to protest the war abroad and the war at home. More
info is at <www.homelandresistance.org>.

The New York Solidarity Movement for a Free Palestine and the Brecht Forum
Present:

The Road Map to Truth Tour: Reports from Palestinian Activists

July 12
7:30pm
Brecht Forum
122 W27th. St.,10th Floor
NY, NY 10001
brechtforum.org
212.242.4201

About NYSMFP:

NYSMFP is a predominantly people of color organized
membership of activists from varied communities in New
York City with a history of mobilizing around domestic
and international struggles for economic and racial
justice.  We believe our struggles for
self-determination and resistance to imperialism are
linked to and aided by the Palestinian fight against
occupation.  We are looking forward to having Maha
Nassar and Ala Al Azzeh here speaking with our
communities first hand about the Palestinians
struggle.

About Maha Nassar:

Maha Nassar is the elected chair person of U.P.W.C.,
Union of Palestinian Womens Committees she is also
Chair Person of the Board of Trustees of the
Alternative Information Centre (co project between
Palestinian and Israeli Progressives who look for a
secular democratic State in Palestine).  She has been
a secondary school Physics teacher for 26 years and a
member of Teachers Union for the 20 past years.  Maha
Nassar is an ex-prisoner, she was in Israeli Jails
during both the first and the second Intifadas.  She
was under house arrest for 6 months during the first
Intifada.

About the UPWC:

Union of Palestinian Womens Committees is a
grassroots or mass based women's
organization doing work in West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Their main goal is to raise the awareness of women about
their social, economic and political rights, and also
to encourage women to take a role in civil society
enforcing laws that forbid discrimination against
them.  Their programs also take into consideration the
critical situation of our people under the aggressive
attacks of Israeli occupation.  Not only on
has the occupation effected our people, but also on
the infrastructure to such a degree that it brought
more responsibilities and burdens on the shoulder of
non-governmental organizations like the UPWC.


About Ala Mahmoud Younis Al Azzeh:

Ala Al Azzeh is currently pursuing an MA in
International Studies from Birzeit University and
works as a math and science teacher at Al Ezzeriyeh
Boys School.  He has been active in the Palestinian
student movement through the course of his higher
education at Bethlehem, AlQuds, and Birzeit
Universities.

He is a founding member of the Handala Center, one of
the only youth activities center in Beit Jibrin
refugee camp. He also volunteers as an
editorial assistant, translator and consultant for an
alternative English language magazine dedicated to
providing alternative and critical information and
analysis on developments in Palestine from a
progressive perspective. (See www.between-lines.org

Sliding scale: $6, $8, $10
__________________________________________________________________________________

WEDNESDAY, JULY 9TH, 2003 AT 7:30PM
THE BRECHT FORUM 122 W27TH ST., 10TH FL
THE MALCOLM X GRASSROOTS MOVEMENT AND THE BRECHT FORUM INVITE YOU TO A BOOK 
PARTY/FORUM

We Are Our Own Liberators:  Selected Prison Writings of Jalil Muntaqim with 
Asha Bandele, Antoinette Bottom* & Others TBA

Join us to celebrate the long-awaited publication of prison writings by 
former Black Panther Party/Black Liberation Army member Jalil Muntaqim, one 
of the world's longest held political prisoners. Imprisoned since 1971, as a 
result of the American government's campaign to crush domestic opposition, 
this collection spans his 31 years of prison writings and outlines his major 
theoretical contributions to the Black Liberation and New-Afrikan 
Independence Movements. It includes "We Are Our Own Liberators," "Africans 
In The Diaspora," "On the Black Liberation Army," "A Case Against Domestic 
Neo-Colonialism," "For The Liberation of North America," "National Strategy 
for the Front for the Liberation of the New Afrikan Nation," "Handbook for 
Revolutionary Nationalist Cadres," "The National and International Struggle 
Toward a New Global Revolutionary Pan-Afrikan Strategy," and his 1975 
sentencing statement.

Asha Bandele is an editor at Essence magazine, published author of The 
Prisoners Wife: A Memoir and Absence in the Palm of my Hands. She is a 
member of Malcolm X Grassroots Movement. Antoinette Bottom (*invited) is the
daughter of Jalil Muntaqim, and is a mother. Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
__________________________________________________________________________________

FRIDAY, JULY 11TH, 2003 AT 6PM AND 8PM FILM FORUM  209 WEST HOUSTON ST. 
BETWEEN 6TH AVE. AND VARICK (7TH AVENUES)
Tickets are $9.  Proceeds benefit the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement, Black 
August and political prisoners.

If you haven't yet seen the Weather Underground movie, or if you've seen it 
and want to see it again, please go to the Film Forum showing on FRIDAY, 
JULY 11, at either 6:00 or 8:00 -- the proceeds from those showings will be 
donated to the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement for their work to support and 
win release of political prisoners (and especially for their annual hip-hop 
concert, Black August www.blackaugust.com.) The theater holds 150 people per 
show, and the more seats are filled, the more money we will raise for MXGM 
and their important work to free political prisoners. The film itself makes 
no mention of all the political prisoners from the Black Panther Party, 
Black Liberation Army and white anti-imperialist groups still inside after 
30 years. But the film-maker helped arrange these two benefit screenings.

Please circulate this message to all your friends and lists in New York, so 
that we can use the film to generate support for political prisoners and the 
struggle for Black liberation.

Subject:ProLibertad Action Digest
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedomm Campaign is calling on all our allies and
supporters to support the ProLibertad Freedom Picnic; this is our summer
fund-raiser for our campaign work and to raise commissary money for the
Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

ALSO, THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES HAVE MADE A CALL FOR SUPPORT FOR THE VIEQUES
ARRESTEES, PLEASE SEND A DOANTION TO THE VIEQUES BAIL FUND BELOW!!

ALSO,  below the ProLibertad Picnic and Vieques Bail FUnd email, ProLibertad
has provided folks a small calendar of activities around Political
Prisoners, Political Art and Support Activities!!

Friends in Solidarity with the Cause of Peace in Vieques:

We ask your support in the face of a campaign of repression by the FBI and
the federal "justice'' system against our people in struggle.  Twelve people
accused of conspiracy and destruction of federal property during the
activities of last May First face possible sentences of 5 to 20 years in
prison.

We include with this note a model letter to send by fax to the Puerto Rican
congress people and the Puerto Rico Resident Commissioner in Washington,
Anibal Acevedo Vil�, whose phone and fax numbers are listed below.

We also would appreciate any economic help for the Committee of Families of
Arrested - May First.  Donations may be deposited in the Banco Popular
account # 512 076 726 or checks sent in the name of the group to:  P.O. Box
1424 Vieques, PR  00765.

With this petition, we begin a campaign to support the accused in this case.
  Thanks greatly for your consistent solidarity.

CRDV
__________________________________________________________________________________

The New York Solidarity Movement for a Free Palestine and the Brecht Forum
Present:

The Road Map to Truth Tour: Reports from Palestinian Activists

July 12
7:30pm
Brecht Forum
122 W27th. St.,10th Floor
NY, NY 10001
brechtforum.org
212.242.4201

About NYSMFP:

NYSMFP is a predominantly people of color organized
membership of activists from varied communities in New
York City with a history of mobilizing around domestic
and international struggles for economic and racial
justice.  We believe our struggles for
self-determination and resistance to imperialism are
linked to and aided by the Palestinian fight against
occupation.  We are looking forward to having Maha
Nassar and Ala Al Azzeh here speaking with our
communities first hand about the Palestinians
struggle.

About Maha Nassar:

Maha Nassar is the elected chair person of U.P.W.C.,
Union of Palestinian Womens Committees she is also
Chair Person of the Board of Trustees of the
Alternative Information Centre (co project between
Palestinian and Israeli Progressives who look for a
secular democratic State in Palestine).  She has been
a secondary school Physics teacher for 26 years and a
member of Teachers Union for the 20 past years.  Maha
Nassar is an ex-prisoner, she was in Israeli Jails
during both the first and the second Intifadas.  She
was under house arrest for 6 months during the first
Intifada.

About the UPWC:

Union of Palestinian Womens Committees is a
grassroots or mass based women's
organization doing work in West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Their main goal is to raise the awareness of women about
their social, economic and political rights, and also
to encourage women to take a role in civil society
enforcing laws that forbid discrimination against
them.  Their programs also take into consideration the
critical situation of our people under the aggressive
attacks of Israeli occupation.  Not only on
has the occupation effected our people, but also on
the infrastructure to such a degree that it brought
more responsibilities and burdens on the shoulder of
non-governmental organizations like the UPWC.


About Ala Mahmoud Younis Al Azzeh:

Ala Al Azzeh is currently pursuing an MA in
International Studies from Birzeit University and
works as a math and science teacher at Al Ezzeriyeh
Boys School.  He has been active in the Palestinian
student movement through the course of his higher
education at Bethlehem, AlQuds, and Birzeit
Universities.

He is a founding member of the Handala Center, one of
the only youth activities center in Beit Jibrin
refugee camp. He also volunteers as an
editorial assistant, translator and consultant for an
alternative English language magazine dedicated to
providing alternative and critical information and
analysis on developments in Palestine from a
progressive perspective. (See www.between-lines.org

Sliding scale: $6, $8, $10
__________________________________________________________________________________

WEDNESDAY, JULY 9TH, 2003 AT 7:30PM
THE BRECHT FORUM 122 W27TH ST., 10TH FL
THE MALCOLM X GRASSROOTS MOVEMENT AND THE BRECHT FORUM INVITE YOU TO A BOOK
PARTY/FORUM

We Are Our Own Liberators:  Selected Prison Writings of Jalil Muntaqim with
Asha Bandele, Antoinette Bottom* & Others TBA

Join us to celebrate the long-awaited publication of prison writings by
former Black Panther Party/Black Liberation Army member Jalil Muntaqim, one
of the world's longest held political prisoners. Imprisoned since 1971, as a
result of the American government's campaign to crush domestic opposition,
this collection spans his 31 years of prison writings and outlines his major
theoretical contributions to the Black Liberation and New-Afrikan
Independence Movements. It includes "We Are Our Own Liberators," "Africans
In The Diaspora," "On the Black Liberation Army," "A Case Against Domestic
Neo-Colonialism," "For The Liberation of North America," "National Strategy
for the Front for the Liberation of the New Afrikan Nation," "Handbook for
Revolutionary Nationalist Cadres," "The National and International Struggle
Toward a New Global Revolutionary Pan-Afrikan Strategy," and his 1975
sentencing statement.

Asha Bandele is an editor at Essence magazine, published author of The
Prisoners Wife: A Memoir and Absence in the Palm of my Hands. She is a
member of Malcolm X Grassroots Movement. Antoinette Bottom (*invited) is the
daughter of Jalil Muntaqim, and is a mother. Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
__________________________________________________________________________________

FRIDAY, JULY 11TH, 2003 AT 6PM AND 8PM FILM FORUM  209 WEST HOUSTON ST.
BETWEEN 6TH AVE. AND VARICK (7TH AVENUES)
Tickets are $9.  Proceeds benefit the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement, Black
August and political prisoners.

If you haven't yet seen the Weather Underground movie, or if you've seen it
and want to see it again, please go to the Film Forum showing on FRIDAY,
JULY 11, at either 6:00 or 8:00 -- the proceeds from those showings will be
donated to the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement for their work to support and
win release of political prisoners (and especially for their annual hip-hop
concert, Black August www.blackaugust.com.) The theater holds 150 people per
show, and the more seats are filled, the more money we will raise for MXGM
and their important work to free political prisoners. The film itself makes
no mention of all the political prisoners from the Black Panther Party,
Black Liberation Army and white anti-imperialist groups still inside after
30 years. But the film-maker helped arrange these two benefit screenings.

Please circulate this message to all your friends and lists in New York, so
that we can use the film to generate support for political prisoners and the
struggle for Black liberation.

Post ID:3279
Sender:Charlotte Kates <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-15 17:11:54
Subject:RUTGERS STUDENTS: DEFEND FREE SPEECH ON CAMPUS!
Message:

PLEASE FORWARD WIDELY!

Sign online at http://www.njsolidarity.org/conference/studentcall.html
Sign via email at studentspeech@...

A call to Rutgers students and student organizations:

July 14, 2003

You may have heard of the recent attacks upon New Jersey Solidarity, a
registered student organization at the University, which is planning to
host the Third North American Student Conference of the Palestine
Solidarity Movement on October 10-12, 2003, at the Douglass College
Center. The conference, which has been held in past years at the
University of California- Berkeley and the University of Michigan- Ann
Arbor, brings together hundreds of activists for educational sessions,
activist skill-sharings and strategy meetings.

This year, however, the conference is under attack. This attack, forwarded
by State Senate President John Bennett and Governor Jim McGreevey, targets
the student organizers for their political positions, and threatens to
cancel the conference simply because state legislators disagree with the
student organizers' politics - a clear threat to freedom of speech and
association. The New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union
has expressed its deep concerns about this overt involvement of state
officials in suppressing student free speech and free expression.

To date, the University administration has held fast to principles of free
speech and free association, stating that the specific political views of
the organizers are irrelevant to the broader question of student free
speech. As students and organizers, we are all under threat whenever the
specter of official state censorship at our University is raised. Please
sign the following appeals to President McCormick and Governor McGreevey
to defend student free speech and free association. Our University and
state-level officials must be held accountable for actions that attempt to
stifle student expression and organizing!

Dear President McCormick,

As student leaders, student organizations, and active students at Rutgers
University, we are writing to call upon you to hold firm to the
University's principles of student free speech and freedom of association.
The recent attacks upon New Jersey Solidarity's planned Third North
American Student Conference of the Palestine Solidarity Movement by press
and government officials have raised the disturbing specter of official
state censorship on our campus. The call by State Senate President John
Bennett for the cancellation of the conference and the comments by
Governor Jim McGreevey that he is "concerned" about "balance" at the
conference indicate an unhealthy level of interest in student activities
that clearly fall under the banner of free speech and association. In
addition, the comments by Micah Rasmussen, McGreevey's spokesman, reported
in the Press of Atlantic City, reveal an even more worrisome approach on
the part of state officials. Rasmussen stated that McGreevey considers the
registered student organization in question "abhorrent" and that the state
government was investigating "whether or not they have a history of
violence;" he also indicated that the state government had checked, but
failed to find the organization on a list of "suspected terrorist
organizations." At a time when we are facing increased attacks on civil
rights and liberties, it is imperative that our academic institutions not
become a venue for political interrogation and persecution.

McGreevey's planned meeting with you is inappropriate and troubling; that
the governor of the state of New Jersey sees fit to involve himself in
purely internal University matters, including student organizations and
their activities - especially as the University's budget is slashed -
indicates a fundamental lack of respect for academic freedom and freedom
of association.

As students, we recognize that a threat to one student's freedom of speech
and association is a threat to us all. We represent many backgrounds and
causes, yet we are united in our belief that our University may only
thrive as an academic center when freedom of debate and discourse is
respected. Our campus should be an open site for discussion and dialogue -
not a place where all student expression requires state sanction. Such a
concept is an affront not only to any concept of a university, but also to
the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.

Please continue to uphold the University's position supporting student
free speech and rebuff the state government's attempt to interfere in
internal University matters and student political work.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Signatories

Dear Governor McGreevey,

As student leaders, student organizations, and active students at Rutgers
University, we are writing to call upon you to reject attacks upon student
free speech and freedom of expression. The recent attacks upon New Jersey
Solidarity's planned Third North American Student Conference of the
Palestine Solidarity Movement by press and government officials have
raised the disturbing specter of official state censorship on our campus.
The call by State Senate President John Bennett for the cancellation of
the conference and by your spokesperson that you are "concerned" about
"balance" at the conference indicate an unhealthy level of interest in
student activities that clearly fall under the banner of free speech and
association.

The comments by Micah Rasmussen, your spokesman, reported in the Press of
Atlantic City, reveal an even more worrisome approach. Rasmussen stated
that you consider the registered student organization in question
"abhorrent" and that the state government was investigating "whether or
not they have a history of violence;" he also indicated that the state
government had checked, but failed to find the organization on a list of
"suspected terrorist organizations." At a time when we are facing
increased attacks on civil rights and liberties, it is imperative that our
academic institutions not become a venue for political interrogation and
persecution.

The fact that you have sought a meeting with Rutgers University President
Richard McCormick rather than recognizing this as a clear issue of freedom
of speech raises very severe questions about your respect as a governor
for the principles of higher education and the university community, and
more fundamental questions about your respect for the First Amendment. The
political activities and events of student organizations should be no more
subject to review by the state governor than any other political events -
any indication to the contrary indicates approval of official state
censorship.

We are calling upon you to reject political baiting and attempts at
repression of student organizations and the student community at Rutgers
University. It is not the place of the state governor to interfere with
the operations of the University, nor is it the place of the governor to
approve or disapprove of student organizing. Our University is an
excellent university because it is committed to principles of a fine
university - including those of an open campus environment, debate,
dialogue and discussion. Please step back from your comments that you are
"investigating" New Jersey Solidarity. Political organizations need not be
"investigated," and your spokesperson's comments are chillingly
reminiscent of the McCarthy period.

It is imperative that our state government respect and recognize our
rights. Please respect the University's independence.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Signatories

To sign onto either or both of these letters, please fill out the form
below, or send an email to studentspeech@....



--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Charlotte L. Kates    ckates@...   ckates@...
http://www.njsolidarity.org                  http://www.rutgersdivest.org/
  http://rutgersactivism.pathbot.com/ - activism at rutgers university!
http://rapj.pathbot.com/               http://www.campus-watch=watch.com/

Post ID:3283
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-11 15:17:52
Subject:Artilces on this year's Venceremos Brigade
Message:

August 5, 2003 Tuesday Final
Edition

HEADLINE: American volunteers visited Cuba illegally to make a point

SOURCE: Osprey News Network

BYLINE: Tony Ricciuto

DATELINE: FORT ERIE

FORT ERIE - About 80 Americans, members of the volunteer organization
Venceremos Brigade, returned to the United States Monday after
spending two weeks  in Cuba.

   They arrived in Fort Erie about 8 a.m., and after listening to
speeches in front of the Mather Arch, walked across the Peace Bridge
not knowing what to expect once they reached the other side.

   The U. S. government requires travellers to obtain a U.S. Treasury
Department Licence before going to Cuba. Members of the Brigade
refuse to get the  licence as a protest against the travel
restrictions.

   "Some of us are nervous," said Sierra Thaibinh, 29, who lives in
California. "We are about to head back home and we are here to take a
visible stand. We know our rights and the rights of Cuban people."

   Thaibinh thanked those Canadians who turned out to give them words
of encouragement before they returned home.

   One of those supporters was Niagara Centre MPP Peter Kormos, who
noted that some causes are worth the risk of going to jail if it
means restoring national and international relationships.

   "These people are engaging in a clear act of civil disobedience by
declaring they have been to Cuba and they are inviting arrest and
charges," explained Kormos, an NDP MPP. "It's important to support
them."

   Kormos didn't expect any of the travellers to actually be arrested
when they returned home because the government would not want to make
martyrs of them.

   Kormos noted the law is from another era and should be changed.

   "The blockade of Cuba by the United States is barbaric and
ineffective," said Kormos. "An open relationship with Cuba can be
productive."

   This was the 34th contingent of the Venceremos Brigade to visit
Cuba.

   Kathe Karlson, from New York City, said the volunteers helped to
paint a health clinic and worked side-by-side with Cubans.

   "It was a wonderful experience," said Karlson. "It's very
important to make friends with people around the world. As Americans,
we want to be able to travel without restrictions and find out the
truth for ourselves."

   Bonnie Massey, 22, also from New York City, said Cubans are a
friendly people and the travel restriction just doesn't make any
sense. Cuba's economy  is suffering because the United States has had
a blockade in place for  more than 40 years.

   "This has been a life-changing experience for many of us. We got
to learn many things that we don't get to learn at home. It makes us
better people," said Massey.

   Members of the Brigade walked across the Peace Bridge in small
groups so they wouldn't interfere with traffic, and so they could be
processed faster once they reached the American side.

   There were no reports of anyone being arrested or unduly detained.


                            Buffalo News (New York)

                      August 4, 2003 Monday

HEADLINE: RETURNEES TO U.S. DEFY CUBA TRAVEL BAN

BYLINE: MARK SOMMER; News Staff Reporter

   More than 80 Americans returning from Cuba via Toronto this morning
defied U.S. travel restrictions by walking across the Peace Bridge.

    The crossing occurred without incident after arrangements were
made in Washington with customs officials.

    The contingent consisted of members of the Venceremos Brigade, a
Cuba friendship and solidarity association, who spent two weeks near
Havana. The protest was intended to draw attention to new Treasury
Department restrictions that have eliminated People to People
Educational Exchange licenses,  the second largest category for Cuban
travel after family visits,and to the four-decades-long economic
embargo.

    The group, which included about 25 high school students, had
spent the past two weeks working alongside Cubans to paint a
medicalcenter and do other manual work near Havana.

    "The embargo and travel ban policies of our country really hurts
them, as well as hurting us," said Bonnie Massie of New York
City. "It denies them a lot of material necessity, and it denies us a
the opportunity to learn about a whole other people."

    John Madsen, chief inspector for the Bureau of Customs and Border
Protection, said arrangements were made in advance with authorities in
Washington, D.C., to allow the protesters to return without arrest.

    "This case was referred to the Office of Foreign Assets Control,
which is a part of the Treasury Department, and in this instance they
were satisfied with the level of inspection we were doing," Madsen
said.

    In 2001, an estimated 140,000 Americans -- 60,000 illegally --
visited communist Cuba, according to the Treasury Department. That
same year, the House of Representatives voted, 232-186, to retire
restrictions on travel to  Cuba, but the Senate never voted on it.

    Earlier this year, the United States and some human rights
groups --including Amnesty International -- criticized Cuba over its
human rights record after the government imposed long prison
sentences on 75 dissidents and executed three people who tried to
hijack a boat to flee the island nation.

    But traveler Tony Ryan of Washington, D.C., suggested the United
States should be careful about pointing fingers at others.

    "People who raise that issue in the U.S. should look at the
treatment of U.S. prisoners in Cuba's Guantanamo Bay, where they are
being denied fair treatment. Or just look at the streets of the
United States and the social injustice and lack of human rights for
all kinds of people," he said.

    e-mail: msommer@...

GRAPHIC: Robert Kirkham/Buffalo News Protesters returning from Cuba
carry a banner while walking across the Peace Bridge today.


                       Copyright 2003 The Buffalo News
                            Buffalo News (New York)

                      August 3, 2003 Sunday, FINAL
EDITION

HEADLINE: VISITORS TO CUBA PLAN PEACE BRIDGE PROTEST
CROSSING

BYLINE: MARK SOMMER; News Staff Reporter

   On Monday morning, 85 visitors to Cuba are scheduled to publicly
defy a Bush administration travel ban by walking across the Peace
Bridge to re-enter the United States.

    The contingent are members of the Venceremos Brigade, a Cuba
friendship association that organized the trip. They flew to Cuba
through Toronto, which unlike the United States has no travel
restrictions to the socialist island. After a scheduled return to
Toronto Sunday night, buses are to deposit  the group at U.S. Customs
on the Fort Erie side of the bridge. They plan to cross  at 8:30
a.m., and then rally in Front Park.

    The group seeks to draw attention to recently tightened travel
restrictions.

    In March, the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets
Control announced the elimination of People to People Educational
Exchange licenses, the second largest category for Cuban travel after
family visits. More than  1,200 people who traveled to Cuba illegally
in the past year also have been  notified they will have to pay fines.

    "We are doing this because we think people should not be harassed
or fined for traveling to Cuba," said Ann Sparanese, spokeswoman for
Venceremos Brigade. "And we don't think people should have to sneak
home when they travel  there. It's our constitutional right to travel
and see Cuba for ourselves."

    For four decades, the United States has enforced an embargo on
goods into Cuba, which critics consider a relic of the Cold War. It
was slightly loosened in 2000.

    The Bush administration, which enjoys strong support from the
Cuban exile community in Miami, signaled it was getting tougher on
Cuban visitors in its first year by tripling the number of people
penalized with fines, compared with the last year of the Clinton
administration.

    Clinton went to bat for musician Ry Cooder in the waning days of
his administration, so that Cooder could return to Cuba and share in
profits from what would become the popular "Buena Vista Social Club"
recordings.

    Cuba received international criticism earlier this year for
imposing long prison sentences on 75 dissidents.

    Dennis Hays, former ambassasor to Surinam and executive vice
president of the largest anti-Castro organization, the Cuban American
National Foundation, applauds the tougher travel restrictions and
scoffed at the Venceremos  Brigade's planned action.

    "If the Venceremos Brigade wants to help people of Cuba, they
should work to get rid of this failed regime and allow the Cuban
people to decide their own future," Hays said.

    "People worry a lot about their rights, but don't worry about the
responsibilities. The (Venceremos Brigade) should look carefully and
see if they are helping or hurting the citizens of Cuba through their
action."

    The Venceremos Brigade began in 1969, when hundreds of young
people expressed solidarity with the Cuban government by helping in
the sugar harvest. Annual, unlicensed work trips have followed. This
year's visit saw  brigade members, ranging in age from high school
students to seniors, work side by side with Cubans for two weeks to
renovate a health clinic near Havana.

    In 2001, an estimated 140,000 Americans -- 60,000 illegally --
visited Cuba according to the Treasury Department. That same year,
the House of Representatives voted 232-186 to retire Cuba travel
restrictions, but  the Senate never voted on it.

    The travel challenge is a joint project with Pastors for Peace,
which delivered a caravan of food and medicine into Cuba through
Mexico last month. Representatives will be on hand at Front Park
welcome the group, along  with the Western New York Peace Center,
Buffalo State Students for Peace and the  anti-war group, A.N.S.W.E.R.

               Copyright 2003 St. Catharines Standard Group Inc.
                             All Rights Reserved
                         The Standard (St. Catharines)

                     August 2, 2003 Saturday Final
Edition

HEADLINE: Pro-Cuba organization expects repercussions for trip to
island

SOURCE: Osprey News Network

BYLINE: Jennifer Pellegrini

DATELINE: FORT ERIE

FORT ERIE - Long weekend traffic may not be the only thing slowing
down the return trip to the United States for 80 American travellers
Monday.

   The group, members of the American volunteer organization the
Venceremos  Brigade, an organization whose objective is to increase
awareness of  the merits of the Castro regime in Cuba, left Toronto's
Pearson Airport July 20,  bound for Havana, Cuba. None of the members
obtained a U.S. Treasury Department licence, a document required by
U.S. citizens for travel to Cuba. All expect to  pay the price for it.

   "We've never concerned ourselves with (licences) because we don't
believe in them," said Venceremos Brigade spokesperson Ann Sparanese,
from the group's Englewood, N.J., headquarters. "This is (an act of)
civil disobedience.

   Sparanese, who travelled to Buffalo Thursday to prepare for
Monday's arrival of Brigade members from Toronto, said she doubts
there will be any real  delay at the border, but does expect
participants -- who will freely admit  travelling to Cuba without a
licence -- will find notices in the mail not long after  their return.

   "It's a currency violation, it's not about travel," she said. "It's
about money. And our intention is not to pay a fine but to challenge
the law."

   And right now, the law says Americans cannot travel to Cuba without
first obtaining a licence from the Treasury Department's Office of
Foreign Assets Control -- essentially granting the person permission
to spend U.S. greenbacks in Cuba.

   There are a number of different licences available for a myriad of
different situations, Sparanese said, but the Venceremos Brigade has
never applied for one in its 32-year history and doesn't plan to
start now.

   She said in the past, Brigade members from all walks of life have
made the roundabout trip to Cuba -- by way of Canada -- without any
fuss or penalty.

   But Helen Santek, a member of the Niagara branch of the
Canadian-Cuban Friendship Association, which will meet the Brigade at
the Peace Bridge early Monday morning, said this group of brigade
members could find themselves in a heap of trouble when they set foot
on American soil.

   "Usually, these brigades would pass back and forth without the
Treasury Department permits, but since the U.S. has now turned its
eye toward Cuba ... they (the Bush administration), are now
threatening them."

   Those threats, she said, could include detention at the border or
monetary penalties ranging from $7,500 to $25,000 US.

   "We really don't know what to expect," she said.

   Taylor Griffin, a spokesperson for the Treasury Department, said
it's unlikely Brigade members will be detained by U.S. Customs upon
their re-entry to the States, but expects they will be fined for
their actions.

   "They may hear it from customs and they'll almost definitely be
fined" he said.

   "But they aren't going to be thrown in the slammer or anything."

Television coverage

WNED

Venceremos Brigade Returns from Cuba
Lucy Nalpathanchil

BUFFALO 2003-08-04

The 34th contingent of the Venceremos Brigade have returned from Cuba.

About 80 Americans walked across the Peace Bridge from Fort Erie this
morning. The groups travelled from Cuba without a Treasury Department
license to challenge the U.S government's restrictions on travel to
the communist country.

The contingent was not cited by U.S Customs officials at the Peace
Bridge. Member of the group, Bob Guild, says the brigade stayed in
Cuba for two weeks and volunteered at health clinics. Guild says the
Venceremos Brigade will continue to go against U.S policy until the
ban is revoked.

"Our demand is for the United States to lift the travel ban. There
are two bills in Congress, right now, sponsored by the majority of
people in the House and the Senate. We want those bills passed. We
want an end to the travel ban."

Guild says Americans who travel to Cuba without U.S permission can
face fines of up to $55,000. He says each member of the brigade may
still face sanctions from the government for their trip.

Subject:Support the Vieques 12
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is urging all our allies and supporters to 
help fund-raise for the Vieques 12. These activists have been targeted by 
the FBI and US government for being leaders in the Vieques struggle and for 
their subsequent activists as peace activists.  They need our support!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
__________________________________________________________________________________

The Friends and Family Support Committee of the May 1st Arrestees has 
established a Bank account to raise money for the cost of transportation of 
Vieques Activists, their family and legal counsel from Vieques to the main 
island of Puerto Rico.  The Bank account is a Banco Popular account #512 076 
726.  If you prefer to mail in your donation then please mail it to: 
Apartado 1424 Vieques, PR 00765.

The May 1st Arrestee Support Committee has established a Bank Account to 
raise money for all legal fees and legal processing expenditures for the 
upcoming September 8th Court Hearing.  You can send donations to Banco 
Popular # 116-26767-4 or send your donation to Apartado 191792, San Juan, 
Puerto Rico 00919-1792

Post ID:3286
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-16 15:54:47
Subject:Socialists and People's Assembly In Puerto Rico
Message:

Socialists And The So-Called Peoples� Assembly On Status
By Jorge Farinacci

In an editorial of the newspaper Claridad, July 24-31, 2003, edition of the
paper, the leadership of the newspaper champions the position of various
sectors of the independence movement in Puerto Rico which support the
process which has begun in the Legislature of Puerto Rico around legislation
about the status issue with the goal of resolving the question of political
status.  In that editorial the leadership of the newspaper presents as a
given the existence of a consensus among the pro-independence forces in
favor of a constituent assembly as it is presented and conceived by the
leaders of the Popular Democratic Party and contained in two legislative
proposals which are pending before the Legislature of Puerto Rico.

In writing this editorial the leadership of the newspaper Claridad has
committed an error reminiscent of the arrogance and presumed dominance which
helped to cause the debacle of the now defunct Puerto Rican Socialist Party.
  To obviate and disregard the fact that an important sector of the
independence movement and nearly the entire organized socialist sectors in
Puerto Rico do not support this process, does nothing to strengthen our
struggle and is merely an attempt to marginalize the most militant sector of
our struggle, a sector that has played an important role in the recent major
battles of our people (The Peoples General Strike and the Vieques Struggle)
and does not give the readers of Claridad the opportunity to become aware
that there exist various and diverse positions regarding this matter.
Claridad has every right to assume positions but it should continue and
maintain its policy of promoting the exchange and debate of ideas within the
heart of our movement.

The Nationalist Party of Puerto Rico, the Federation of University Students
Pro-Independence, the Boricua Popular Army-Macheteros, the Socialist Front
and all its member organizations (Socialist Movement of Workers, Workshop
for Political Formation, Communist Re-Foundation, the Revolutionary Party of
the Puerto Rican Workers, The Young Revolutionary League, The Union of
Socialist Youth-MST), among others, are opposed to a process which is led by
the intellectual elite and from the centers of colonial power.  The
pro-independence activists who are promoting this process cannot explain the
dramatic way in which a radical change such as this would occur in the
thinking of the great masses in Puerto Rico or in the balance of forces
among the different social classes which exist in our country.  Among all
these social classes there exist different political projects.

We can be sure that the New Progressive Party and the Popular Democratic
Party will continue to propose economic and social political projects for
our country which are in tune with northamerican interests in Puerto Rico
and which favor the political and economic privileges of the dominant social
classes in our society.  These dominant social classes some time ago tied
their fortunes and their future with that of the northamerican imperialist
bourgeoisie.

The pro-independence activists who promote participation in this process do
not have an organized political presence at this juncture which would allow
them to have a voice, even a marginal one, in this process, nor do they
attempt to build one.  There is no doubt that this idea originated in the
elitist discussions in the Puerto Rican Bar Association whose source and
inspiration are the ideas of Eugenio Maria de Hostos and the Constitution of
the Free Associated State of Puerto Rico (ELA) founded in 1952.  This idea
of the Puerto Rican Bar Association has been decreasing in its quality to
the extent that it is filtered through the colonial political apparatus.  In
addition to not having either organizational incidence nor electoral weight
that would allow it to come even remotely close to the strength that both
the colonialist and annexationist forces presently have, they have not
presented to the people of Puerto Rico a project for substantive
decolonization which they think would be the result of their participation
in this project.  The independent organization of the working class in
defense of its political and economic interests is the fundamental
requirement of political strength that we need to be able to impact the
capitalist colonial relationship which has characterized Puerto Rico since
the latter part of the 19th century.

The models of economic development and political organization and the entire
social morass that characterizes our country all respond to powerful
interests in Puerto Rico and the United States and the ideology of
dependence which still prevails with great strength because the attraction
and lure of the economic and political models of the traditional
pro-independence sectors, no longer convince anyone.  Neither the Puerto
Rican bourgeoisie, nor the country�s intellectuals which have been left like
orphans without a political project, will be capable of producing a
political project for future decolonization for our people because within
their conception of the world they will not be able to design one which goes
beyond their own interests that is one other than the model we have today.

In the best-case scenario of the remote possibility of an associated
republic in a not too distant future, such a process would be designed in
harmony with the interests of the political and economic sectors dominating
our country and based on its subordination to imperialism.  This possibility
is a remote one because it does not have a social class with enough strength
to defend it and because the sector which designs it will not have the
capability to convince the masses of workers that it is in their economic,
political and social interests.

We, the socialist of Puerto Rico, have a responsibility to continue the task
of organizing our forces and to deepen and broaden the dissemination of the
ideas of liberation and justice in the hearts of working class people so
that in the future, sooner rather than later, and as a part of the struggles
of all the peoples of the world, we can generate in an independent manner
sufficient strength and the political force which will allow us to liberate
ourselves from the colonial imperialist yoke. This will allow us to build a
better society based on justice and freedom and based on the enjoyment of
the spiritual and material wealth which are now only available to a few.

Jorge Farinacci, is one of the leaders and spokespersons of the Socialist
Front of Puerto Rico.

Translation: Courtesy of Frank Velgara, Working Group on Puerto Rico of the
Socialist Front of Puerto Rico (New York).

Los socialistas y la llamada
Asamblea de Pueblo sobre el status

Por Jorge Farinacci


En el editorial del peri�dico Claridad, edici�n del 24 al 31 de julio, la
direcci�n del peri�dico hace suyo el planteamiento de varios sectores del
independentismo apoyando el proceso que se intenta comenzar en la
legislatura de Puerto Rico sobre una legislaci�n de status de pueblo con el
prop�sito de “resolver el dilema del status”. En esta editorial
la direcci�n del peri�dico da por hecho la existencia de un consenso en el
independentismo en favor de un proceso de asamblea constituyente tal y como
lo conciben los dirigentes del Partido Popular y el cual est� plasmado en
dos proyectos de ley pendientes en la legislatura de Puerto Rico.

Al escribir esta editorial la direcci�n del peri�dico Claridad comete un
error que nos recuerda a la arrogancia y prepotencia que ayudaron a causar
la debacle del hoy difunto Partido Socialista Puertorriqueo. El
obviar el hecho de que un sector importante del independentismo y casi la
totalidad del sector socialista organizado en Puerto Rico no favorecen este
proceso no le hace bien a nuestra lucha y es solamente un intento de
marginar al sector m�s militante de nuestra lucha, el cual ha tenido un rol
muy importante en las recientes grandes batallas de nuestro pueblo (Huelga
del Pueblo y Vieques)y no le brinda a los lectores de Claridad la
oportunidad de conocer que existen diversas posiciones frente a este asunto.
Claridad tiene todo el derecho a tomar posiciones pero debe mantener su
pol�tica de fomentar el debate de ideas en el seno de nuestro movimiento.

El Partido Nacionalista de Puerto Rico, la Federaci�n de Universitarios Pro
Independencia, el Ejercito Popular Boricua-Macheteros, el Frente Socialista
y todas sus organizaciones (Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores, Taller de
Formaci�n Pol�tica, Refundaci�n Comunista, Partido Revolucionario de los
Trabajadores Puertorriqueos, Liga Juvenil Revolucionaria y Uni�n de
Juventudes Socialistas-MST) ,entre otros, se oponen a un proceso dirigido
desde las �lites intelectuales y desde los centros de poder colonial. Los
independentistas que promueven el mismo no pueden explicar la manera
dram�tica en que ocurrir�  un cambio radical en el pensamiento de las
grandes mayor�as en Puerto Rico y en la correlaci�n de fuerzas entre las
diversas clases sociales existentes en nuestro pa�s, las cuales tienen
proyectos pol�ticos distintos entre s�. Podemos estar seguros de que el
Partido Nuevo Progresista y el Partido Popular Democr�tico seguir�n
proponiendo proyectos pol�ticos sociales y econ�micos para nuestro pa�s
afines con los intereses norteamericanos en Puerto Rico y que  favorezcan
los privilegios pol�ticos y econ�micos de las clases sociales dominantes en
nuestra sociedad, las cuales hace muchos aos amarraron su suerte y
su futuro a la burgues�a imperialista norteamericana.

Los independentistas que promueven la participaci�n en este proceso no
tienen, en este momento,  una correspondencia organizativa ,o el intento de
tenerla, que les permita tener una voz aunque sea marginal en este proceso.
No hay duda de que esta idea se origin� en discusiones   elitistas del
Colegio de Abogados de Puerto Rico utilizando como fuente de inspiraci�n las
ideas de Eugenio Mar�a de Hostos y la Constituci�n del Estado Libre Asociado
de Puerto Rico del 1952 . Esta idea del Colegio de Abogados ha ido
desmereciendo en calidad a medida que pasa por el crisol de los pol�ticos
coloniales. Adem�s de no tener correspondencia organizativa ni fuerza
electoral que les permita trastocar la fuerza que hoy tienen los sectores
colonialistas y anexionistas, tampoco le han presentado al pueblo el
proyecto descolonizador sustantivo que piensan ser� el resultado de su
participaci�n en este  proyecto. La organizaci�n independiente del pueblo
trabajador en defensa de sus intereses pol�ticos y econ�micos es el
requisito primordial de fuerza que necesitamos para poder trastocar la
relaci�n colonial capitalista que caracteriza a Puerto Rico desde finales
del siglo XIX .Los modelos de desarrollo econ�mico, de organizaci�n pol�tica
y todo el tinglado social que nos caracteriza, responden a intereses
poderosos aqu� en Puerto Rico como en los Estados Unidos y la ideolog�a de
dependencia todav�a prevalece con gran fuerza ya que los amagos de proyectos
y modelos pol�ticos y econ�micos del independentismo tradicional no
convencen a nadie. Ni la burgues�a puertorriquea ni la
intelectualidad criolla, hu�rfana de proyecto pol�tico, ser�n capaces de
producir  un proyecto de futuro descolonizador para nuestro pueblo porque
dentro de su concepci�n de mundo no podr�n dise�ar uno que sea superior para
sus intereses que el modelo que hoy tenemos. En el mejor caso de la remota
posibilidad de una rep�blica asociada en alg�n futuro no muy lejano, �sta
ser� diseada en armon�a con los intereses de los sectores pol�ticos
y econ�micos hegem�nicos en nuestro pa�s partiendo de la subordinaci�n al
imperialismo. Esta posibilidad es remota porque no tiene una clase social
con fuerza para defenderla y porque  el sector que la disee no ser�
capaz de convencer al pueblo trabajador de que la misma responder� a sus
intereses econ�micos, pol�ticos y sociales.

Los socialistas de Puerto Rico tenemos la responsabilidad de seguir la
tarea de organizar nuestras fuerzas y de ampliar y profundizar la
diseminaci�n de las ideas libertadoras y de justicia en el seno del pueblo
trabajador para que en alg�n momento futuro, m�s temprano que tarde, y como
parte de la lucha de todos los pueblos del mundo generemos de manera
independiente la fuerza suficiente que nos permita liberarnos del yugo
colonial imperialista y podamos construir una sociedad superior basada en la
justicia, en la libertad y en el disfrute de los bienes materiales y
espirituales hoy disponibles para s�lo unos pocos.

Jorge Farinacci, es un lider y protavoz de el Frente Socialista De Puerto
Rico.
