Post ID:3287
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-16 15:55:54
Subject:Socialists and the People's Assembly in Puerto Rico
Message:

Socialists And The So-Called Peoples� Assembly On Status
By Jorge Farinacci

In an editorial of the newspaper Claridad, July 24-31, 2003, edition of the
paper, the leadership of the newspaper champions the position of various
sectors of the independence movement in Puerto Rico which support the
process which has begun in the Legislature of Puerto Rico around legislation
about the status issue with the goal of resolving the question of political
status.  In that editorial the leadership of the newspaper presents as a
given the existence of a consensus among the pro-independence forces in
favor of a constituent assembly as it is presented and conceived by the
leaders of the Popular Democratic Party and contained in two legislative
proposals which are pending before the Legislature of Puerto Rico.

In writing this editorial the leadership of the newspaper Claridad has
committed an error reminiscent of the arrogance and presumed dominance which
helped to cause the debacle of the now defunct Puerto Rican Socialist Party.
  To obviate and disregard the fact that an important sector of the
independence movement and nearly the entire organized socialist sectors in
Puerto Rico do not support this process, does nothing to strengthen our
struggle and is merely an attempt to marginalize the most militant sector of
our struggle, a sector that has played an important role in the recent major
battles of our people (The Peoples General Strike and the Vieques Struggle)
and does not give the readers of Claridad the opportunity to become aware
that there exist various and diverse positions regarding this matter.
Claridad has every right to assume positions but it should continue and
maintain its policy of promoting the exchange and debate of ideas within the
heart of our movement.

The Nationalist Party of Puerto Rico, the Federation of University Students
Pro-Independence, the Boricua Popular Army-Macheteros, the Socialist Front
and all its member organizations (Socialist Movement of Workers, Workshop
for Political Formation, Communist Re-Foundation, the Revolutionary Party of
the Puerto Rican Workers, The Young Revolutionary League, The Union of
Socialist Youth-MST), among others, are opposed to a process which is led by
the intellectual elite and from the centers of colonial power.  The
pro-independence activists who are promoting this process cannot explain the
dramatic way in which a radical change such as this would occur in the
thinking of the great masses in Puerto Rico or in the balance of forces
among the different social classes which exist in our country.  Among all
these social classes there exist different political projects.

We can be sure that the New Progressive Party and the Popular Democratic
Party will continue to propose economic and social political projects for
our country which are in tune with northamerican interests in Puerto Rico
and which favor the political and economic privileges of the dominant social
classes in our society.  These dominant social classes some time ago tied
their fortunes and their future with that of the northamerican imperialist
bourgeoisie.

The pro-independence activists who promote participation in this process do
not have an organized political presence at this juncture which would allow
them to have a voice, even a marginal one, in this process, nor do they
attempt to build one.  There is no doubt that this idea originated in the
elitist discussions in the Puerto Rican Bar Association whose source and
inspiration are the ideas of Eugenio Maria de Hostos and the Constitution of
the Free Associated State of Puerto Rico (ELA) founded in 1952.  This idea
of the Puerto Rican Bar Association has been decreasing in its quality to
the extent that it is filtered through the colonial political apparatus.  In
addition to not having either organizational incidence nor electoral weight
that would allow it to come even remotely close to the strength that both
the colonialist and annexationist forces presently have, they have not
presented to the people of Puerto Rico a project for substantive
decolonization which they think would be the result of their participation
in this project.  The independent organization of the working class in
defense of its political and economic interests is the fundamental
requirement of political strength that we need to be able to impact the
capitalist colonial relationship which has characterized Puerto Rico since
the latter part of the 19th century.

The models of economic development and political organization and the entire
social morass that characterizes our country all respond to powerful
interests in Puerto Rico and the United States and the ideology of
dependence which still prevails with great strength because the attraction
and lure of the economic and political models of the traditional
pro-independence sectors, no longer convince anyone.  Neither the Puerto
Rican bourgeoisie, nor the country�s intellectuals which have been left like
orphans without a political project, will be capable of producing a
political project for future decolonization for our people because within
their conception of the world they will not be able to design one which goes
beyond their own interests that is one other than the model we have today.

In the best-case scenario of the remote possibility of an associated
republic in a not too distant future, such a process would be designed in
harmony with the interests of the political and economic sectors dominating
our country and based on its subordination to imperialism.  This possibility
is a remote one because it does not have a social class with enough strength
to defend it and because the sector which designs it will not have the
capability to convince the masses of workers that it is in their economic,
political and social interests.

We, the socialist of Puerto Rico, have a responsibility to continue the task
of organizing our forces and to deepen and broaden the dissemination of the
ideas of liberation and justice in the hearts of working class people so
that in the future, sooner rather than later, and as a part of the struggles
of all the peoples of the world, we can generate in an independent manner
sufficient strength and the political force which will allow us to liberate
ourselves from the colonial imperialist yoke. This will allow us to build a
better society based on justice and freedom and based on the enjoyment of
the spiritual and material wealth which are now only available to a few.

Jorge Farinacci, is one of the leaders and spokespersons of the Socialist
Front of Puerto Rico.

Translation: Courtesy of Frank Velgara, Working Group on Puerto Rico of the
Socialist Front of Puerto Rico (New York).

Los socialistas y la llamada
Asamblea de Pueblo sobre el status

Por Jorge Farinacci


En el editorial del peri�dico Claridad, edici�n del 24 al 31 de julio, la
direcci�n del peri�dico hace suyo el planteamiento de varios sectores del
independentismo apoyando el proceso que se intenta comenzar en la
legislatura de Puerto Rico sobre una legislaci�n de status de pueblo con el
prop�sito de “resolver el dilema del status”. En esta editorial
la direcci�n del peri�dico da por hecho la existencia de un consenso en el
independentismo en favor de un proceso de asamblea constituyente tal y como
lo conciben los dirigentes del Partido Popular y el cual est� plasmado en
dos proyectos de ley pendientes en la legislatura de Puerto Rico.

Al escribir esta editorial la direcci�n del peri�dico Claridad comete un
error que nos recuerda a la arrogancia y prepotencia que ayudaron a causar
la debacle del hoy difunto Partido Socialista Puertorriqueo. El
obviar el hecho de que un sector importante del independentismo y casi la
totalidad del sector socialista organizado en Puerto Rico no favorecen este
proceso no le hace bien a nuestra lucha y es solamente un intento de
marginar al sector m�s militante de nuestra lucha, el cual ha tenido un rol
muy importante en las recientes grandes batallas de nuestro pueblo (Huelga
del Pueblo y Vieques)y no le brinda a los lectores de Claridad la
oportunidad de conocer que existen diversas posiciones frente a este asunto.
Claridad tiene todo el derecho a tomar posiciones pero debe mantener su
pol�tica de fomentar el debate de ideas en el seno de nuestro movimiento.

El Partido Nacionalista de Puerto Rico, la Federaci�n de Universitarios Pro
Independencia, el Ejercito Popular Boricua-Macheteros, el Frente Socialista
y todas sus organizaciones (Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores, Taller de
Formaci�n Pol�tica, Refundaci�n Comunista, Partido Revolucionario de los
Trabajadores Puertorriqueos, Liga Juvenil Revolucionaria y Uni�n de
Juventudes Socialistas-MST) ,entre otros, se oponen a un proceso dirigido
desde las �lites intelectuales y desde los centros de poder colonial. Los
independentistas que promueven el mismo no pueden explicar la manera
dram�tica en que ocurrir�  un cambio radical en el pensamiento de las
grandes mayor�as en Puerto Rico y en la correlaci�n de fuerzas entre las
diversas clases sociales existentes en nuestro pa�s, las cuales tienen
proyectos pol�ticos distintos entre s�. Podemos estar seguros de que el
Partido Nuevo Progresista y el Partido Popular Democr�tico seguir�n
proponiendo proyectos pol�ticos sociales y econ�micos para nuestro pa�s
afines con los intereses norteamericanos en Puerto Rico y que  favorezcan
los privilegios pol�ticos y econ�micos de las clases sociales dominantes en
nuestra sociedad, las cuales hace muchos aos amarraron su suerte y
su futuro a la burgues�a imperialista norteamericana.

Los independentistas que promueven la participaci�n en este proceso no
tienen, en este momento,  una correspondencia organizativa ,o el intento de
tenerla, que les permita tener una voz aunque sea marginal en este proceso.
No hay duda de que esta idea se origin� en discusiones   elitistas del
Colegio de Abogados de Puerto Rico utilizando como fuente de inspiraci�n las
ideas de Eugenio Mar�a de Hostos y la Constituci�n del Estado Libre Asociado
de Puerto Rico del 1952 . Esta idea del Colegio de Abogados ha ido
desmereciendo en calidad a medida que pasa por el crisol de los pol�ticos
coloniales. Adem�s de no tener correspondencia organizativa ni fuerza
electoral que les permita trastocar la fuerza que hoy tienen los sectores
colonialistas y anexionistas, tampoco le han presentado al pueblo el
proyecto descolonizador sustantivo que piensan ser� el resultado de su
participaci�n en este  proyecto. La organizaci�n independiente del pueblo
trabajador en defensa de sus intereses pol�ticos y econ�micos es el
requisito primordial de fuerza que necesitamos para poder trastocar la
relaci�n colonial capitalista que caracteriza a Puerto Rico desde finales
del siglo XIX .Los modelos de desarrollo econ�mico, de organizaci�n pol�tica
y todo el tinglado social que nos caracteriza, responden a intereses
poderosos aqu� en Puerto Rico como en los Estados Unidos y la ideolog�a de
dependencia todav�a prevalece con gran fuerza ya que los amagos de proyectos
y modelos pol�ticos y econ�micos del independentismo tradicional no
convencen a nadie. Ni la burgues�a puertorriquea ni la
intelectualidad criolla, hu�rfana de proyecto pol�tico, ser�n capaces de
producir  un proyecto de futuro descolonizador para nuestro pueblo porque
dentro de su concepci�n de mundo no podr�n dise�ar uno que sea superior para
sus intereses que el modelo que hoy tenemos. En el mejor caso de la remota
posibilidad de una rep�blica asociada en alg�n futuro no muy lejano, �sta
ser� diseada en armon�a con los intereses de los sectores pol�ticos
y econ�micos hegem�nicos en nuestro pa�s partiendo de la subordinaci�n al
imperialismo. Esta posibilidad es remota porque no tiene una clase social
con fuerza para defenderla y porque  el sector que la disee no ser�
capaz de convencer al pueblo trabajador de que la misma responder� a sus
intereses econ�micos, pol�ticos y sociales.

Los socialistas de Puerto Rico tenemos la responsabilidad de seguir la
tarea de organizar nuestras fuerzas y de ampliar y profundizar la
diseminaci�n de las ideas libertadoras y de justicia en el seno del pueblo
trabajador para que en alg�n momento futuro, m�s temprano que tarde, y como
parte de la lucha de todos los pueblos del mundo generemos de manera
independiente la fuerza suficiente que nos permita liberarnos del yugo
colonial imperialista y podamos construir una sociedad superior basada en la
justicia, en la libertad y en el disfrute de los bienes materiales y
espirituales hoy disponibles para s�lo unos pocos.

Jorge Farinacci, es un lider y protavoz de el Frente Socialista De Puerto
Rico.

Post ID:3288
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-22 13:57:00
Subject:¡UNIDOS SOMOS INVENCIBLES!
Message:

El peor enemigo en el movimiento es aquel que nos divide.
�UNIDOS SOMOS INVENCIBLES!

Por Ram�n Laba�ino
Uno de los Cinco H�roes Cubanos prisioneros injustamente en EE.UU.


Vivimos tiempos cruciales en el desarrollo de la humanidad. La vida del ser 
humano est� en peligro, el planeta se arriesga a desaparecer, si no 
detenemos a tiempo esta fuerza atroz y descabellada del Imperialismo 
Nazi-Fascista. Pero la forma de derrotarles existe y est� en nuestras manos: 
LA UNIDAD.

En estos momentos es imperioso e imprescindible UNIRNOS, y salvar la raza 
humana, el planeta, para las futuras generaciones. Esta es nuestra deuda con 
la historia y con nuestros propios hijos.

Sabemos que lograr esta UNIDAD no es f�cil, m�s cuando el Imperialismo nos 
teme unidos, y hace todo a su alcance para mantenernos aislados y d�biles, 
desde usar la propaganda enga�osa, hasta crear falsos l�deres e infiltrar 
nuestras filas de traidores y peones del Imperio. Pero es tarea nuestra 
depurar nuestras filas y fortalecernos.
Hay que empezar por UNIR a todas las fuerzas progresistas, de izquierda, 
ecologistas, luchadores civiles, etc, en un frente cohesionado 
Anti-Imperialista; y no hablamos de sue�os ni imposibles, pues las 
condiciones para ello existen, veamos:

Hoy m�s que nunca antes existe un fuerte movimiento popular casi un�nime en 
contra de la Guerra, del Imperialismo Norteamericano y su bloque de 
vasallos; existe una enorme repulsa a la figura del se�or George W. Bush, 
crece la lucha por los derechos civiles tanto en EE.UU. como en el resto de 
las grandes potencias, hay un elevado descontento por el desastre del 
Neo-Liberalismo y por las f�rmulas capitalistas, que han llevado a nuestros 
pa�ses a una profunda e insalvable crisis, que parece sin salida. �Como es 
posible entonces que no podamos aglutinar todas estas fuerzas en un frente 
�nico e indivisible?

Si en los a�os 1960-1970, cuando el gran auge de la lucha por los derechos 
civiles, sal�an a las calles manifestantes en n�mero de 20 000 y 30 000, y 
eran considerados como un movimiento fuerte y pujante; �c�mo es posible que 
hoy salgan a las calles en cifras sin precedentes de 200 000, 250 000, 1 000 
000, y hasta 2 000 000 de personas (como ha ocurrido en ciudades de Francia 
e Inglaterra, recientemente), y no seamos capaces de capitalizar, organizar 
y dirigir estas fabulosas fuerzas en aras del bien com�n: salvar el planeta, 
derrotando al imperialismo?
Para lograr la UNIDAD, debemos dejar a un lado mezquinos intereses 
personales y econ�micos, y pensar en el sacrificio y el esfuerzo como mejor 
recompensa por el bien de la humanidad.

Debemos buscar los l�deres de cada movimiento y en cada pa�s, y que cuenten 
con el apoyo mayoritario o un�nime de todos, que tenga la humildad, carisma 
y poder pol�tico de convencer y unir fuerzas.

El peor enemigo que puede haber en el movimiento progresista es aquel que 
nos divide o corrompe, y a ese m�s que nadie, hay que combatir y excomulgar 
de nuestras filas. Debemos ser celosos guardianes de la cohesi�n, la unidad 
y la pureza de nuestras fuerzas, y nunca perder la idea central: La lucha 
contra el Imperialismo.

Una vez que logremos esa Unidad monol�tica y organizada, se pasar�a entonces 
a la actividad progresista coordinada y s�lida, para dar respuesta a cada 
mal que se imponga.

Cada pueblo encontrar� cu�l es la v�a adecuada a sus condiciones objetivas y 
subjetivas, habr� que ser creativos y audaces, y no copiar f�rmulas 
prefijadas que no respondan a nuestras realidades.

Habr� que combatir en todos los frentes; por ejemplo, habr�a que crear una 
especie de CONTRA-MEDIA; o sea una poderosa empresa informativa, que con la 
verdad real, objetiva y amena, sea capaz de enfrentar y derrotar la nociva, 
tergiversadora y mentirosa propaganda imperial. Para ello habr�a que reunir 
recursos venidos de personalidades y organizaciones progresistas que cuenten 
con ellos, y as�, ir creando la MEDIA PROGRESISTA. Por ahora todos los 
esfuerzos que hagamos en la Internet son muy importantes; pero hay que hacer 
m�s, de forma que lleguemos a cada persona del planeta.

Por otro lado, el papel que han de jugar nuestros intelectuales progresistas 
es de gran importancia, siempre teniendo en cuenta que se puede criticar al 
amigo; pero nunca usar propaganda hostil y devastadora, que destruya la 
UNIDAD, y sirva como instrumento de ataque en manos del enemigo. Esto es 
casi una traici�n al movimiento progresista, y no se debe tolerar.

Ser�a iluso pensar que, un hombre "progresista", por miedo o con cuidado de 
salvar su vida ante la atrocidad imperial, trate de congraciarse con el 
imperio, criticando a las fuerzas de izquierda o progresistas del mundo; 
ser�a esto bien iluso pues, no tenga la menor duda de que, m�s tarde o m�s 
temprano, el imperialismo tratar� de exterminarnos, uno a uno; por la simple 
raz�n de que nosotros somos sus enemigos naturales; y aun con m�s desprecio 
lo har�a con aquellos que, a �ltima hora se convirtieron en traidores de la 
humanidad.

Este es, en fin, un llamado a la UNIDAD de todas nuestras fuerzas; porque 
estamos convencidos que no hay gobierno del mundo por poderoso que sea, que 
no caiga ante el empuje de todo su pueblo volcado contra �l.

Por eso, tenemos que UNIRNOS, ORGANIZAR Y DIRIGIR a nuestros pueblos como 
�nica forma de salvarlos del desastre al cual el Capitalismo, en su fase 
�ltima y terminal, nos arrastra con todas sus guerras, crisis y conflictos.

�UNIDOS SOMOS INVENCIBLES!

Ramon Laba�ino Salazar,
SP Beaumont,
Texas. USA.

imperio

Subject:ProLibertad Action Digest
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters 
to support all these endeavors and to pass along the information that this 
email digest contains.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
__________________________________________________________________________________

New York Forum With Visiting Delegation Of The Socialist Front of Puerto 
Rico

Saturday, August 30, 2003
12 Noon
St. Mary's Episcopal Church
521 West 126th Street, Manhattan
Between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue
New York City
IRT #1 and # 9 7th Avenue subway Trains To 125th Street

The Current Political/Social Reality In Puerto Rico
Presentations will include the situation facing the workers
movement, the struggle in the electrical energy sector, the
constituent assembly, perspectives on the Vieques struggle, the
potential closing of the Roosevelt Road military base, the
student movement, repression against the independence and
socialist movements in Puerto Rico.

Jorge Farinacci, Spokesperson, Socialist Front
The Student/Youth Movement In Puerto Rico
Karen Vega, Spokesperson, Socialist Front

Work/Activity Reports Of The
Working Group Of The Socialsit Front In New York
Frank Velgara, Carlos Rovira, Benjamin Ramos, Ricardo Gabriel
And others.

Invitation Extended By:
The Socialist Front of Puerto Rico
The Working Group of the Socialist Front in New York

For More Information:
(718)601-4751
(212)749-8024
__________________________________________________________________________________

After the Vieques Victory How Does Puerto Rico
Fit Into US Strategies for Global Domination?

Saturday, September 20
The Brecht Forum
122 West 27th Street - 10th Floor
Between 6th and 7th Avenue, Manhattan, New York City
10:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.
1-Day Seminar

Sponsored by the Vieques Support Campaign & the Brecht Forum.

Jorge Farinacci, Ismael Guadalupe & Others To Be Announced.

Why would the U.S. close down a base when its war machine is revved up
at an all time high?

On May 1, 2003, after years of worldwide protest, the U.S. Navy halted
the bombing of Vieques-at least for now. But the U.S. has neither
relinquished it to the people of Vieques or addressed the urgently
needed decontamination of the island after 63 years of constant naval
target practice.

The fact is that Vieques is only the tip of the military "iceberg" in
Puerto Rico. The pentagon controls 14% of the entire Puerto Rican
territory. There are 109 U.S. military bases and facilities in Puerto
Rico of which Fort Buchanan and Roosevelt Roads are the largest.
Puerto Rico houses 80% of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes
the invasion forces for all of Latin America, and all troops on their
way to Africa pass through Puerto Rico. The island is also home to the
elite components of the U.S. military such as the Green Berets, Navy
Seals, Air Force Commandos, etc.

In short, Puerto Rico is central to U.S. military domination of Latin
America and plays a major role in the global strategies of the U.S.

This one-day seminar will address the informational needs of activists
in solidarity work with the national liberation struggle as well as
activists in the Puerto Rican community and anti-war movement.

Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
__________________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York

PRESERVING THE MEMORY OF DR. PEDRO ALBIZU CAMPOS

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York are fundraising in the effort 
to renovate and preserve the tomb of Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos. The tomb needs 
immediate repairs. Funds raised will help for services to maintain the 
upkeep of the tomb and contribute towards placing an appropriate monument in 
honor of Puerto Rico�s national hero. Also, funds will be used to pay for 
travel expenses for volunteers of the Nationalist Youth who will also be 
participating in the commemoration of El Grito de Lares, Sept. 23, 2003.

For more information about the tomb or
the trip to Lares, please call
(646) 283-6253 or send an email to Tato at
tatobrujo@... or Dennis at
bosefod@....

To contribute, please send check or money
order to:

Fundacion Andres Figueroa Cordero
Att: Don Pedro�s Tomb
P.O. Box 1570
Bronx, NY 10459
__________________________________________________________________________________

Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
PO Box 1424          Vieques, Puerto Rico  00765
Tel.  787 741-0716   Fax  741-0358   E mail:  bieke@...
http://www.prorescatevieques.org             
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/bieke_pr/
Report from the Peace and Justice Camp
24 August, 203

The Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques is committed to the 
common saying here:  the struggle continues!  Every day the CRDV office in 
the Peace and Justice Camp receives and sends messages related to the work 
in this new phase in the struggle for peace on Vieques.  Our commissions on 
environment, health and development keep an intense work pace.  Myrna Pagan 
directs the Health Commission and together with Aleja Ortiz, Fela Garc�a and 
Dr. Rafael Rivera Casta�o, participate in community meetings and workshops 
with the PR Health Department to demand the medical services our people 
deserve.  Nilda Medina, Ismael Guadalupe and Gregorio Feliciano make up the 
CRDV Environment Commission and coordinate efforts to form a technical 
advisory team for the community to help design the urgently needed 
strategies to deal with the highly complicated issues of decontamination.  
Recently, in Puerto Rico, a second meeting of this initiative was held with 
the participation of the Environmental Law Clinic at the UPR; environmental 
scientists, Dr. Arturo Massol and nucelar engineer Frankie Jim�nez.  Also in 
attendance were members of the CRDV and Viequenses, Pedro Oliveras, Nandy 
Camacho and Rosita L�pez.

The CRDV Development Commission, made up of Armando Torres, Cynthia 
Mart�nez, Letty P�rez, Edgardo Rodr�guez, Carmen Valencia, Fabi�n Mart�nez, 
Robert Rabin and Xaymara Romero, prepares for the second organizing meeting 
of the Community Coalition for Sustainable Development on Vieques.  (See 
Coalition press release).  This initiative is every day more urgent due to 
the threat from speculators who look to control the greatest possible amount 
of our lands, displacing our people at an alarming rate.  The efforts of the 
Community Coalition are indispensible to assure that a Vieques freed from 
the Navy will really be controlled by the people of Vieques.

Javier Rosario, from the UPR Law School, in coordination with the CRDV, the 
Vieques Women's Alliance and the Community Group for Vieques Decontamination 
(part of the Technical Review Committee that works on clean up issues on the 
Western end of Vieques), works on funding for community education and 
technical support.  Members of the CRDV met recently with Mary Skelton, of 
the Consensus Building Institute of Boston, to discuss a proposal to help 
set up community coalitions for environmental as well as sustainable 
development initiatives.

While we work on these projects, the CRDV plays a key role in the support 
campaign for those accused in relation to the May First incidents.  Nilda 
Medina, founding member of the CRDV is one of the accused who face sentences 
of up to 20 years for charges of damage to federal property and conspiracy.  
Alba Avill�n and Xiomari Tirado, wives of two of the accused and 
coordinators of the Committee of Family and Friends of the May First 
Accused, have worked tirelessly to come up with the funding necesarry to 
cover the costs of transportation and others related to the case.  At a 
press conference in San Juan last Thursday, Myrta Sanes (mother of Jose 
Monta�ez Sanes, another accused, and sister to David Sanes); Alba Avill�n 
(wife of accused, Willi Mir�); Xiomari Tirado (wife of accused, Manuel 
P�rez) and Yolanda Medina (sister of Nilda Medina) made excellent 
declarations about the injustice of these accusations against people highly 
regarded in the community and far from being criminals, are victims of the 
criminal activity b the US Navy in Vieques.

In the name of the accused and their families, we thank the Pro Vieques 
Camp, located in the area of the federal prison at Guaynabo, who have 
coordinated logistic support - transportation, food, and housing - for the 
Viequenses during the trial period that could begin early September.  We 
extend this note of gratitude to the members of the Committee in Support of 
the Vieques Twelve and the brigade of lawyers for the defense who volunteer 
their vital services.  These are manifestations of the Puerto Rican 
solidarity that is a key element of the magic that explains the success of 
our people against the most powerful military force in the history of 
humanity.

We send a loving embrace of Congratulations to Flavio Cumpiano, Esq. CRDV 
representative in Washington, DC and Stephanie Saenger, on the occasion of 
their recent marriage.  Flavio has provided consistent and crucial 
information and advice for our committee during the past four years of 
intense struggle.

We also send our prayers and positive energies to Norma Torres and Jenny 
Ben�tez, part of our CRDV,  undergoing cancer treatment.  On the night of 22 
August, over thirty people participated in a prayer circle at the Milivy 
Camp, with the presence of Norma and under the direction of the Deacon of 
the local Catholic Church - and civil disobedient - Justino L�pez, Jr.
__________________________________________________________________________________

FRIENDS AND FAMILY OF ACCUSED FOR MAY FIRST ON VIEQUES
P.O. BOX 1424     VIEQUES, P.R.  00765
Email     bieke@...  Tel. 787-741-0716

PRESS RELEASE
20 AUGUST, 2003

VIEQUENSES SUPPORT ACCUSED FOR MAY FIRST ACTIONS

Convinced that those accused for the May First events are not criminals, the 
Mayor of Vieques, D�maso Serrano L�pez and the Municipal Assembly 
unanimously approved Resolution Number 5-2003, dated 18 August in support of 
the accused and for a motion to dismiss all charges.  The resolution states 
that �� the destructive acts were provoked by decades of repressed rage and 
frustration and not mallice or criminal intent��  The PNP (statehood party) 
representative on the assembly supported the accused as did an outspoken pro 
Navy member of the PPD (government party) on the assembly.  After the voting 
session, she said to the accused and family members present:  �You all know 
my position on the military; however, in this case I have to support my 
people because I know you are not criminals, but good Viequenses.�

The resolution was presented at a press conference in San Juan with the 
participation of the Mayor of Vieques, civiL and religious leaders, friends 
and family of the accused.  The Committee of Family and Friends of the 
Accused for May First on Vieques and the Committee in Support of the Vieques 
12 for May First � made up of solidarity groups from the main island of 
Puerto Rico � urged all members of the Puerto Rican community to show 
solidarity with the accused who include:

Nilda Medina (highly respected community leader), Jorge Cruz (Viequense from 
fishing family), Andy Santigo (Viequense laborer), Jos� Monta�ez Sanes 
(municipal employee and nephew of David Sanes, R.I.P.), Willie Mir� 
(Viequense worker and athlete), Nestor de Jes�s (school counsellor and 
community leader), Osvaldo Skerett  (viequense worker), Eric Hern�ndez 
(Viequense municipal employee and sports trainer) and Manuel P�rez 
(Viequense municipal worker).  Also facing charges for damage to federal 
property and conspiracy are Jesus Delgado, ex president of the Puerto Rico 
Teachers� Federation and Jos� P�rez, construction worker from the town of 
Mayaguez.

Jury selection is slated for September 8th.  For more information or to send 
economic support please call 787 741-0716.

Contacts:  Alba Avill�n or Xiomari Tirado

New York Forum With Visiting Delegation Of The Socialist Front of Puerto 
Rico

Saturday, August 30, 2003
12 Noon
St. Mary's Episcopal Church
521 West 126th Street, Manhattan
Between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue
New York City
IRT #1 and # 9 7th Avenue subway Trains To 125th Street

The Current Political/Social Reality In Puerto Rico
Presentations will include the situation facing the workers
movement, the struggle in the electrical energy sector, the
constituent assembly, perspectives on the Vieques struggle, the
potential closing of the Roosevelt Road military base, the
student movement, repression against the independence and
socialist movements in Puerto Rico.

Jorge Farinacci, Spokesperson, Socialist Front
The Student/Youth Movement In Puerto Rico
Karen Vega, Spokesperson, Socialist Front

Work/Activity Reports Of The
Working Group Of The Socialsit Front In New York
Frank Velgara, Carlos Rovira, Benjamin Ramos, Ricardo Gabriel
And others.

Invitation Extended By:
The Socialist Front of Puerto Rico
The Working Group of the Socialist Front in New York

For More Information:
(718)601-4751
(212)749-8024
__________________________________________________________________________________

After the Vieques Victory How Does Puerto Rico
Fit Into US Strategies for Global Domination?

Saturday, September 20
The Brecht Forum
122 West 27th Street - 10th Floor
Between 6th and 7th Avenue, Manhattan, New York City
10:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.
1-Day Seminar

Sponsored by the Vieques Support Campaign & the Brecht Forum.

Jorge Farinacci, Ismael Guadalupe & Others To Be Announced.

Why would the U.S. close down a base when its war machine is revved up
at an all time high?

On May 1, 2003, after years of worldwide protest, the U.S. Navy halted
the bombing of Vieques-at least for now. But the U.S. has neither
relinquished it to the people of Vieques or addressed the urgently
needed decontamination of the island after 63 years of constant naval
target practice.

The fact is that Vieques is only the tip of the military "iceberg" in
Puerto Rico. The pentagon controls 14% of the entire Puerto Rican
territory. There are 109 U.S. military bases and facilities in Puerto
Rico of which Fort Buchanan and Roosevelt Roads are the largest.
Puerto Rico houses 80% of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes
the invasion forces for all of Latin America, and all troops on their
way to Africa pass through Puerto Rico. The island is also home to the
elite components of the U.S. military such as the Green Berets, Navy
Seals, Air Force Commandos, etc.

In short, Puerto Rico is central to U.S. military domination of Latin
America and plays a major role in the global strategies of the U.S.

This one-day seminar will address the informational needs of activists
in solidarity work with the national liberation struggle as well as
activists in the Puerto Rican community and anti-war movement.

Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
__________________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York

PRESERVING THE MEMORY OF DR. PEDRO ALBIZU CAMPOS

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York are fundraising in the effort 
to renovate and preserve the tomb of Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos. The tomb needs 
immediate repairs. Funds raised will help for services to maintain the 
upkeep of the tomb and contribute towards placing an appropriate monument in 
honor of Puerto Rico�s national hero. Also, funds will be used to pay for 
travel expenses for volunteers of the Nationalist Youth who will also be 
participating in the commemoration of El Grito de Lares, Sept. 23, 2003.

For more information about the tomb or
the trip to Lares, please call
(646) 283-6253 or send an email to Tato at
tatobrujo@... or Dennis at
bosefod@....

To contribute, please send check or money
order to:

Fundacion Andres Figueroa Cordero
Att: Don Pedro�s Tomb
P.O. Box 1570
Bronx, NY 10459
__________________________________________________________________________________

Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
PO Box 1424          Vieques, Puerto Rico  00765
Tel.  787 741-0716   Fax  741-0358   E mail:  bieke@...
http://www.prorescatevieques.org             
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/bieke_pr/
Report from the Peace and Justice Camp
24 August, 203

The Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques is committed to the 
common saying here:  the struggle continues!  Every day the CRDV office in 
the Peace and Justice Camp receives and sends messages related to the work 
in this new phase in the struggle for peace on Vieques.  Our commissions on 
environment, health and development keep an intense work pace.  Myrna Pagan 
directs the Health Commission and together with Aleja Ortiz, Fela Garc�a and 
Dr. Rafael Rivera Casta�o, participate in community meetings and workshops 
with the PR Health Department to demand the medical services our people 
deserve.  Nilda Medina, Ismael Guadalupe and Gregorio Feliciano make up the 
CRDV Environment Commission and coordinate efforts to form a technical 
advisory team for the community to help design the urgently needed 
strategies to deal with the highly complicated issues of decontamination.  
Recently, in Puerto Rico, a second meeting of this initiative was held with 
the participation of the Environmental Law Clinic at the UPR; environmental 
scientists, Dr. Arturo Massol and nucelar engineer Frankie Jim�nez.  Also in 
attendance were members of the CRDV and Viequenses, Pedro Oliveras, Nandy 
Camacho and Rosita L�pez.

The CRDV Development Commission, made up of Armando Torres, Cynthia 
Mart�nez, Letty P�rez, Edgardo Rodr�guez, Carmen Valencia, Fabi�n Mart�nez, 
Robert Rabin and Xaymara Romero, prepares for the second organizing meeting 
of the Community Coalition for Sustainable Development on Vieques.  (See 
Coalition press release).  This initiative is every day more urgent due to 
the threat from speculators who look to control the greatest possible amount 
of our lands, displacing our people at an alarming rate.  The efforts of the 
Community Coalition are indispensible to assure that a Vieques freed from 
the Navy will really be controlled by the people of Vieques.

Javier Rosario, from the UPR Law School, in coordination with the CRDV, the 
Vieques Women's Alliance and the Community Group for Vieques Decontamination 
(part of the Technical Review Committee that works on clean up issues on the 
Western end of Vieques), works on funding for community education and 
technical support.  Members of the CRDV met recently with Mary Skelton, of 
the Consensus Building Institute of Boston, to discuss a proposal to help 
set up community coalitions for environmental as well as sustainable 
development initiatives.

While we work on these projects, the CRDV plays a key role in the support 
campaign for those accused in relation to the May First incidents.  Nilda 
Medina, founding member of the CRDV is one of the accused who face sentences 
of up to 20 years for charges of damage to federal property and conspiracy.  
Alba Avill�n and Xiomari Tirado, wives of two of the accused and 
coordinators of the Committee of Family and Friends of the May First 
Accused, have worked tirelessly to come up with the funding necesarry to 
cover the costs of transportation and others related to the case.  At a 
press conference in San Juan last Thursday, Myrta Sanes (mother of Jose 
Monta�ez Sanes, another accused, and sister to David Sanes); Alba Avill�n 
(wife of accused, Willi Mir�); Xiomari Tirado (wife of accused, Manuel 
P�rez) and Yolanda Medina (sister of Nilda Medina) made excellent 
declarations about the injustice of these accusations against people highly 
regarded in the community and far from being criminals, are victims of the 
criminal activity b the US Navy in Vieques.

In the name of the accused and their families, we thank the Pro Vieques 
Camp, located in the area of the federal prison at Guaynabo, who have 
coordinated logistic support - transportation, food, and housing - for the 
Viequenses during the trial period that could begin early September.  We 
extend this note of gratitude to the members of the Committee in Support of 
the Vieques Twelve and the brigade of lawyers for the defense who volunteer 
their vital services.  These are manifestations of the Puerto Rican 
solidarity that is a key element of the magic that explains the success of 
our people against the most powerful military force in the history of 
humanity.

We send a loving embrace of Congratulations to Flavio Cumpiano, Esq. CRDV 
representative in Washington, DC and Stephanie Saenger, on the occasion of 
their recent marriage.  Flavio has provided consistent and crucial 
information and advice for our committee during the past four years of 
intense struggle.

We also send our prayers and positive energies to Norma Torres and Jenny 
Ben�tez, part of our CRDV,  undergoing cancer treatment.  On the night of 22 
August, over thirty people participated in a prayer circle at the Milivy 
Camp, with the presence of Norma and under the direction of the Deacon of 
the local Catholic Church - and civil disobedient - Justino L�pez, Jr.
__________________________________________________________________________________

FRIENDS AND FAMILY OF ACCUSED FOR MAY FIRST ON VIEQUES
P.O. BOX 1424     VIEQUES, P.R.  00765
Email     bieke@...  Tel. 787-741-0716

PRESS RELEASE
20 AUGUST, 2003

VIEQUENSES SUPPORT ACCUSED FOR MAY FIRST ACTIONS

Convinced that those accused for the May First events are not criminals, the 
Mayor of Vieques, D�maso Serrano L�pez and the Municipal Assembly 
unanimously approved Resolution Number 5-2003, dated 18 August in support of 
the accused and for a motion to dismiss all charges.  The resolution states 
that �� the destructive acts were provoked by decades of repressed rage and 
frustration and not mallice or criminal intent��  The PNP (statehood party) 
representative on the assembly supported the accused as did an outspoken pro 
Navy member of the PPD (government party) on the assembly.  After the voting 
session, she said to the accused and family members present:  �You all know 
my position on the military; however, in this case I have to support my 
people because I know you are not criminals, but good Viequenses.�

The resolution was presented at a press conference in San Juan with the 
participation of the Mayor of Vieques, civiL and religious leaders, friends 
and family of the accused.  The Committee of Family and Friends of the 
Accused for May First on Vieques and the Committee in Support of the Vieques 
12 for May First � made up of solidarity groups from the main island of 
Puerto Rico � urged all members of the Puerto Rican community to show 
solidarity with the accused who include:

Nilda Medina (highly respected community leader), Jorge Cruz (Viequense from 
fishing family), Andy Santigo (Viequense laborer), Jos� Monta�ez Sanes 
(municipal employee and nephew of David Sanes, R.I.P.), Willie Mir� 
(Viequense worker and athlete), Nestor de Jes�s (school counsellor and 
community leader), Osvaldo Skerett  (viequense worker), Eric Hern�ndez 
(Viequense municipal employee and sports trainer) and Manuel P�rez 
(Viequense municipal worker).  Also facing charges for damage to federal 
property and conspiracy are Jesus Delgado, ex president of the Puerto Rico 
Teachers� Federation and Jos� P�rez, construction worker from the town of 
Mayaguez.

Jury selection is slated for September 8th.  For more information or to send 
economic support please call 787 741-0716.

Contacts:  Alba Avill�n or Xiomari Tirado

Post ID:3293
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-27 20:44:54
Subject:Safiya Bukhari in the hearts of the People!!
Message:

Safiya Bukhari en el corazon del Pueblo!! Safiya Bukhari in the hearts of 
the People!!
by The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign mourns the loss our sister, ally, comrade 
and friend Safiya Asia Bukhari.  Safiya was an extraordinary human being 
whose life was an example of true dedication and love for all peoples.  
Safiya exemplified the most beautiful and powerful qualities of a 
revolutionary; she was strong, loving, a teacher, a sister to all, 
inspirational, and motivational.  Safiya's commitment to freedom and 
revolution was infectious and touched all who knew her and had the privilege 
to work with her. A powerful force for change and struggle, Safiya was a 
former Black Panther and Black Liberation Army member.  She spent nine years 
as a Political Prisoner for her work with the BLA.  She was the co-chair of 
the New York Free Mumia Coalition and co-coordinated the work of the Jericho 
Movement to Free all Political Priosners and Prisoners of War.  Safiya was 
also a producer for "Where we live" on WBAI 99.5 fm, where she produced 
shows about working class politics and issues.  Safiya, much like Political 
Prisoner Mumia Abu Jamal, was a voice for the voiceless and empowered 
communities through her work.

A consummate internationalist, Safiya's work in solidarity of all National 
Liberation struggles made her a friend and ally to the Puerto Rican 
Independence movement.  Her comiment to the freedom of the Puerto Rican 
Political Prisoners/POWs, endeared  her  to many Puerto Rican Independence 
leaders, such as Rafael Cancel Miranda and Lolita Lebron. Safiya cared for 
the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners/POWs as though they were her own 
family.

The loss of Safiya Bukhari will be felt in the hearts and souls of the 
people for a long time. Safiya gave us strength, hope and determination.  
She taught us about camaraderie and love.  Safiya dedicated her life to 
freedom and revolution; In honor of her amazing example, we continue on the 
road towards freedom for all Political Prisoners and Prisoners of War.  We 
continue moving forward, learning and growing, teaching and passing down our 
revolutionary traditions.  We carry on, with Safiya in our hearts, towards 
liberation as she would have wanted us to.

Safiya BuKHari Presente!!
Safiya Buhkari en el corazon del Pueblo!!
FREE ALL POLITICAL PRISONERS AND PRISONERS OF WAR!!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

PLease attend the following in support of Safiya and her family!!

Wake & Viewing
Friday, August 29th 4:00-8:30 p.m.

Funeral
Saturday, August 30th 9:00-10:00 a.m.

All services will be held at:
House of the Lord Church, 415 Atlantic Ave (between Nevins & Bond)
Brooklyn, NY 11217

Please send donations to:
Shylis Turner
97-17 134th St.
Richmond Hills, NY 11419-2326

_________________________________________________________________
Get MSN 8 and enjoy automatic e-mail virus protection.  
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign mourns the loss our sister, ally, comrade 
and friend Safiya Asia Bukhari.  Safiya was an extraordinary human being

Safiya exemplified the most beautiful and powerful qualities of a

revolution was infectious and touched all who knew her and had the privilege

former Black Panther and Black Liberation Army member.  She spent nine years 
as a Political Prisoner for her work with the BLA.  She was the co-chair of 
the New York Free Mumia Coalition and co-coordinated the work of the Jericho 
Movement to Free all Political Priosners and Prisoners of War.  Safiya was 
also a producer for "Where we live" on WBAI 99.5 fm, where she produced

freedom and revolution; In honor of her amazing example, we continue on the

continue moving forward, learning and growing, teaching and passing down our

The September 27 Welcoming Committee Invites You
To Join The Friends Of Cuba
Saturday, September 27, 2003
To Welcome
Felipe P�rez Roque
Cuba�s Minister Of Foreign Relations
[Location To Be Announced]

Dear Friends:

September 16, 2003, marks the opening session of the 58th United Nations 
General Assembly in New York City. On September 27, 2003, the friends of 
Cuba are organizing a peoples� welcome for Cuba�s Minister of Foreign 
Relations, Felipe P�rez Roque.

This will be an important occasion for Cuba�s friends to become aware and 
informed of the latest developments in U.S.-Cuba relations, Cuba�s 
assessment of the international situation, the campaign to free the Cuban 5 
currently held in U.S. federal penitentiaries, and the travel challenges 
which have taken place this year.  These and other issues of relevant to our 
work in support Cuba, ending the U.S. blockade and support the Cuban 5 will 
be addressed.

Many of you and/or your organizations were key to a very successful 
celebration of the 50th Anniversary of Moncada, recently held in New York 
City at the Martin Luther King Labor Center.  The friends of Cuba are 
confident that we can have another major event for Cuba on September 27th.

Your endorsement now and your financial support through donations, in-kind 
contributions, participation in the September 27th Welcoming Committee, 
and/or an ad in the September 27th Journal, will go along way in making this 
expression of our support for Cuba another resounding success.

Please fill out the information requested below and forward this 
information. Time is short and your prompt response and help is greatly 
appreciated.

The September 27th Welcoming Committee
August 28, 2003

ENDORSEMENT INFORMATION

What we really need is your support and input in the organizing process. 
Please take the time to complete the form below, it will make a difference 
in the quality of our organizing efforts for September 27th.

Organization:
Contact:
Address:
City/State/Zip Code
Telephone:
Fax:
E-mail:

Give name of organization/person as it should appear on endorsement list:


JOURNAL INFORMATION

The September 27th Journal will be distributed the day of the event. Space 
rates for the journal are as follows:

Full Page:  $200  - (7.5 by 10 inches)
Half Page: $100  -  (7.5 by 4.75 inches)
Quarter Page: $50 - (3.5 by 4.75 inches)
Business Card: $35 - (3.5 by 2 inches)
12 Word Greeting: - $25

Yes, my organization will place an ad in the journal:

Please indicate size & dollar amount of ad:

Each organization is responsible for text and graphics.  All ads should be 
mailed in its original format (especially those with graphics) with a check 
in the correct amount payable to IFCO/September 27th Welcoming Committee, 
402 West 145th Street, New York, New York 10031

Note: Once we recieve your information for endorsement and for the journal 
ad, you will be contacted by the committee working on the ad if any further 
information is needed.  You will also recieve an e-mail and format to use in 
the event you choose to send a camera-ready ad by e-mail.

ENDORSERS (list in formation):

________________________________________________________________________________

After the Vieques Victory How Does Puerto Rico
Fit Into US Strategies for Global Domination?

Saturday, September 20
The Brecht Forum
122 West 27th Street - 10th Floor
Between 6th and 7th Avenue, Manhattan, New York City
10:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.
1-Day Seminar

Sponsored by the Vieques Support Campaign & the Brecht Forum.

Jorge Farinacci, Ismael Guadalupe & Others To Be Announced.

Why would the U.S. close down a base when its war machine is revved up
at an all time high?

On May 1, 2003, after years of worldwide protest, the U.S. Navy halted
the bombing of Vieques-at least for now. But the U.S. has neither
relinquished it to the people of Vieques or addressed the urgently
needed decontamination of the island after 63 years of constant naval
target practice.

The fact is that Vieques is only the tip of the military "iceberg" in
Puerto Rico. The pentagon controls 14% of the entire Puerto Rican
territory. There are 109 U.S. military bases and facilities in Puerto
Rico of which Fort Buchanan and Roosevelt Roads are the largest.
Puerto Rico houses 80% of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes
the invasion forces for all of Latin America, and all troops on their
way to Africa pass through Puerto Rico. The island is also home to the
elite components of the U.S. military such as the Green Berets, Navy
Seals, Air Force Commandos, etc.

In short, Puerto Rico is central to U.S. military domination of Latin
America and plays a major role in the global strategies of the U.S.

This one-day seminar will address the informational needs of activists
in solidarity work with the national liberation struggle as well as
activists in the Puerto Rican community and anti-war movement.

Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
________________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York

PRESERVING THE MEMORY OF DR. PEDRO ALBIZU CAMPOS

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York are fundraising in the effort
to renovate and preserve the tomb of Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos. The tomb needs
immediate repairs. Funds raised will help for services to maintain the
upkeep of the tomb and contribute towards placing an appropriate monument in
honor of Puerto Rico�s national hero. Also, funds will be used to pay for
travel expenses for volunteers of the Nationalist Youth who will also be
participating in the commemoration of El Grito de Lares, Sept. 23, 2003.

For more information about the tomb or
the trip to Lares, please call
(646) 283-6253 or send an email to Tato at
tatobrujo@... or Dennis at
bosefod@....

To contribute, please send check or money
order to:

Fundacion Andres Figueroa Cordero
Att: Don Pedro�s Tomb
P.O. Box 1570
Bronx, NY 10459

__________________________________________________________________________________
To my dear friends,

This September 11, 2003 commemorates not only the
attack on the Twin Towers in 2001, but also another
bloody and "terrorist" event in history, and one that
also impacted me personally.

This September 11th, 2003 commemorates 30 years since
the military dictatorship under Augusto Pinochet took
over in a bloody coup in Chile. This September 11th
commemorates the death of Salvador Allende, elected by
the people, and left with no option but to commit
suicide while defending the National Palace.

This September 11th commemorates the three years my
father spent in prison and torture during the first
years of the dictatorship. This September 11th
commemorates the several years of imprisonment and
torture of my aunt and uncle, Nieves Ayress and Victor
Toro. This September 11th commemorates our familes
political exile and the wounds that still heal.

This September 11th commemorates the thousands of
Chileans, who died at the hands of torture, and in
prison camps, and the "disappeared" companeros whose
bodies are still being found today. This September
11th commemorates a Chile that continues with a
constitution set up by the military and a "socialist"
government that governs with murderers, forgives the
past, and opens Chile to the "world market."
This September 11th commemorates a CIA and US
government that were directly involved in the military
coup and destabilization of the Allende government.

This September 11th we commemorate the human rights
groups, the FUNA's (denouncement of torturers), the
youth groups, the labor groups, the indigenous
Mapuches that continue resisting.
This September 11th we commemorate the struggle that
still continues....

I would like to invite you to several events for the
30th Anniversary of the death of Salvador Allende and
the 30 years of struggle.

Sincerely,

Marcelo Venegas-Pizarro, MD


---------------------------------------

empanadas, wine, cultural night, music, t-shirts

FRIDAY, AUGUST 29th, 2003
8:00PM
*CASA DE MARGOT (Margot's house)
534 E. 11st. Apt. #9
(Between Ave. A and B)

info: 212-674-3456 / suggested donation $25

The Battle of Chile, Part II
7:30PM
122 W. 27th St., 10th floor
---------------------------------------
Thursday, September 11th, 2003

Brecht Forum / Exhibit Opening
Poster and Artwork from Chile's Popular Unity Period
5:30PM
122 W. 27th St., 10th floor
----------------------------------------

Saturday, September 13th, 2003

*Official Event of the 30th Anniversary
"History is not detained by repression or death"
Invited guests:
Ramsey Clark, former US Attorney General
Family Members of Rodrigo Rojas Denegri (Chilean youth
killed by burns from being doused with gasoline after
a protest in Chile)Family members of Orlando Letelier,
Frank Terrugi, Charles Homann, Boris Weisfeiler.
Ex-political prisoners: Victor Toro, Nieves Ayress
Margot Olavarria, Marcelo Venegas

Cultural performance by Luisa Ankamil and the Condor
Pasa Group.

International Action Center
39 W. 14th St. 2nd Flr
Room 206
(Between 5th and 6th Ave.)

------------------------------------------
Sunday, September 14th, 2003

*Popular Mass in honor of those fallen in the struggle
in Chile

San Romero Church
Mass led by Father Luis Barrios

2410 Amsterdam Ave. 4th Flr.
(Between 179th and 180 St)

*All of the work for the 30th Anniversary will be
dedicated to the Venezuelan Bolivarian Revolution.

Post ID:3296
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-31 10:56:12
Subject:SUPPORT JERICHO SEPT. 7TH
Message:

Join the Jericho Movement on Sunday September 7th, 2003 for a Special 
Planning Meeting for an International Human Rights Conference/Demonstration 
in 2004!!

The Jericho Movement is calling on all people to join together to organize a 
powerful International Human Rights Weekend from Dec. 10th-12th in the year 
2004!!  This conference will culminate with a powerful mobilization on 
Sunday Dec. 12th to the United Nations!!

We need all people to come and make this activity a reality!!  PLease come 
ready to take on tasks and support in any way you can!! THis activity will 
be potluck, we are asking folks to bring some food to share or beverages!!

IN memory of our beloved Sister Safiya Bukhari, who dedicated her life to 
Jericho, please come out and continue the work she held so dear!!  The work 
that was her life's goal: FREEDOM AND LIBERATION!!

Join us as we discuss conference topics such as:

US Held Political Prisoners/POWs
Native American Human Rights
US Militarism in the Philippines/Puerto Rico
Women�s Rights
Palestine and the Detainees
International PPs/POWs
LGBTTS Human Rights and more...

Sunday Sept. 7th, 2003 at 3pm at
Freedom Hall, 113 West 128th Street
Freedom Hall Directions: Freedom Hall is on West 128th St. in Harlem between 
Malcolm X/Lenox & Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvds. Subways #2 or 3 to 125th 
St. 4, 5 or 6 to 125th St. & walk west 4 blocks A, B, C or D to 125th St. & 
walk east 3 blocks

For more information please contact 718-220-6004/718-601-4751
http://www.politicalprisoners.us

_________________________________________________________________
MSN 8: Get 6 months for $9.95/month http://join.msn.com/?page=dept/dialup

The September 27 Welcoming Committee Invites You
To Join The Friends Of Cuba
Saturday, September 27, 2003
To Welcome
Felipe P�rez Roque
Cuba�s Minister Of Foreign Relations
[Location To Be Announced]

Dear Friends:

September 16, 2003, marks the opening session of the 58th United Nations 
General Assembly in New York City. On September 27, 2003, the friends of 
Cuba are organizing a peoples� welcome for Cuba�s Minister of Foreign 
Relations, Felipe P�rez Roque.

This will be an important occasion for Cuba�s friends to become aware and 
informed of the latest developments in U.S.-Cuba relations, Cuba�s 
assessment of the international situation, the campaign to free the Cuban 5 
currently held in U.S. federal penitentiaries, and the travel challenges 
which have taken place this year.  These and other issues of relevant to our 
work in support Cuba, ending the U.S. blockade and support the Cuban 5 will 
be addressed.

Many of you and/or your organizations were key to a very successful 
celebration of the 50th Anniversary of Moncada, recently held in New York 
City at the Martin Luther King Labor Center.  The friends of Cuba are 
confident that we can have another major event for Cuba on September 27th.

Your endorsement now and your financial support through donations, in-kind 
contributions, participation in the September 27th Welcoming Committee, 
and/or an ad in the September 27th Journal, will go along way in making this 
expression of our support for Cuba another resounding success.

Please fill out the information requested below and forward this 
information. Time is short and your prompt response and help is greatly 
appreciated.

The September 27th Welcoming Committee
August 28, 2003

ENDORSEMENT INFORMATION

What we really need is your support and input in the organizing process. 
Please take the time to complete the form below, it will make a difference 
in the quality of our organizing efforts for September 27th.

Organization:
Contact:
Address:
City/State/Zip Code
Telephone:
Fax:
E-mail:

Give name of organization/person as it should appear on endorsement list:


JOURNAL INFORMATION

The September 27th Journal will be distributed the day of the event. Space 
rates for the journal are as follows:

Full Page:  $200  - (7.5 by 10 inches)
Half Page: $100  -  (7.5 by 4.75 inches)
Quarter Page: $50 - (3.5 by 4.75 inches)
Business Card: $35 - (3.5 by 2 inches)
12 Word Greeting: - $25

Yes, my organization will place an ad in the journal:

Please indicate size & dollar amount of ad:

Each organization is responsible for text and graphics.  All ads should be 
mailed in its original format (especially those with graphics) with a check 
in the correct amount payable to IFCO/September 27th Welcoming Committee, 
402 West 145th Street, New York, New York 10031

Note: Once we recieve your information for endorsement and for the journal 
ad, you will be contacted by the committee working on the ad if any further 
information is needed.  You will also recieve an e-mail and format to use in 
the event you choose to send a camera-ready ad by e-mail.

ENDORSERS (list in formation):

_________________________________________________________________________________

New York Forum With Visiting Delegation Of The Socialist Front of Puerto
Rico

Saturday, August 30, 2003
12 Noon
St. Mary's Episcopal Church
521 West 126th Street, Manhattan
Between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue
New York City
IRT #1 and # 9 7th Avenue subway Trains To 125th Street

The Current Political/Social Reality In Puerto Rico
Presentations will include the situation facing the workers
movement, the struggle in the electrical energy sector, the
constituent assembly, perspectives on the Vieques struggle, the
potential closing of the Roosevelt Road military base, the
student movement, repression against the independence and
socialist movements in Puerto Rico.

Jorge Farinacci, Spokesperson, Socialist Front
The Student/Youth Movement In Puerto Rico
Karen Vega, Spokesperson, Socialist Front

Work/Activity Reports Of The
Working Group Of The Socialsit Front In New York
Frank Velgara, Carlos Rovira, Benjamin Ramos, Ricardo Gabriel
And others.

Invitation Extended By:
The Socialist Front of Puerto Rico
The Working Group of the Socialist Front in New York

For More Information:
(718)601-4751
(212)749-8024
________________________________________________________________________________

After the Vieques Victory How Does Puerto Rico
Fit Into US Strategies for Global Domination?

Saturday, September 20
The Brecht Forum
122 West 27th Street - 10th Floor
Between 6th and 7th Avenue, Manhattan, New York City
10:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.
1-Day Seminar

Sponsored by the Vieques Support Campaign & the Brecht Forum.

Jorge Farinacci, Ismael Guadalupe & Others To Be Announced.

Why would the U.S. close down a base when its war machine is revved up
at an all time high?

On May 1, 2003, after years of worldwide protest, the U.S. Navy halted
the bombing of Vieques-at least for now. But the U.S. has neither
relinquished it to the people of Vieques or addressed the urgently
needed decontamination of the island after 63 years of constant naval
target practice.

The fact is that Vieques is only the tip of the military "iceberg" in
Puerto Rico. The pentagon controls 14% of the entire Puerto Rican
territory. There are 109 U.S. military bases and facilities in Puerto
Rico of which Fort Buchanan and Roosevelt Roads are the largest.
Puerto Rico houses 80% of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes
the invasion forces for all of Latin America, and all troops on their
way to Africa pass through Puerto Rico. The island is also home to the
elite components of the U.S. military such as the Green Berets, Navy
Seals, Air Force Commandos, etc.

In short, Puerto Rico is central to U.S. military domination of Latin
America and plays a major role in the global strategies of the U.S.

This one-day seminar will address the informational needs of activists
in solidarity work with the national liberation struggle as well as
activists in the Puerto Rican community and anti-war movement.

Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
________________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York

PRESERVING THE MEMORY OF DR. PEDRO ALBIZU CAMPOS

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York are fundraising in the effort
to renovate and preserve the tomb of Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos. The tomb needs
immediate repairs. Funds raised will help for services to maintain the
upkeep of the tomb and contribute towards placing an appropriate monument in
honor of Puerto Rico�s national hero. Also, funds will be used to pay for
travel expenses for volunteers of the Nationalist Youth who will also be
participating in the commemoration of El Grito de Lares, Sept. 23, 2003.

For more information about the tomb or
the trip to Lares, please call
(646) 283-6253 or send an email to Tato at
tatobrujo@... or Dennis at
bosefod@....

To contribute, please send check or money
order to:

Fundacion Andres Figueroa Cordero
Att: Don Pedro�s Tomb
P.O. Box 1570
Bronx, NY 10459
________________________________________________________________________________

__________________________________________________________________________________
To my dear friends,

This September 11, 2003 commemorates not only the
attack on the Twin Towers in 2001, but also another
bloody and "terrorist" event in history, and one that
also impacted me personally.

This September 11th, 2003 commemorates 30 years since
the military dictatorship under Augusto Pinochet took
over in a bloody coup in Chile. This September 11th
commemorates the death of Salvador Allende, elected by
the people, and left with no option but to commit
suicide while defending the National Palace.

This September 11th commemorates the three years my
father spent in prison and torture during the first
years of the dictatorship. This September 11th
commemorates the several years of imprisonment and
torture of my aunt and uncle, Nieves Ayress and Victor
Toro. This September 11th commemorates our familes
political exile and the wounds that still heal.

This September 11th commemorates the thousands of
Chileans, who died at the hands of torture, and in
prison camps, and the "disappeared" companeros whose
bodies are still being found today. This September
11th commemorates a Chile that continues with a
constitution set up by the military and a "socialist"
government that governs with murderers, forgives the
past, and opens Chile to the "world market."
This September 11th commemorates a CIA and US
government that were directly involved in the military
coup and destabilization of the Allende government.

This September 11th we commemorate the human rights
groups, the FUNA's (denouncement of torturers), the
youth groups, the labor groups, the indigenous
Mapuches that continue resisting.
This September 11th we commemorate the struggle that
still continues....

I would like to invite you to several events for the
30th Anniversary of the death of Salvador Allende and
the 30 years of struggle.

Sincerely,

Marcelo Venegas-Pizarro, MD

be potluck, we are asking folks to bring some food to share or beverages!!

IN memory of our beloved Sister Safiya Bukhari, who dedicated her life to
Jericho, please come out and continue the work she held so dear!!  The work
that was her life's goal: FREEDOM AND LIBERATION!!

Join us as we discuss conference topics such as:

US Held Political Prisoners/POWs
Native American Human Rights
US Militarism in the Philippines/Puerto Rico
Women�s Rights
Palestine and the Detainees
International PPs/POWs
LGBTTS Human Rights and more...

Sunday Sept. 7th, 2003 at 3pm at
Freedom Hall, 113 West 128th Street
Freedom Hall Directions: Freedom Hall is on West 128th St. in Harlem between
Malcolm X/Lenox & Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvds. Subways #2 or 3 to 125th
St. 4, 5 or 6 to 125th St. & walk west 4 blocks A, B, C or D to 125th St. &
walk east 3 blocks

For more information please contact 718-220-6004/718-601-4751
http://www.politicalprisoners.us

Post ID:3301

Subject:SUPPORT JERICHO SEPT. 7TH
Message:

Join the Jericho Movement on Sunday September 7th, 2003 for a Special
Planning Meeting for an International Human Rights Conference/Demonstration
in 2004!!

The Jericho Movement is calling on all people to join together to organize a
powerful International Human Rights Weekend from Dec. 10th-12th in the year
2004!!  This conference will culminate with a powerful mobilization on
Sunday Dec. 12th to the United Nations!!

We need all people to come and make this activity a reality!!  PLease come
ready to take on tasks and support in any way you can!! THis activity will
be potluck, we are asking folks to bring some food to share or beverages!!

IN memory of our beloved Sister Safiya Bukhari, who dedicated her life to
Jericho, please come out and continue the work she held so dear!!  The work
that was her life's goal: FREEDOM AND LIBERATION!!

Join us as we discuss conference topics such as:

US Held Political Prisoners/POWs

The Jericho Movement is calling on all people to join together to organize a
powerful International Human Rights Weekend from Dec. 10th-12th in the year
2004!!  This conference will culminate with a powerful mobilization on
Sunday Dec. 12th to the United Nations!!

ready to take on tasks and support in any way you can!! THis activity will
be potluck, we are asking folks to bring some food to share or beverages!!

________________________________________________________________________________

After the Vieques Victory How Does Puerto Rico
Fit Into US Strategies for Global Domination?

Saturday, September 20
The Brecht Forum
122 West 27th Street - 10th Floor
Between 6th and 7th Avenue, Manhattan, New York City
10:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.
1-Day Seminar

Sponsored by the Vieques Support Campaign & the Brecht Forum.

Jorge Farinacci, Ismael Guadalupe & Others To Be Announced.

Why would the U.S. close down a base when its war machine is revved up
at an all time high?

On May 1, 2003, after years of worldwide protest, the U.S. Navy halted
the bombing of Vieques-at least for now. But the U.S. has neither
relinquished it to the people of Vieques or addressed the urgently
needed decontamination of the island after 63 years of constant naval
target practice.

The fact is that Vieques is only the tip of the military "iceberg" in
Puerto Rico. The pentagon controls 14% of the entire Puerto Rican
territory. There are 109 U.S. military bases and facilities in Puerto
Rico of which Fort Buchanan and Roosevelt Roads are the largest.
Puerto Rico houses 80% of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes
the invasion forces for all of Latin America, and all troops on their
way to Africa pass through Puerto Rico. The island is also home to the
elite components of the U.S. military such as the Green Berets, Navy
Seals, Air Force Commandos, etc.

In short, Puerto Rico is central to U.S. military domination of Latin
America and plays a major role in the global strategies of the U.S.

This one-day seminar will address the informational needs of activists
in solidarity work with the national liberation struggle as well as
activists in the Puerto Rican community and anti-war movement.

Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
________________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York

PRESERVING THE MEMORY OF DR. PEDRO ALBIZU CAMPOS

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York are fundraising in the effort
to renovate and preserve the tomb of Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos. The tomb needs
immediate repairs. Funds raised will help for services to maintain the
upkeep of the tomb and contribute towards placing an appropriate monument in
honor of Puerto Rico�s national hero. Also, funds will be used to pay for
travel expenses for volunteers of the Nationalist Youth who will also be
participating in the commemoration of El Grito de Lares, Sept. 23, 2003.

For more information about the tomb or
the trip to Lares, please call
(646) 283-6253 or send an email to Tato at
tatobrujo@... or Dennis at
bosefod@....

To contribute, please send check or money
order to:

Fundacion Andres Figueroa Cordero
Att: Don Pedro�s Tomb
P.O. Box 1570
Bronx, NY 10459
________________________________________________________________________________


Report Back from CUBA
first hand accounts of our trip to Cuba
Speakers:
� N.Y. delegation of US-Cuba Youth Exchange,
� Venceremos brigada,
� Pastors for Peace,
� Luis Miranda

Wednesday, Sept 10th, 2003
6:30 - 8:00pm
Hunter College
Thomas Building Rm 105
(next to North Bldg)
Lexington Ave bet 68th and 69th

Co-Sponsors: Casa De Las Americas and NY-Cuban Solidarity Network

Cubaexchange@...
http://cubaexchange.8m.com
________________________________________________________________________________

La Junta del Partido Nacionalista de N.Y. INVITA a
la conmemoci�n del Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos que se
llavar� a cabo el 12 de septiembre. Aparte del acto
cultural de ese d�a, durante la actividad el mismo
sal�n donde se celebrar� el acto se va dedicar a su
memoria y de ah� en adelante se conocer� con el
apelativo del (Mestro) permanente- mente. Al mismo
tiempo, se exhibiran varios trabajos artisticos con
su imagen.

El futuro sal�n del (Maestro) queda en el 700 de
Elton Avenue del Bronx, una cuadra a mano izquierda
de la 3ra. entre calle 154 y 155, 2do piso. El acto
comienza a las 6:30 P.M. Participar�n los Pleneros


de la 21. Auspiciados por Yerbabuena. El Rev. Luis
Barrios. vicario de la iglesia San Romero de las
Am�ricas bendecir� el lugar. Juan Roure Marrero y
"Prisionera" dir�n algunos poemas y tambi�n se
ense�ar� el video ALBIZU VIVE.

Para m�s informaci�n favor de llamar a los
siguientes Tel�fonos.
Cel. 646-337-6775 (Ponce)
646-361-5312 y 718-328-8291 (Bomex�)

Transportaci�n: Trenes 5 y 2, hasta la 149 y 3ra.
Ave. Si no quiere caminar puede cojer la guaguas
hasta la 154 y 3ra.

________________________________________________________________________________

To my dear friends,

This September 11, 2003 commemorates not only the
attack on the Twin Towers in 2001, but also another
bloody and "terrorist" event in history, and one that
also impacted me personally.

This September 11th, 2003 commemorates 30 years since
the military dictatorship under Augusto Pinochet took
over in a bloody coup in Chile. This September 11th
commemorates the death of Salvador Allende, elected by
the people, and left with no option but to commit
suicide while defending the National Palace.

This September 11th commemorates the three years my
father spent in prison and torture during the first
years of the dictatorship. This September 11th
commemorates the several years of imprisonment and
torture of my aunt and uncle, Nieves Ayress and Victor
Toro. This September 11th commemorates our familes
political exile and the wounds that still heal.

This September 11th commemorates the thousands of
Chileans, who died at the hands of torture, and in
prison camps, and the "disappeared" companeros whose
bodies are still being found today. This September
11th commemorates a Chile that continues with a
constitution set up by the military and a "socialist"
government that governs with murderers, forgives the
past, and opens Chile to the "world market."
This September 11th commemorates a CIA and US
government that were directly involved in the military
coup and destabilization of the Allende government.

This September 11th we commemorate the human rights
groups, the FUNA's (denouncement of torturers), the
youth groups, the labor groups, the indigenous
Mapuches that continue resisting.
This September 11th we commemorate the struggle that
still continues....

I would like to invite you to several events for the
30th Anniversary of the death of Salvador Allende and
the 30 years of struggle.

Sincerely,

Marcelo Venegas-Pizarro, MD


---------------------------------------

****FUNDRAISER DINNER PARTY****
empanadas, wine, cultural night, music, t-shirts

FRIDAY, AUGUST 29th, 2003
8:00PM
*CASA DE MARGOT (Margot's house)
534 E. 11st. Apt. #9
(Between Ave. A and B)
Train L to 1st Ave station.
info: 212-674-3456 / suggested donation $25

---------------------------------------
Monday, September 8th, 2003

Brecht Forum / Film
The Battle of Chile, Part II
7:30PM
122 W. 27th St., 10th floor
---------------------------------------
Thursday, September 11th, 2003

Brecht Forum / Exhibit Opening
Poster and Artwork from Chile's Popular Unity Period
5:30PM
122 W. 27th St., 10th floor
----------------------------------------

Saturday, September 13th, 2003

*Official Event of the 30th Anniversary
"History is not detained by repression or death"
Invited guests:
Ramsey Clark, former US Attorney General
Family Members of Rodrigo Rojas Denegri (Chilean youth
killed by burns from being doused with gasoline after
a protest in Chile)Family members of Orlando Letelier,
Frank Terrugi, Charles Homann, Boris Weisfeiler.
Ex-political prisoners: Victor Toro, Nieves Ayress
Margot Olavarria, Marcelo Venegas

Cultural performance by Luisa Ankamil and the Condor
Pasa Group.

International Action Center
39 W. 14th St. 2nd Flr
Room 206
(Between 5th and 6th Ave.)

------------------------------------------
Sunday, September 14th, 2003

*Popular Mass in honor of those fallen in the struggle
in Chile

San Romero Church
Mass led by Father Luis Barrios

2410 Amsterdam Ave. 4th Flr.
(Between 179th and 180 St)
-------------------------------------------

*All of the work for the 30th Anniversary will be
dedicated to the Venezuelan Bolivarian Revolution.

To my dear friends,

This September 11, 2003 commemorates not only the
attack on the Twin Towers in 2001, but also another
bloody and "terrorist" event in history, and one that
also impacted me personally.

This September 11th, 2003 commemorates 30 years since
the military dictatorship under Augusto Pinochet took
over in a bloody coup in Chile. This September 11th
commemorates the death of Salvador Allende, elected by
the people, and left with no option but to commit
suicide while defending the National Palace.

This September 11th commemorates the three years my
father spent in prison and torture during the first
years of the dictatorship. This September 11th
commemorates the several years of imprisonment and
torture of my aunt and uncle, Nieves Ayress and Victor
Toro. This September 11th commemorates our familes
political exile and the wounds that still heal.

This September 11th commemorates the thousands of
Chileans, who died at the hands of torture, and in
prison camps, and the "disappeared" companeros whose
bodies are still being found today. This September
11th commemorates a Chile that continues with a
constitution set up by the military and a "socialist"
government that governs with murderers, forgives the
past, and opens Chile to the "world market."
This September 11th commemorates a CIA and US
government that were directly involved in the military
coup and destabilization of the Allende government.

This September 11th we commemorate the human rights
groups, the FUNA's (denouncement of torturers), the
youth groups, the labor groups, the indigenous
Mapuches that continue resisting.
This September 11th we commemorate the struggle that
still continues....

I would like to invite you to several events for the
30th Anniversary of the death of Salvador Allende and
the 30 years of struggle.

Sincerely,

Marcelo Venegas-Pizarro, MD

Report Back from CUBA
first hand accounts of our trip to Cuba
Speakers:
� N.Y. delegation of US-Cuba Youth Exchange,
� Venceremos brigada,
� Pastors for Peace,
� Luis Miranda

Wednesday, Sept 10th, 2003
6:30 - 8:00pm
Hunter College
Thomas Building Rm 105
(next to North Bldg)
Lexington Ave bet 68th and 69th

Co-Sponsors: Casa De Las Americas and NY-Cuban Solidarity Network

Cubaexchange@...
http://cubaexchange.8m.com
