________________________________________________________________________________

To my dear friends,

This September 11, 2003 commemorates not only the
attack on the Twin Towers in 2001, but also another
bloody and "terrorist" event in history, and one that
also impacted me personally.

This September 11th, 2003 commemorates 30 years since
the military dictatorship under Augusto Pinochet took
over in a bloody coup in Chile. This September 11th
commemorates the death of Salvador Allende, elected by
the people, and left with no option but to commit
suicide while defending the National Palace.

This September 11th commemorates the three years my
father spent in prison and torture during the first
years of the dictatorship. This September 11th
commemorates the several years of imprisonment and
torture of my aunt and uncle, Nieves Ayress and Victor
Toro. This September 11th commemorates our familes
political exile and the wounds that still heal.

This September 11th commemorates the thousands of
Chileans, who died at the hands of torture, and in
prison camps, and the "disappeared" companeros whose
bodies are still being found today. This September
11th commemorates a Chile that continues with a
constitution set up by the military and a "socialist"
government that governs with murderers, forgives the
past, and opens Chile to the "world market."
This September 11th commemorates a CIA and US
government that were directly involved in the military
coup and destabilization of the Allende government.

This September 11th we commemorate the human rights
groups, the FUNA's (denouncement of torturers), the
youth groups, the labor groups, the indigenous
Mapuches that continue resisting.
This September 11th we commemorate the struggle that
still continues....

I would like to invite you to several events for the
30th Anniversary of the death of Salvador Allende and
the 30 years of struggle.

Sincerely,

Marcelo Venegas-Pizarro, MD


---------------------------------------

killed by burns from being doused with gasoline after
a protest in Chile)Family members of Orlando Letelier,
Frank Terrugi, Charles Homann, Boris Weisfeiler.

Margot Olavarria, Marcelo Venegas

Pasa Group.

Post ID:3305

Subject:Updated ProLibertad Digest
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is asking folks to support and foward out
the following activities throughout the City!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
ProLibertad@...
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 2123-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
________________________________________________________________________________

After the Vieques Victory How Does Puerto Rico
Fit Into US Strategies for Global Domination?

Saturday, September 20
The Brecht Forum
122 West 27th Street - 10th Floor
Between 6th and 7th Avenue, Manhattan, New York City
10:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.
1-Day Seminar

Sponsored by the Vieques Support Campaign & the Brecht Forum.

Jorge Farinacci, Ismael Guadalupe & Others To Be Announced.

Why would the U.S. close down a base when its war machine is revved up
at an all time high?

On May 1, 2003, after years of worldwide protest, the U.S. Navy halted
the bombing of Vieques-at least for now. But the U.S. has neither
relinquished it to the people of Vieques or addressed the urgently
needed decontamination of the island after 63 years of constant naval
target practice.

The fact is that Vieques is only the tip of the military "iceberg" in
Puerto Rico. The pentagon controls 14% of the entire Puerto Rican
territory. There are 109 U.S. military bases and facilities in Puerto
Rico of which Fort Buchanan and Roosevelt Roads are the largest.
Puerto Rico houses 80% of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes
the invasion forces for all of Latin America, and all troops on their
way to Africa pass through Puerto Rico. The island is also home to the
elite components of the U.S. military such as the Green Berets, Navy
Seals, Air Force Commandos, etc.

In short, Puerto Rico is central to U.S. military domination of Latin
America and plays a major role in the global strategies of the U.S.

This one-day seminar will address the informational needs of activists
in solidarity work with the national liberation struggle as well as
activists in the Puerto Rican community and anti-war movement.

Suggested donation: $6/$8/$10
________________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York

PRESERVING THE MEMORY OF DR. PEDRO ALBIZU CAMPOS

The Puerto Rican Nationalist Youth of New York are fundraising in the effort
to renovate and preserve the tomb of Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos. The tomb needs
immediate repairs. Funds raised will help for services to maintain the
upkeep of the tomb and contribute towards placing an appropriate monument in
honor of Puerto Rico�s national hero. Also, funds will be used to pay for
travel expenses for volunteers of the Nationalist Youth who will also be
participating in the commemoration of El Grito de Lares, Sept. 23, 2003.

For more information about the tomb or
the trip to Lares, please call
(646) 283-6253 or send an email to Tato at
tatobrujo@... or Dennis at
bosefod@....

To contribute, please send check or money
order to:

Fundacion Andres Figueroa Cordero
Att: Don Pedro�s Tomb
P.O. Box 1570
Bronx, NY 10459
________________________________________________________________________________

� N.Y. delegation of US-Cuba Youth Exchange,

To my dear friends,

This September 11, 2003 commemorates not only the
attack on the Twin Towers in 2001, but also another
bloody and "terrorist" event in history, and one that
also impacted me personally.

This September 11th, 2003 commemorates 30 years since
the military dictatorship under Augusto Pinochet took
over in a bloody coup in Chile. This September 11th
commemorates the death of Salvador Allende, elected by
the people, and left with no option but to commit
suicide while defending the National Palace.

This September 11th commemorates the three years my
father spent in prison and torture during the first
years of the dictatorship. This September 11th
commemorates the several years of imprisonment and
torture of my aunt and uncle, Nieves Ayress and Victor
Toro. This September 11th commemorates our familes
political exile and the wounds that still heal.

This September 11th commemorates the thousands of
Chileans, who died at the hands of torture, and in
prison camps, and the "disappeared" companeros whose
bodies are still being found today. This September
11th commemorates a Chile that continues with a
constitution set up by the military and a "socialist"
government that governs with murderers, forgives the
past, and opens Chile to the "world market."
This September 11th commemorates a CIA and US
government that were directly involved in the military
coup and destabilization of the Allende government.

This September 11th we commemorate the human rights
groups, the FUNA's (denouncement of torturers), the
youth groups, the labor groups, the indigenous
Mapuches that continue resisting.
This September 11th we commemorate the struggle that
still continues....

I would like to invite you to several events for the
30th Anniversary of the death of Salvador Allende and
the 30 years of struggle.

Sincerely,

Marcelo Venegas-Pizarro, MD

Post ID:3306
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 10:05:33
Subject:Vieques Political Prisoners
Message:

Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
PO Box 1424          Vieques, Puerto Rico  00765
Tel.  787 741-0716   Fax  741-0358   E mail:  bieke@...
http://www.prorescatevieques.org             
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/bieke_pr/

10 September, 2003
Special Report from the Vieques Peace and Justice Camp

CURRENT SITUATION OF ARRESTED FOR MAY FIRST ACTIONS ON VIEQUES

Warm greetings from Vieques.  The ten Viequenses arrested by the FBI in June 
and accused of conspiracy and damage to federal property in relation to 
events here last May first, following suggestions of their lawyers, entered 
into agreements with federal attorneys to avoid application of mandatory 5 
to 20 year sentences against several of the accused.  Ex president of the 
Puerto Rico Federation of Teachers, Jes�s Delgado also followed this 
recommendation.  The trial against Jose P�rez, laborer from Ponce and the 
only one of the twelve accused who decided to go to trial, began Monday, 
September 8th and should finish this same week.  We urge all those in 
solidarity with the Vieques cause to support Jos� and all the accused for 
the May First events.

On 5 September, Jos� V�lez Acosta turned himself in at the Federal Court.  
V�lez is on the FBI list of those of accused but in June when the other 
eleven were arrested  he was in the neighboring island of St. Croix, where 
part of his family lives.  He is being detained at the federal prison at 
Guaynabo pending conversations between his lawyer and federal attorneys.  
Letters can be sent to Jos� at:  MDC Guaynabo, PO Box 2147  SJ, PR  
00922-2147.  His prisoner number - that must be written after his name on 
the envelope - is 23883-069.

On 4 December, Judge Fust� will dictate sentences of the Viequenses.  
Information available on the expected sentences is as follows:  Jorge Cruz 
(21 mos. prison), Jos� Monta�ez Sanes (24 mos. prison), Heriberto Hern�ndez 
(4 mos. prison), Jes�s Delgado (6 mos. house arrest and 1 yr. probation), 
Nilda Medina (1 yr. probation), N�stor de Jes�s (6 mos. house arrest, 2 yrs. 
probation), Osvald Skerret (2 yrs. probation, 6 mos. house arrest), William 
Mir� (1 yr. probation), Manuel P�rez (1 yr. probation), Andy Santiago (1yr. 
probation).

The Viequenses accused and their families express their gratitude for the 
work and sacrifice by lawyers:  Linda Backiel, Mar�a Sandoval; Judith 
Berkan, Peter Berkowitz; Luis Guzm�n; Enrique Juli�; Jorge Luis Armenteros; 
Juan Matos Bonet; Juan Matos de Juan, Pedro Varela, Edgar Vega Pab�n, Ferm�n 
Arraiza.

Attorney Taina Moscoso, of the Puerto Rico Bar Association's Special 
Commision on Vieques, together with lawyer Jos�e Pantojas of the Committee 
in Support of the Vieques Accused for May First, have made great efforts to 
coordinate meetings and movement of information between lawyers, accused and 
families.  On Saturday, 6 September, the CSVAMay 1st held a successful radio 
marathon in which 20 thousand dollars was raised to help with legal and 
other costs for accused and family members.  Those interested in helping can 
send donations to:

Committee in Support of the Vieques Accused for May First
PO Box 191792        San Juan, Puerto Rico  00919-1792

Donations can also be deposited directily the Banco Popular account
Banco Popular   #  116-26767-4.


THE STRUGGLE CONTINUES!
DECONTAMINATION AND RETURN OF OUR LANDS, NOW!


Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
PO Box 1424          Vieques, Puerto Rico  00765
Tel.  787 741-0716   Fax  741-0358   E mail:  bieke@...
http://www.prorescatevieques.org              
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/bieke_pr/

9 September, 2003
Press Release

Viequenses in solidarity with Jos� P�rez, accused for May First acts in 
Vieques

The Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques (CRDV) expressed 
solidarity with Jos� P�rez, worker from Ponce accused for events on May 
First in Vieques, whose trial began yesterday in the Federal Court.  �We are 
in solidarity with Jos� and all those accused for May First actions because 
they are not criminals,� said leaders of the Vieques group.  The charges 
against Jos� carry sentences of five to twenty years in jail.  Members of 
the CRDV said the sentences are disproportionate to the events of that 
night.

Jos� P�rez exemplifies the thousands of Puerto Rican men and women who made 
great sacrifices in favor of the people of Vieques and �... now its our turn 
to show solidarity with him�, said members of the CRDV.

According to spokespersons for the community group, the actions of May First 
� the destruction of a guard kiosk and the burning of vehicles � were not 
motivated by mallice or criminal intent but by the strong emotions of that 
historic moment that marked the end of sixty years of bombing and abuses by 
the Navy in Vieques.

Jos� P�rez was arrested on two occasions during the past four years for 
civil disobedience in support of peace on Vieques.  We urge all those in 
solidarity with the Vieques cause to show support for Jos�.

Contact:  Robert Rabin  375-0525

10 September, 2003
Special Report from the Vieques Peace and Justice Camp

CURRENT SITUATION OF ARRESTED FOR MAY FIRST ACTIONS ON VIEQUES

Warm greetings from Vieques.  The ten Viequenses arrested by the FBI in June
and accused of conspiracy and damage to federal property in relation to
events here last May first, following suggestions of their lawyers, entered
into agreements with federal attorneys to avoid application of mandatory 5
to 20 year sentences against several of the accused.  Ex president of the
Puerto Rico Federation of Teachers, Jes�s Delgado also followed this
recommendation.  The trial against Jose P�rez, laborer from Ponce and the
only one of the twelve accused who decided to go to trial, began Monday,
September 8th and should finish this same week.  We urge all those in
solidarity with the Vieques cause to support Jos� and all the accused for
the May First events.

On 5 September, Jos� V�lez Acosta turned himself in at the Federal Court.
V�lez is on the FBI list of those of accused but in June when the other
eleven were arrested  he was in the neighboring island of St. Croix, where
part of his family lives.  He is being detained at the federal prison at
Guaynabo pending conversations between his lawyer and federal attorneys.
Letters can be sent to Jos� at:  MDC Guaynabo, PO Box 2147  SJ, PR
00922-2147.  His prisoner number - that must be written after his name on
the envelope - is 23883-069.

On 4 December, Judge Fust� will dictate sentences of the Viequenses.
Information available on the expected sentences is as follows:  Jorge Cruz
(21 mos. prison), Jos� Monta�ez Sanes (24 mos. prison), Heriberto Hern�ndez
(4 mos. prison), Jes�s Delgado (6 mos. house arrest and 1 yr. probation),
Nilda Medina (1 yr. probation), N�stor de Jes�s (6 mos. house arrest, 2 yrs.
probation), Osvald Skerret (2 yrs. probation, 6 mos. house arrest), William
Mir� (1 yr. probation), Manuel P�rez (1 yr. probation), Andy Santiago (1yr.
probation).

The Viequenses accused and their families express their gratitude for the
work and sacrifice by lawyers:  Linda Backiel, Mar�a Sandoval; Judith
Berkan, Peter Berkowitz; Luis Guzm�n; Enrique Juli�; Jorge Luis Armenteros;
Juan Matos Bonet; Juan Matos de Juan, Pedro Varela, Edgar Vega Pab�n, Ferm�n
Arraiza.

Attorney Taina Moscoso, of the Puerto Rico Bar Association's Special
Commision on Vieques, together with lawyer Jos�e Pantojas of the Committee
in Support of the Vieques Accused for May First, have made great efforts to
coordinate meetings and movement of information between lawyers, accused and
families.  On Saturday, 6 September, the CSVAMay 1st held a successful radio
marathon in which 20 thousand dollars was raised to help with legal and
other costs for accused and family members.  Those interested in helping can
send donations to:

Committee in Support of the Vieques Accused for May First
PO Box 191792        San Juan, Puerto Rico  00919-1792

Cuba Speaks For Itself
Saturday, September 27, 2003
A Public Forum With
Felipe Perez Roque, Cuba's Minister of Foreign Relations

Church Of The Intercession
Broadway @ West 155th Street
New York City
6pm
[IRT #1 & #9 subway trains to West 157th Street or "C" subway rain to
155th Street & St. Nicholas Avenue]

Information Telephone For Tickets Is: IFCO (212) 926-5757


         ___________________________________________



Dear Friends,

Time is short!  We need your organizational donation to complete the
event for Felipe Prez Roque. Cuba's Minister Of Foreign Relations
will speak on Saturday, September 27, 2003 at the Church of the
Intercession, Broadway and 155th St. in Manhattan.

The Welcoming Committee wants to meet the expenses of organizing this
event and still keep the ticket cost low!

Your financial support is critical for making this event a success.
Every sponsoring organization has pledged to financially support this
event to the best of their ability. We are asking that you make a
donation of $50 or $100.00 as quickly as possible!  Individual
donations are also welcome. Your prompt response is greatly
appreciated! If your organization has already made its contribution
thank you!

This is an important opportunity for Cuba's friends to demonstrate
their solidarity with Cuba and learn about the latest developments in
US-Cuba relations, Cuba's assessment of the international situation,
the campaign to free the Cuban 5 held in U.S. federal penitentiaries,
and the travel challenges which have taken place this year.

ENDORSEMENT INFORMATION

Organization:
Contact:
Address:
City/State/Zip Code Telephone:
Fax: E-mail:
Amount of Contribution   $________________________
(Checks to be made out to IFCO, our fiscal sponsor, with a notation
"September 27th Welcoming Committee")

IFCO has set up a special telephone line equipped with an answering
machine for where you can leave messages and updates about your
contribution:  212. 926.2730.


Name of organization/person as it should appear on endorsement list

_____________________________________________________

______________________________________________________

If your organization can also afford a journal ad, that would be great!
Information about the journal ad prices are below.


Yours in Solidarity,
The September 27th Welcoming Committee
September 13, 2003



JOURNAL INFORMATION

The September 27th Journal will be distributed the day of the event.
Space rates for the journal are as follows:

Full Page: $200 - (7.5 by 10 inches)
Half Page: $100 - (7.5 by 4.75 inches)
Quarter Page: $50 - (3.5 by 4.75 inches)
Business Card: $35 - (3.5 by 2 inches)
12 Word Greeting: - $25

Please indicate size & dollar amount of ad: ____________________

Each organization is responsible for text and graphics. All ads should
be mailed in its original format (especially those with graphics) with
a check in the correct amount payable to IFCO/September 27th Welcoming
Committee, 402 West 145th Street, New York, New York 10031. Emailed
ads should be addressed to lucia.igc.org

Note: Once we receive your information for endorsement and for the
journal ad, you will be contacted by the committee working on the ad
if any further information is needed. You will also receive an e-mail
and format to use in the event you choose to send a camera-ready ad by
    e-mail.

ENDORSERS (list in formation):

Rev. Luis Barrios, Ph.d, John Jay College*
Elombe Brath, Afrikaleidoscope, WBAI
Brecht Forum
Casa de Las Americas
Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador (CISPES)
Committee in Solidarity with Venezuela
Cuba Solidarity New York
December 12 Movement
Dominican Friends of Cuba
Harlem Tenants Council
IFCO/Pastors For Peace
Iglesia San Romero de las Americas
International Action Center
International Concerned Family and Friends of Mumia Abu-Jamal
Jericho Movement
Kangaroo Productions, Inc.
Rev. Earl Koopercamp, Saint Mary's Episcopal Church*
Movimiento la Pena del Bronx
New Jersey Network on Cuba
New York Free Mumia Abu-Jamal Coalition

Cuba Speaks For Itself
Saturday, September 27, 2003
A Public Forum With
Felipe Perez Roque, Cuba's Minister of Foreign Relations

Church Of The Intercession
Broadway @ West 155th Street
New York City
6pm
[IRT #1 & #9 subway trains to West 157th Street or "C" subway rain to
155th Street & St. Nicholas Avenue]

Information Telephone For Tickets Is: IFCO (212) 926-5757


         ___________________________________________



Dear Friends,

Time is short!  We need your organizational donation to complete the
event for Felipe Prez Roque. Cuba's Minister Of Foreign Relations
will speak on Saturday, September 27, 2003 at the Church of the
Intercession, Broadway and 155th St. in Manhattan.

The Welcoming Committee wants to meet the expenses of organizing this
event and still keep the ticket cost low!

Your financial support is critical for making this event a success.
Every sponsoring organization has pledged to financially support this
event to the best of their ability. We are asking that you make a
donation of $50 or $100.00 as quickly as possible!  Individual
donations are also welcome. Your prompt response is greatly
appreciated! If your organization has already made its contribution
thank you!

This is an important opportunity for Cuba's friends to demonstrate
their solidarity with Cuba and learn about the latest developments in
US-Cuba relations, Cuba's assessment of the international situation,
the campaign to free the Cuban 5 held in U.S. federal penitentiaries,
and the travel challenges which have taken place this year.

ENDORSEMENT INFORMATION

Organization:
Contact:
Address:
City/State/Zip Code Telephone:
Fax: E-mail:
Amount of Contribution   $________________________
(Checks to be made out to IFCO, our fiscal sponsor, with a notation
"September 27th Welcoming Committee")

IFCO has set up a special telephone line equipped with an answering
machine for where you can leave messages and updates about your
contribution:  212. 926.2730.


Name of organization/person as it should appear on endorsement list

_____________________________________________________

______________________________________________________

If your organization can also afford a journal ad, that would be great!
Information about the journal ad prices are below.


Yours in Solidarity,
The September 27th Welcoming Committee
September 13, 2003



JOURNAL INFORMATION

The September 27th Journal will be distributed the day of the event.
Space rates for the journal are as follows:

Full Page: $200 - (7.5 by 10 inches)
Half Page: $100 - (7.5 by 4.75 inches)
Quarter Page: $50 - (3.5 by 4.75 inches)
Business Card: $35 - (3.5 by 2 inches)
12 Word Greeting: - $25

Please indicate size & dollar amount of ad: ____________________

Each organization is responsible for text and graphics. All ads should
be mailed in its original format (especially those with graphics) with
a check in the correct amount payable to IFCO/September 27th Welcoming
Committee, 402 West 145th Street, New York, New York 10031. Emailed
ads should be addressed to lucia.igc.org

Note: Once we receive your information for endorsement and for the
journal ad, you will be contacted by the committee working on the ad
if any further information is needed. You will also receive an e-mail
and format to use in the event you choose to send a camera-ready ad by
    e-mail.

ENDORSERS (list in formation):

Rev. Luis Barrios, Ph.d, John Jay College*

Dear Friends,

will speak on Saturday, September 27, 2003 at the Church of the
Intercession, Broadway and 155th St. in Manhattan.

donations are also welcome. Your prompt response is greatly
appreciated! If your organization has already made its contribution
thank you!

Post ID:3311
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-22 11:13:18
Subject:Safiya Bukhari Human Rights Weekend 2004
Message:

ALL ARE WELCOMED TO JOIN THE Safiya Bukhari International Human Rights 
Weekend 2004,

The Safiya Bukhari Human Rights Weekend 2004, is an initiative started by 
several organizations in New York City that are planning a series of 
activities for International Human Rights Weekend Dec. 10th-12th, 2004.

That weekend we will be dealing with issues of Colonialism, Imperialism, 
Military Occupation, POLITICAL PRISONERS, Human Rights, and many other 
people's issues.

Our next planning meeting will be on Saturday October 4th, 2003 at 9am at 
St. Mary's Church 521 W126th St. (between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue).  
The closest trains are the 1 and 9 trains to W125th St or the A, B, C, D, to 
W125th St. and walk over to the Westside a few blocks.

We are asking folks to invite other individuals, activists and organizations 
to attend this meeting.  Remember our goal is to be inclusive and 
broad-based, we want to make sure to have as many folks involved as 
possible.

At the meeting, we will be further developing the idea of our Friday Dec. 
10th Cultural Activity and the Saturday Dec. 11th Demonstration.

For any more information contact: 718-601-4751 718-220-6004

_________________________________________________________________
Instant message in style with MSN Messenger 6.0. Download it now FREE!  
http://msnmessenger-download.com

Post ID:3315
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-03 10:41:40
Subject:Puerto Rico Update
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is asking our allies and supporters to 
attend and support the following activities and actions.  Please forward 
these messages out and please write to as many of the Political Prisoenrs as 
possible.

1. Antonio Camacho Negron turns 58 and is moved to Lewisburg
2. Support the Vieques Political Prisoners
3. Safiya Bukhari Huamn Rights Weekend 2004
4. BORICUA CONTINGENT FOR OCTOBER 25TH, 2003

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
__________________________________________________________________________________

ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON TURNS 58 YEARS YOUNG ON SATURDAY OCTOBER 4TH, 2003!!

Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho Negron was moved to a US 
Penitentiary in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania.

Antonio Camacho Negron was forced onto parole on May 2002.  He refused to 
acknowledge any parole conditions, stating that any adherence to parole 
conditions would be accepting the United States hegemony over Puerto Rico.  
Antonio  spent  over a year touring Puerto Rico, speaking at Public 
activities and demonstrations despite his parole conditions excluding him 
from such activities.

Antonio was re-arrested on April 14th, 2003 for parole violations and was 
taken to MDC Guaynabo a Federal Prison in Puerto Rico.   Antonio� s case was 
rejected by a local Puerto Rican judge, stating that his case was out of the 
judge�s jurisdiction.  Antonio remained in MDC Guaynabo until he was moved 
to Philadelphia on Tuesday August 11th, 2003, awaiting a new hearting for 
his parole violation.  He is now currently in Lewisburg and is not clear 
whether the hearing has taken place or not.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign will keep all our allies and supporters 
abreast of any updates in Antonio�s situation.  We will publish information 
as it comes to us.
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is asking all our supporters and allies to 
write to Antonio and send him commissary donations.

ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON
#03587-069
USP LEWISBURG �
RD #5, FEDERAL PRISON �
LEWISBURG, PA 17837
__________________________________________________________________________________

Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
Update on Accused for May First Actions

Friends in Solidarity with the Struggle for Peace on Vieques:

Warm greetings from Vieques. Jos� P�rez Gonzalez (#21519-069) and Jos� V�lez 
Acosta (#23883-069) are in the Federal Prison in Puerto Rico in relation to 
actions on Vieques last May first. You can write them at:
(Name and prisoner number) MDC Guaynabo P.O. Box 2147 SJ, PR 00922-2147

For a list of articles prisoners may recieve or other information about them 
call 787 749-4480

December 4 is the date set for sentencing for the twelve accused for May 
first actions. Jorge Cruz, Jos� Monta�ez Sanes and Eric Hern�ndez face 
sentences of 21, 24 and 4 months respectively. It is expected that Jos� 
P�rez and Jos� V�lez receive higher sentences. The rest of the accused - 
Jes�s Delgado, Willie Mir�, Manuel P�rez, N�stor de Jes�s, Nilda Medina, 
Andy Santiago y Osvaldo Skerret - expect to be given probation. However, at 
the moment of sentencing the judge could impose higher penalties than those 
stipulated.

We urge all people in solidarity with the Vieques cause to write these 
'compa�eros' imprisoned and to be attentive to information on the Twelve of 
Vieques.

It is very important that people write to the Vieques Political Prisoners 
and send them commissary donations:

Jos� P�rez Gonzalez #21519-069
Jos� V�lez Acosta #23883-069
MDC Guaynabo
P.O. Box 2147
SJ, PR 00922-2147
__________________________________________________________________________________

ALL ARE WELCOMED TO JOIN THE Safiya Bukhari International Human Rights 
Weekend 2004

The Safiya Bukhari Human Rights Weekend 2004, is an initiative started by
several organizations in New York City that are planning a series of
activities for International Human Rights Weekend Dec. 10th-12th, 2004.

That weekend we will be dealing with issues of Colonialism, Imperialism,
Military Occupation, POLITICAL PRISONERS, Human Rights, and many other
people's issues.

Our next planning meeting will be on Saturday October 4th, 2003 at 9am at
St. Mary's Church 521 W126th St. (between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue).
The closest trains are the 1 and 9 trains to W125th St or the A, B, C, D, to
W125th St. and walk over to the Westside a few blocks.

We are asking folks to invite other individuals, activists and organizations
to attend this meeting.  Remember our goal is to be inclusive and
broad-based, we want to make sure to have as many folks involved as
possible.

At the meeting, we will be further developing the idea of our Friday Dec.
10th Cultural Activity and the Saturday Dec. 11th Demonstration.

For any more information contact: 718-601-4751 718-220-6004
__________________________________________________________________________________

For a world free of U.S. military occupation & colonialism, from Puerto Rico 
to Iraq, ALL OUT TO DC OCTOBER 25!

Join ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, Nationalist Party of Puerto Rico
New York Committee, the Vieques Support Campaign and many others, in a
Vieques/Puerto Rico contingent at an anti-war protest in Washington,
DC on October 25th. The protest is sponsored by International
A.N.S.W.E.R. and United For Peace & Justice.

The same U.S. government responsible for the brutal occupation of the
Iraqi peoples' homeland, is also waging a campaign of reprisals
against the people of Vieques. There are 12 political defendents in
Puerto Rico facing serious charges for simply exercising their right
to celebrate with defiance, the closing of the U.S. Navy target
practice range in Vieques on May 1 of this year.

The Committee for the Rescue & Development of Vieques has called on
its supporters everywhere to protest the continued abuse of the
people of that Puerto Rican island. The abuses continue and therefore,
the struggle will continue.

The cancer and other consequences of the six decades of bombing
practices are taking its toll in the lives of the people there; U.S.
officials refuse to address the issue of decontamination and the
return of the stolen lands to the people.

The misery and destruction which Vieques continues to suffer are for
reasons none other than the lust U.S. officials have for war. Since
1941, U.S. military operations have been rehearst on the island of
Vieques, Puerto Rico.

The Puerto Rican experience confirms precisely what are U.S. motives
in Iraq - colonial domination. All out to Washington, DC on October 25
to oppose U.S. military occupation from Puerto Rico to Iraq. Join the
Vieques/Puerto Rico Contingent.

Bus Tickets for Vieques/Boricua contingent are now available.

* Price: $30
* Time: 6:30 A.M.
* Buses for the Vieques/Boricua contingent will leave from 33rd & 34th
  Streets on 8th Avenue, New York City.

For more information regarding the Vieques/Boricua contingent, please
call: (718)601-4751 (212)677-0619 (212)749-8024

_________________________________________________________________

service providers in your area). Click here.   https://broadband.msn.com

Post ID:3316
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-07 09:06:48
Subject:PRican PP Antonio Camacho Negron Moved!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is asking all of our allies and supporters 
to write to Antonio Camacho Negron and to send him a commissry donation!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
__________________________________________________________________________________

Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho Negron was moved to FCI Med. 
Allenwood.

Antonio Camacho Negron was forced onto parole on May 2002.  He refused to 
acknowledge any parole conditions, stating that any adherence to parole 
conditions would be accepting the United States hegemony over Puerto Rico.  
Antonio  spent  over a year touring Puerto Rico, speaking at Public 
activities and demonstrations despite his parole conditions excluding him 
from such activities.

Antonio was re-arrested on April 14th, 2003 for parole violations and was 
taken to MDC Guaynabo a Federal Prison in Puerto Rico.   Antonio� s case was 
rejected by a local Puerto Rican judge, stating that his case was out of the 
judge�s jurisdiction.  Antonio remained in MDC Guaynabo until he was moved 
to Philadelphia on Tuesday August 11th, 2003, then he was moved to USP 
Lewisburg, and then finally is currently in FCI Allenwood.  According to the 
Bureau of Prisons website he will be released on August 13th, 2004.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign will keep all our allies and supporters 
abreast of any updates in Antonio�s situation.  We will publish information 
as it comes to us. The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is asking all our 
supporters and allies to write to Antonio and send him commissary donations.

ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON
#03587-069
FCI MED. ALLENWOOD
P.O. BOX 2500 �
WHITE DEER , PA 17887

Post ID:3318
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-19 13:34:25
Subject:DEMAND MEDICAL TREATMENT FOR OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
Message:

Dear ProLibertad Supporters and Allies,

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is supporting the Human Rights Committee of 
Puerto Rico and the National Boricua Human Rights Network call to people to 
send letters to the Bureau of Prisons so that Oscar Lopez Rivera, a Puerto 
Rican Political Prisoner, receives the medical treatment for his bilateral 
hernias.

Oscar has been denied medical attention for over 7 months. Please read the 
press release below and the sample letter below and send one out.  Please 
pass these documents through your address books and list serves.

PLEASE HELP US IN THE CAMPAIGN TO DEMAND MEDICAL ATTENTION FOR POLITICAL 
PRISONER OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_________________________________________________________________________________


COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907
787/725-6284
PRESS RELEASE
October 16, 2003

The health and well being of Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar L�pez 
Rivera is at this moment at risk. Last March, Dr. Taude, a surgeon at USP 
Terre Haute, diagnosed bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would 
recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. 
Since that time Mr. L�pez has reported to medical staff that he has 
increasing pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still 
able to exercise vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the 
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. 
L�pez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez 
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the 
Bureau of Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We have consulted with physicians who inform us that although the hernias 
seem to be reducible, with the increasing pain, one of the two hernias might 
become stuck, which could result in a surgical emergency.

Oscar, serving a 70 year sentence, is not eligible for release until 2027. 
For more than half of his 22 years in prison, he was held in the most 
maximum security prisons in the United States in the strictest solitary 
confinement, politically punitive conditions calculated to break his will. 
Withholding needed medical care is another weapon in the government�s 
arsenal to seek this same end.

Prison officials at the maximum security United States Penitentiary at Terre 
Haute, Indiana, where he is held, seem to be using his high security status 
to delay needed medical treatment, at no small cost and risk to Oscar�s 
health and well-being. We have written in protest to the Harley G. Lappin, 
director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, and we are calling on all people 
of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be 
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined 
he needs.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:

Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, 
Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 00907, Margarita Mergal 787/732-3209
Contacts in U.S.:
National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 W. North Ave., 
Chicago, IL 60647, 773/342-8022

**********************************************************************************

Harley G. Lappin, Director
Federal Bureau of Prisons
320 First Street N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20534
Via facsimile 202/514-6878

Re: Oscar L�pez Rivera, 87651-024
USP Terre Haute

Dear Director Lappin:

In March of 2003, a surgeon at USP Terre Haute, Dr. Taude, diagnosed Mr. 
L�pez with bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would recommend to the 
Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. Since that time 
Mr. L�pez has reported to medical staff that he has increasing pain in the 
area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still able to exercise 
vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the pain. After 
enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. L�pez again saw 
Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez that he had 
recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the Bureau of 
Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.
We are concerned, based on his attorney�s consultation with qualified 
outside medical personnel, that although the hernias seem to be reducible, 
the pain is increasing, and if one of the hernias becomes stuck, the result 
could be a surgical emergency. We further understand that since he has two 
hernias, they could both be repaired at the same time so that he will have 
to recover from only one surgery, and avoiding the necessity for anesthesia 
on two occasions.

Finally, given the political nature of the acts and beliefs for which Mr. 
L�pez is in prison�fighting for the independence of Puerto Rico� we are 
concerned that prison authorities are placing an inappropriate emphasis on 
his high security status, at no small cost and risk to Mr. L�pez� health and 
well-being. We must insist that you immediately provide him with the care 
that the surgeon has already determined he needs. You can be sure that we 
will continue to monitor his situation and advocate for his human rights. 
May we please hear your response.

Sincerely yours,

_________________________________________________________________

patented spam control and more.  Get two months FREE!

Post Date/Time:2003-10-19 13:37:25
Subject:DEMAND MEDICAL TREATMENT FOR OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
Message:

Dear ProLibertad Supporters and Allies,

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is supporting the Human Rights Committee of 
Puerto Rico and the National Boricua Human Rights Network call to people to 
send letters to the Bureau of Prisons so that Oscar Lopez Rivera, a Puerto 
Rican Political Prisoner, receives the medical treatment for his bilateral 
hernias.

Oscar has been denied medical attention for over 7 months. Please read the 
press release below and the sample letter below and send one out.  Please 
pass these documents through your address books and list serves.

PLEASE HELP US IN THE CAMPAIGN TO DEMAND MEDICAL ATTENTION FOR POLITICAL 
PRISONER OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907
787/725-6284
PRESS RELEASE
October 16, 2003

The health and well being of Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar L�pez 
Rivera is at this moment at risk. Last March, Dr. Taude, a surgeon at USP 
Terre Haute, diagnosed bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would 
recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. 
Since that time Mr. L�pez has reported to medical staff that he has 
increasing pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still 
able to exercise vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the 
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. 
L�pez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez 
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the 
Bureau of Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We have consulted with physicians who inform us that although the hernias 
seem to be reducible, with the increasing pain, one of the two hernias might 
become stuck, which could result in a surgical emergency.

Oscar, serving a 70 year sentence, is not eligible for release until 2027. 
For more than half of his 22 years in prison, he was held in the most 
maximum security prisons in the United States in the strictest solitary 
confinement, politically punitive conditions calculated to break his will. 
Withholding needed medical care is another weapon in the government�s 
arsenal to seek this same end.

Prison officials at the maximum security United States Penitentiary at Terre 
Haute, Indiana, where he is held, seem to be using his high security status 
to delay needed medical treatment, at no small cost and risk to Oscar�s 
health and well-being. We have written in protest to the Harley G. Lappin, 
director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, and we are calling on all people 
of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be 
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined 
he needs.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:

Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, 
Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 00907, Margarita Mergal 787/732-3209
Contacts in U.S.:
National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 W. North Ave., 
Chicago, IL 60647, 773/342-8022

**********************************************************************************

Harley G. Lappin, Director
Federal Bureau of Prisons
320 First Street N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20534
Via facsimile 202/514-6878

Re: Oscar L�pez Rivera, 87651-024
USP Terre Haute

Dear Director Lappin:

In March of 2003, a surgeon at USP Terre Haute, Dr. Taude, diagnosed Mr. 
L�pez with bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would recommend to the 
Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. Since that time 
Mr. L�pez has reported to medical staff that he has increasing pain in the 
area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still able to exercise 
vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the pain. After 
enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. L�pez again saw 
Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez that he had 
recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the Bureau of 
Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.
We are concerned, based on his attorney�s consultation with qualified 
outside medical personnel, that although the hernias seem to be reducible, 
the pain is increasing, and if one of the hernias becomes stuck, the result 
could be a surgical emergency. We further understand that since he has two 
hernias, they could both be repaired at the same time so that he will have 
to recover from only one surgery, and avoiding the necessity for anesthesia 
on two occasions.

Finally, given the political nature of the acts and beliefs for which Mr. 
L�pez is in prison�fighting for the independence of Puerto Rico� we are 
concerned that prison authorities are placing an inappropriate emphasis on 
his high security status, at no small cost and risk to Mr. L�pez� health and 
well-being. We must insist that you immediately provide him with the care 
that the surgeon has already determined he needs. You can be sure that we 
will continue to monitor his situation and advocate for his human rights. 
May we please hear your response.

Sincerely yours,

Post ID:3320
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-22 10:38:56
Subject:Demand Medical Treatment for Oscar Lopez Rivera
Message:

Dear ProLibertad Supporters and Allies,

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is supporting the Human Rights Committee of
Puerto Rico and the National Boricua Human Rights Network call to people to
send letters to the Bureau of Prisons so that Oscar Lopez Rivera, a Puerto
Rican Political Prisoner, receives the medical treatment for his bilateral
hernias.

Oscar has been denied medical attention for over 7 months. Please read the
press release below and the sample letter below and send one out.  Please
pass these documents through your address books and list serves.

PLEASE HELP US IN THE CAMPAIGN TO DEMAND MEDICAL ATTENTION FOR POLITICAL
PRISONER OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_________________________________________________________________________________


COMIT PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Len, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907
787/725-6284
PRESS RELEASE
October 16, 2003

The health and well being of Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar Lpez
Rivera is at this moment at risk. Last March, Dr. Taude, a surgeon at USP
Terre Haute, diagnosed bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would
recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired.
Since that time Mr. Lpez has reported to medical staff that he has
increasing pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still
able to exercise vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr.
Lpez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. Lpez
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the
Bureau of Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We have consulted with physicians who inform us that although the hernias
seem to be reducible, with the increasing pain, one of the two hernias might
become stuck, which could result in a surgical emergency.

Oscar, serving a 70 year sentence, is not eligible for release until 2027.
For more than half of his 22 years in prison, he was held in the most
maximum security prisons in the United States in the strictest solitary
confinement, politically punitive conditions calculated to break his will.
Withholding needed medical care is another weapon in the governments
arsenal to seek this same end.

Prison officials at the maximum security United States Penitentiary at Terre
Haute, Indiana, where he is held, seem to be using his high security status
to delay needed medical treatment, at no small cost and risk to Oscars
health and well-being. We have written in protest to the Harley G. Lappin,
director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, and we are calling on all people
of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined
he needs.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:

Comit Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Len,
Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 00907, Margarita Mergal 787/732-3209
Contacts in U.S.:
National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 W. North Ave.,
Chicago, IL 60647, 773/342-8022

**********************************************************************************

Harley G. Lappin, Director
Federal Bureau of Prisons
320 First Street N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20534
Via facsimile 202/514-6878

Re: Oscar Lpez Rivera, 87651-024
USP Terre Haute

Dear Director Lappin:

In March of 2003, a surgeon at USP Terre Haute, Dr. Taude, diagnosed Mr.
Lpez with bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would recommend to the
Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. Since that time
Mr. Lpez has reported to medical staff that he has increasing pain in the
area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still able to exercise
vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the pain. After
enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. Lpez again saw
Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. Lpez that he had
recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the Bureau of
Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.
We are concerned, based on his attorneys consultation with qualified
outside medical personnel, that although the hernias seem to be reducible,
the pain is increasing, and if one of the hernias becomes stuck, the result
could be a surgical emergency. We further understand that since he has two
hernias, they could both be repaired at the same time so that he will have
to recover from only one surgery, and avoiding the necessity for anesthesia
on two occasions.

Finally, given the political nature of the acts and beliefs for which Mr.
Lpez is in prisonfighting for the independence of Puerto Rico we are
concerned that prison authorities are placing an inappropriate emphasis on
his high security status, at no small cost and risk to Mr. Lpez health and
well-being. We must insist that you immediately provide him with the care
that the surgeon has already determined he needs. You can be sure that we
will continue to monitor his situation and advocate for his human rights.
May we please hear your response.

Sincerely yours,

_________________________________________________________________

http://clinic.mcafee.com/clinic/ibuy/campaign.asp?cid=3963

Subject:Demand Medical Treatment for Oscar Lopez Rivera
Message:

Dear ProLibertad Supporters and Allies,

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is supporting the Human Rights Committee of
Puerto Rico and the National Boricua Human Rights Network call to people to
send letters to the Bureau of Prisons so that Oscar Lopez Rivera, a Puerto
Rican Political Prisoner, receives the medical treatment for his bilateral
hernias.

Oscar has been denied medical attention for over 7 months. Please read the
press release below and the sample letter below and send one out.  Please
pass these documents through your address books and list serves.

PLEASE HELP US IN THE CAMPAIGN TO DEMAND MEDICAL ATTENTION FOR POLITICAL
PRISONER OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_________________________________________________________________________________


COMIT PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Len, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907
787/725-6284
PRESS RELEASE
October 16, 2003

The health and well being of Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar Lpez
Rivera is at this moment at risk. Last March, Dr. Taude, a surgeon at USP
Terre Haute, diagnosed bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would
recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired.
Since that time Mr. Lpez has reported to medical staff that he has
increasing pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still
able to exercise vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr.
Lpez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. Lpez
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the
Bureau of Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We have consulted with physicians who inform us that although the hernias
seem to be reducible, with the increasing pain, one of the two hernias might
become stuck, which could result in a surgical emergency.

Oscar, serving a 70 year sentence, is not eligible for release until 2027.
For more than half of his 22 years in prison, he was held in the most
maximum security prisons in the United States in the strictest solitary
confinement, politically punitive conditions calculated to break his will.
Withholding needed medical care is another weapon in the governments
arsenal to seek this same end.

Prison officials at the maximum security United States Penitentiary at Terre
Haute, Indiana, where he is held, seem to be using his high security status
to delay needed medical treatment, at no small cost and risk to Oscars
health and well-being. We have written in protest to the Harley G. Lappin,
director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, and we are calling on all people
of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined
he needs.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:

Comit Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Len,
Apt. 1018, San Juan, PR 00907, Margarita Mergal 787/732-3209
Contacts in U.S.:
National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 W. North Ave.,
Chicago, IL 60647, 773/342-8022

**********************************************************************************

Harley G. Lappin, Director
Federal Bureau of Prisons
320 First Street N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20534
Via facsimile 202/514-6878

Re: Oscar Lpez Rivera, 87651-024
USP Terre Haute

Dear Director Lappin:

In March of 2003, a surgeon at USP Terre Haute, Dr. Taude, diagnosed Mr.
Lpez with bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would recommend to the
Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. Since that time
Mr. Lpez has reported to medical staff that he has increasing pain in the
area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still able to exercise
vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the pain. After
enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. Lpez again saw
Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. Lpez that he had
recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the Bureau of
Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.
We are concerned, based on his attorneys consultation with qualified
outside medical personnel, that although the hernias seem to be reducible,
the pain is increasing, and if one of the hernias becomes stuck, the result
could be a surgical emergency. We further understand that since he has two
hernias, they could both be repaired at the same time so that he will have
to recover from only one surgery, and avoiding the necessity for anesthesia
on two occasions.

Finally, given the political nature of the acts and beliefs for which Mr.
Lpez is in prisonfighting for the independence of Puerto Rico we are
concerned that prison authorities are placing an inappropriate emphasis on
his high security status, at no small cost and risk to Mr. Lpez health and
well-being. We must insist that you immediately provide him with the care
that the surgeon has already determined he needs. You can be sure that we
will continue to monitor his situation and advocate for his human rights.
May we please hear your response.

Sincerely yours,

_________________________________________________________________

Post ID:3322
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-29 09:59:09
Subject:URGENT UPDATE ON OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is happy to support the campaign to demand 
medical treatment for Oscar Lopez Rivera and to circulate this update on the 
campaign.  The time is critical please get these latters out and support 
Oscar, we are close to a date for surgery and we need more letters out there 
to increase the pressure.

GET THOSE LETTERS OUT!!  CIRCUALTE THE CALL TO DEMAND MEDICAL TREATEMENT FOR 
OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
__________________________________________________________________________________

Dear Friends,

The COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO and the BORICUA NATIONAL 
HUMAN RIGHTS NETWORK would like to thank everyone for their letters, faxes, 
and postcards in support of the campaign to obtain medical care for Oscar 
L�pez Rivera. We know that many people in Puerto Rico, Boston, Camden, 
Chicago, Cleveland, New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Washington DC, 
and other areas have already participated in this effort.

We have just received word that on October 27, 2003, Oscar was taken to the 
infirmary and shown the letters that had come in. He was told that the 
letters were unnecessary because the surgery was already approved, but he 
was not given a date. He was also told that they would only operate on one 
of his two hernias.

We need to keep the pressure on to make sure that Oscar is given a date 
immediately, and that both hernias are safely and successfully repaired.

The original press release and sample letter are enclosed in case you do not 
have them.

With many thanks for your solidarity and support!

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907
787/725-6284
PRESS RELEASE
October 21, 2003

The health and well being of Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar L�pez 
Rivera is at this moment at risk. Last March, Dr. Taude, a surgeon at USP 
Terre Haute, diagnosed bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would 
recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. 
Since that time Mr. L�pez has reported to medical staff that he has 
increasing pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still 
able to exercise vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the 
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. 
L�pez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez 
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the 
Bureau of Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We have consulted with physicians who inform us that although the hernias 
seem to be reducible, with the increasing pain, one of the two hernias might 
become stuck, which could result in a surgical emergency.

Oscar, serving a 70 year sentence, is not eligible for release until 2027. 
For more than half of his 22 years in prison, he was held in the most 
maximum security prisons in the United States in the strictest solitary 
confinement, politically punitive conditions calculated to break his will. 
Withholding needed medical care is another weapon in the government�s 
arsenal to seek this same end.

Prison officials at the maximum security United States Penitentiary at Terre 
Haute, Indiana, where he is held, seem to be using his high security status 
to delay needed medical treatment, at no small cost and risk to Oscar�s 
health and well-being. We have written in protest to the Harley G. Lappin, 
director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, and we are calling on all people 
of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be 
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined 
he needs.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:
Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, 
Apt. 1018,
San Juan, PR 00907, Margarita Mergal 787/732-3209

Contacts in U.S.:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, ProLibertad@..., 
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com, bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 
212-927-9065, New Jersey 201-435-3244

National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 W. North Ave., 
Chicago, IL 60647, 773/342-8022

**********************************************************************************

Harley G. Lappin, Director
Federal Bureau of Prisons
320 First Street N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20534
BOP fax number: 202/514-6878

Re: Oscar L�pez Rivera, 87651-024

USP Terre Haute

Dear Director Lappin:
In March of 2003, a surgeon at USP Terre Haute, Dr. Taude, diagnosed Mr. 
L�pez with bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would recommend to the 
Bureau of Prisons (BOP) that the hernias be surgically repaired. Since that 
time, Mr. L�pez has reported to the medical staff that he has increasing 
pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still able to 
exercise vigorously, but he is currently unable to do so because of the 
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since the diagnosis, Mr. 
L�pez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez 
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the BOP 
to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We are concerned, based on his attorney's consultation with qualified 
outside medical personnel, that although the hernias seem to be reducible, 
the pain is increasing, and if one of the hernias becomes stuck, the result 
could be a surgical emergency. We further understand that since he has two 
hernias, they could both be repaired at the same time so that he will have 
to recover from only one surgery, and avoiding the necessity for anesthesia 
on two occasions.

Finally, given the political nature of the acts and beliefs for which Mr. 
L�pez is in prison-fighting for the independence of Puerto Rico- we are 
concerned that prison authorities are placing an inappropriate emphasis on 
his high security status, at no small cost and risk to Mr. L�pez' health and 
well-being. We insist that you immediately provide him with the care that 
the surgeon has already determined he needs. You can be sure that we will 
continue to monitor his situation and advocate for his human rights. We 
expect a forthcoming response.

Sincerely yours,

Name ________________________
Address _______________________

**********************************************************************************

Background Information on Oscar L�pez Rivera and the Puerto Rican Political 
Prisoners.
Oscar L�pez Rivera was among fifteen Puerto Rican men and women imprisoned 
in the 1980's and 1990's for their acts and beliefs in favor of Puerto Rican 
independence. The support for their release included several members of 
congress, Nobel laureates, labor leaders, the Catholic Archbishop of Puerto 
Rico, and all the major Protestant churches of Puerto Rico and many 
denominations in the US, as well as the entire political spectrum in Puerto 
Rico.

By the time most of these supporters became involved in the campaign for 
their release, the prisoners had all served over a decade in prison. The 
supporters held many different views about pacifism vs. just war and 
political status, but they agreed that that these prisoners had received 
disproportionately long sentences (ave. over 65 years) and had more than 
served whatever debt they may have owed to society.

Of those fifteen, in 1999 President Clinton commuted the sentences of 
eleven, declaring that their sentences were indeed disproportionate. Of the 
four who remain in prison, two are scheduled for release before the end of 
next year. Mr. L�pez and Carlos Alberto Torres, however, continue to face 
the equivalent of life sentences, with release dates in 2027 and 2024, 
respectively.

Most of these political prisoners, including Mr. L�pez and Mr. Torres, were 
associated with the FALN (Armed Forces of National Liberation) and were 
convicted of seditious conspiracy (the same charge for which Nelson Mandela 
was convicted, and which has been used primarily against the Puerto Rican 
independence movement). They were accused of military actions against 
corporate and military targets related to the colonial condition of Puerto 
Rico, but not of any act resulting in human injury or loss of life. Because 
they invoked the international law position as prisoners of war, insisting 
that they had a right under the Geneva Conventions to be tried by an 
international tribunal instead of by the colonial power, they did not defend 
themselves in court.

Just as their disproportionate sentences were calculated to punish them for 
their political beliefs and acts, so have their prison conditions, 
particularly in Mr. L�pez� case. For over 12 years he experienced the most 
maximum security prisons in the U.S., including USP Marion, Illinois, 
condemned by Amnesty International as violating virtually every one of the 
United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, and 
ADX Florence, Colorado, the "Alcatraz of the Rockies," known for interning 
those regarded by the government as "terrorists."

Since September 11, the risk to those who remain in prison has only 
increased, as the "anti-terrorist" order of the day has ushered in a harsher 
regime, making their segregation and isolation even more imminent, and 
elevating their high security status to the point where it interferes with 
needed medical care.

While those of us who sought the release of all fifteen celebrate that 
eleven have come home, we continue to strive for the heath, welfare and 
freedom of those who remain behind bars.

Contacts in the US:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, ProLibertad@..., 
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com, bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 
212-927-9065, New Jersey 201-435-3244

Chicago, IL, 60647, 773-342-8022; Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience 
Project, PO Box 770608, Lakewood, OH 44107, , 216 780-9262.

Contacts in Puerto Rico: Margarita Mergal, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, 
Condominio Caribbean Towers, Ave. Ponce de Le�n, n�m. 670, Apto. 1018, San 
Juan, P.R., 00907; Tel: 787-732-3209.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3323
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-29 10:03:19
Subject:URGENT UPDATE ON OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is happy to support the campaign to demand 
medical treatment for Oscar Lopez Rivera and to circulate this update on the 
campaign.  The time is critical please get these latters out and support 
Oscar, we are close to a date for surgery and we need more letters out there 
to increase the pressure.

GET THOSE LETTERS OUT!!  CIRCUALTE THE CALL TO DEMAND MEDICAL TREATEMENT FOR 
OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
__________________________________________________________________________________

Dear Friends,

The COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO and the BORICUA NATIONAL 
HUMAN RIGHTS NETWORK would like to thank everyone for their letters, faxes, 
and postcards in support of the campaign to obtain medical care for Oscar 
L�pez Rivera. We know that many people in Puerto Rico, Boston, Camden, 
Chicago, Cleveland, New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Washington DC, 
and other areas have already participated in this effort.

We have just received word that on October 27, 2003, Oscar was taken to the 
infirmary and shown the letters that had come in. He was told that the 
letters were unnecessary because the surgery was already approved, but he 
was not given a date. He was also told that they would only operate on one 
of his two hernias.

We need to keep the pressure on to make sure that Oscar is given a date 
immediately, and that both hernias are safely and successfully repaired.

The original press release and sample letter are enclosed in case you do not 
have them.

With many thanks for your solidarity and support!

COMIT� PRO DERECHOS HUMANOS DE PUERTO RICO
Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, Apto. 1018
San Juan Puerto Rico 00907
787/725-6284
PRESS RELEASE
October 21, 2003

The health and well being of Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar L�pez 
Rivera is at this moment at risk. Last March, Dr. Taude, a surgeon at USP 
Terre Haute, diagnosed bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would 
recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that the hernias be surgically repaired. 
Since that time Mr. L�pez has reported to medical staff that he has 
increasing pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still 
able to exercise vigorously, but he currently unable to do so because of the 
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since diagnosis, Mr. 
L�pez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez 
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the 
Bureau of Prisons to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We have consulted with physicians who inform us that although the hernias 
seem to be reducible, with the increasing pain, one of the two hernias might 
become stuck, which could result in a surgical emergency.

Oscar, serving a 70 year sentence, is not eligible for release until 2027. 
For more than half of his 22 years in prison, he was held in the most 
maximum security prisons in the United States in the strictest solitary 
confinement, politically punitive conditions calculated to break his will. 
Withholding needed medical care is another weapon in the government�s 
arsenal to seek this same end.

Prison officials at the maximum security United States Penitentiary at Terre 
Haute, Indiana, where he is held, seem to be using his high security status 
to delay needed medical treatment, at no small cost and risk to Oscar�s 
health and well-being. We have written in protest to the Harley G. Lappin, 
director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, and we are calling on all people 
of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be 
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined 
he needs.

Contacts in Puerto Rico:
Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, Condominio Caribbean Towers, 670 Ponce de Le�n, 
Apt. 1018,
San Juan, PR 00907, Margarita Mergal 787/732-3209

Contacts in U.S.:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, ProLibertad@..., 
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com, bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 
212-927-9065, New Jersey 201-435-3244

National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 W. North Ave., 
Chicago, IL 60647, 773/342-8022

**********************************************************************************

Harley G. Lappin, Director
Federal Bureau of Prisons
320 First Street N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20534
BOP fax number: 202/514-6878

Re: Oscar L�pez Rivera, 87651-024

USP Terre Haute

Dear Director Lappin:
In March of 2003, a surgeon at USP Terre Haute, Dr. Taude, diagnosed Mr. 
L�pez with bilateral hernias. The doctor indicated he would recommend to the 
Bureau of Prisons (BOP) that the hernias be surgically repaired. Since that 
time, Mr. L�pez has reported to the medical staff that he has increasing 
pain in the area of the hernias. Three months ago he was still able to 
exercise vigorously, but he is currently unable to do so because of the 
pain. After enduring months of pain and discomfort since the diagnosis, Mr. 
L�pez again saw Dr. Taude in early October. The doctor assured Mr. L�pez 
that he had recommended surgery, but apprised him that it was up to the BOP 
to decided whether to provide the surgery.

We are concerned, based on his attorney's consultation with qualified 
outside medical personnel, that although the hernias seem to be reducible, 
the pain is increasing, and if one of the hernias becomes stuck, the result 
could be a surgical emergency. We further understand that since he has two 
hernias, they could both be repaired at the same time so that he will have 
to recover from only one surgery, and avoiding the necessity for anesthesia 
on two occasions.

Finally, given the political nature of the acts and beliefs for which Mr. 
L�pez is in prison-fighting for the independence of Puerto Rico- we are 
concerned that prison authorities are placing an inappropriate emphasis on 
his high security status, at no small cost and risk to Mr. L�pez' health and 
well-being. We insist that you immediately provide him with the care that 
the surgeon has already determined he needs. You can be sure that we will 
continue to monitor his situation and advocate for his human rights. We 
expect a forthcoming response.

Sincerely yours,

Name ________________________
Address _______________________

**********************************************************************************

Background Information on Oscar L�pez Rivera and the Puerto Rican Political 
Prisoners.
Oscar L�pez Rivera was among fifteen Puerto Rican men and women imprisoned 
in the 1980's and 1990's for their acts and beliefs in favor of Puerto Rican 
independence. The support for their release included several members of 
congress, Nobel laureates, labor leaders, the Catholic Archbishop of Puerto 
Rico, and all the major Protestant churches of Puerto Rico and many 
denominations in the US, as well as the entire political spectrum in Puerto 
Rico.

By the time most of these supporters became involved in the campaign for 
their release, the prisoners had all served over a decade in prison. The 
supporters held many different views about pacifism vs. just war and 
political status, but they agreed that that these prisoners had received 
disproportionately long sentences (ave. over 65 years) and had more than 
served whatever debt they may have owed to society.

Of those fifteen, in 1999 President Clinton commuted the sentences of 
eleven, declaring that their sentences were indeed disproportionate. Of the 
four who remain in prison, two are scheduled for release before the end of 
next year. Mr. L�pez and Carlos Alberto Torres, however, continue to face 
the equivalent of life sentences, with release dates in 2027 and 2024, 
respectively.

Most of these political prisoners, including Mr. L�pez and Mr. Torres, were 
associated with the FALN (Armed Forces of National Liberation) and were 
convicted of seditious conspiracy (the same charge for which Nelson Mandela 
was convicted, and which has been used primarily against the Puerto Rican 
independence movement). They were accused of military actions against 
corporate and military targets related to the colonial condition of Puerto 
Rico, but not of any act resulting in human injury or loss of life. Because 
they invoked the international law position as prisoners of war, insisting 
that they had a right under the Geneva Conventions to be tried by an 
international tribunal instead of by the colonial power, they did not defend 
themselves in court.

Just as their disproportionate sentences were calculated to punish them for 
their political beliefs and acts, so have their prison conditions, 
particularly in Mr. L�pez� case. For over 12 years he experienced the most 
maximum security prisons in the U.S., including USP Marion, Illinois, 
condemned by Amnesty International as violating virtually every one of the 
United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, and 
ADX Florence, Colorado, the "Alcatraz of the Rockies," known for interning 
those regarded by the government as "terrorists."

Since September 11, the risk to those who remain in prison has only 
increased, as the "anti-terrorist" order of the day has ushered in a harsher 
regime, making their segregation and isolation even more imminent, and 
elevating their high security status to the point where it interferes with 
needed medical care.

While those of us who sought the release of all fifteen celebrate that 
eleven have come home, we continue to strive for the heath, welfare and 
freedom of those who remain behind bars.

Contacts in the US:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, ProLibertad@..., 
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com, bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 
212-927-9065, New Jersey 201-435-3244

National Boricua Human Rights Network, P.O. Box 112, 2820 North Ave., 
Chicago, IL, 60647, 773-342-8022; Interfaith Prisoners of Conscience 
Project, PO Box 770608, Lakewood, OH 44107, , 216 780-9262.

Contacts in Puerto Rico: Margarita Mergal, Comit� Pro Derechos Humanos, 
Condominio Caribbean Towers, Ave. Ponce de Le�n, n�m. 670, Apto. 1018, San 
Juan, P.R., 00907; Tel: 787-732-3209.

_________________________________________________________________
Surf and talk on the phone at the same time with broadband Internet access. 
Get high-speed for as low as $29.95/month (depending on the local service 
providers in your area).  https://broadband.msn.com

Post ID:3324
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-11-02 13:16:05
Subject:Vieques Picket/Holiday Party/Oscar Lopez
Message:

THURSDAY DECEMBER 4, 2003 AT 5:30PM
PICKET IN PROTEST OF THE SENTENCING OF THE VIEQUES 12  AT THE UNITED NATIONS 
RALPH BUNCHE PARK E42ND ST AND 1ST AVENUE

Join the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign on Thursday December 4th, 2003 as we 
protest the unfair and
unjust sentencing of the Vieques 12!!

The Vieques 12 are activists, community members and residents of 
Vieques/mainland Puerto Rico that have been targeted by the FBI for their 
activities in Vieques on May 1st, 2003. The arrests of ten of the Vieques 12 
in June is another attempt by the FBI and U.S. government to repress and 
punish Vieques activists for participating in the struggle to remove the 
U.S. Navy from Vieques.  Two of the twelve, Jose Perez went to trial in 
Sept. and Jose Velez turned himself in after the arrest.  It is also an 
attempt to discourage activists from continuing the struggle to achieve the 
four demands of the People of Vieques 
(Decontamination-Devolution-Development-Demilitarization)!!

We urge all people in solidarity with the Vieques cause to help us protest 
this unjust and unfair targeting of activists by the FBI in Puerto Rico.

We are calling on all organizations to endorse this activity and commit to 
mobilizing for this event!!  To endorse please email 
ProLibertad@..., call 718-601-4751!!

__________________________________________________________________________________

SATURDAY DECEMBER 13, 2003 AT 7PM PROLIBERTAD HOLIDAY PARTY!!
THE BRECHT FORUM 122 W27TH ST 10th floor (BETWEEN 6-7TH AVES.)

Join the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for our annual Holiday Party at the 
Brecht!!

Join us for a night of DELICIOUS PUERTO RICAN FOOD, FABULOUS MUSIC (Salsa, 
Merengue and Hip Hop), DANCING, and our famous HOLIDAY AUCTION OF 
ART/COQUITO/CRAFTS for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Commissary Fund!! 
ONLY $10 (no one will be turned away)

Come out and party with us as we celebrate a year of organzing for freedom!! 
  All are welcome!!  if you are  a poet and want to perform come on over, 
you want to sing, we would love to have you, if you have any talent and want 
to share it, we would love you too!!

__________________________________________________________________________________

of conscience to join in a letter writing campaign to insist that Oscar be
immediately provided with the medical care their own doctors have determined
